May 4, 1951.

Mr. Wm. Gowans,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Ilford, Manitoba.

Re: Voucher No. 328

We are returning your voucher No. 328 and wish to draw your attention to the fact that Marion Trout No. 0685 of the Brandon Residential School, according to our records, was 15 in June 1950 and Ellen Andrews No. 0675 of the same school was 14 years of age in June 1950. It is evident according to these records that these two girls have not been discharged from the Brandon School and decided simply not to return. Under these circumstances we believe that the responsibility for their transportation should be the parents'. You may submit another voucher for the expenditure that the Reverend Mr. Gibson had to disburse for these two pupils.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Encl.
0685 Marion Trout
age 15 June 1950
Return

0675 Ellen Andrews
age 14 June 1950
Return
Mr. Wm. Gowans, Supt.,
Nelson River Agency,
Ilford, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Gowans:

Re: Account for return fare from Brandon Residential School for Ellen Andrews & Marion Trout as per my letter of Oct. 3, 1950.

Marion Trout & Ellen Andrews, pupils of Brandon Residential School came home last July for holidays but did not return to school. Marion was 16 in July and Ellen was 16 in October. Application is hereby made on behalf of the parents & myself for reimbursement for their travel expenses, Winnipeg to God's Lake. The total cost for each girl was $28.00, a total expense account of altogether $56.00. This was made up as follows:

S.S. Keenora - Selkirk to Norway House - (½ fare rate) - $13.00 each

Canoe trip & food - June 28 to July 16th - $15.00 each
(we were delayed due to motor failure, had to return to Norway House)

total $28.00 each

The girls' parents paid the S.S. Keenora fare. I paid for the canoe trip. Thus payment is to be made as follows:

1. for 2 fares on S.S. Keenora.......
   to Jerry Trout (parent of Marion Trout)........... $13.00
   Address - God's Lake, Man.
   to Mary Andrews (parent of Ellen Andrews)....... $13.00
   Address - God's Lake Narrows, Man.
   ...........total $26.00

2. for canoe travel & food for these two girls.......
   to Rev. H.B. Gibson, God's Lake Narrows, Man. $15.00 each girl
   ...........total $30.00

Brandon return fare expenses thus a total of : $56.00

Thanking you, I am,

Yours very truly,

Howard B. Gibson.

God's Lake Narrows, Man.,
March 30, 1951.

Director of Education,
Indians Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

This is to certify that my daughter, Ellen Andrews, has returned home from Brandon Residential School in June 1950, following completion of her schooling. Her return fare was paid by Rev. H.B. Gibson, God's Lake Narrows, Man., and the Indian Affairs Branch can reimburse him for this. The fare amounted to $28.00, being $13 from Winnipeg to Norway House on the S.S. Keenora, and $15.00 from Norway House to God's Lake.

[Signature]

Mary Andrews
(Mother of Ellen Andrews)

Witnesses - Rev. H.B. Gibson.

Joseph White

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6259, file 576-10, part 17)
God's Lake, Man.
March 28, 1951.

Director of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

This is to certify that my daughter, Marion Trout, has returned to my home at God's Lake following completion of her schooling at Brandon Residential School. Her return fare was paid by Rev. H.B. Gibson, God's Lake Narrows, Man., and the Indian Affairs Branch can reimburse him for this. The fare amounted to $28.00, being $13 from Winnipeg to Norway House and $15 from Norway House to God's Lake.

JERRY TROUT (his mark)
(FATHER OF MARION TROUT)

Witnessed by: Rev. H.B. Gibson,
Bernard Blend

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this day of , 1951.

BETWEEN

HIS MAJESTY THE KING IN RIGHT OF CANADA as represented by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, hereinafter called "The Minister"

OF THE FIRST PART

and

MANITOBA MOTOR TRANSIT LIMITED of the City of Brandon in the Province of Manitoba, hereinafter called "The Operator"

OF THE SECOND PART

WHEREAS it is deemed necessary to provide for the transportation to and from schools in the City of Brandon of certain Indian school children who are being maintained at the Brandon Indian Residential School;

AND WHEREAS the Minister has entered into an arrangement with the Operator for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto;

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto as follows:

1. The Operator shall inaugurate and maintain commencing the 5th day of January, 1951, and continuing until this agreement shall be terminated in the manner hereinafter described, a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such schools as the Minister shall from time to time designate and notify to the Operator within the limits of the City of Brandon such children as shall from time to time be designated by the Minister or his Superintendent of the Portage la Prairie Indian Agency and notified by him to the Operator.
2. Subject to the provisions of the Manitoba Highway Traffic Act and regulations made thereunder and to any ordinances or by-laws of the City of Brandon each child shall be permitted to debus and embus at such points within the City of Brandon as may be designated by the Minister or Superintendent as most convenient for the purpose for which the child is being transported.

3. The Operator shall ensure that the vehicle or vehicles shall for the purposes of loading and unloading be brought to such point within the grounds of the Brandon Indian Residential School as may from time to time be designated by the Minister or his Superintendent aforesaid.

4. The Operator shall conform to the instructions of the principal of the said residential school with regard to the time of departure of the vehicles employed in the carrying out of this agreement from the residential school in the mornings and with regard to the time of return to the residential school in the afternoons and the Operator shall take all reasonable measures to ensure that the aforesaid pupils arrive at and depart from the aforesaid city schools conveniently for the proper discharge of the school duties of such pupils.

5. The Operator shall comply with all and every provision of the Manitoba Highway Traffic Act (Revised Statutes of Manitoba, etc.,...) and shall comply with any ordinance or by-laws of the City of Brandon now or hereafter in force and applicable.

6. The Operator shall maintain a good, safe, efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Operator shall not be bound to maintain the service on any day or days when the usual route or any alternative route is rendered impassible or dangerous by reason of
deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Operator but the Operator shall not be entitled to any remuneration for such day or days.

7. The Operator shall at the Operator's own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any of the Operator's vehicles and in respect of any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Minister and such insurance shall cover the Operator and all or any liability of His Majesty in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Operator shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Minister or his Superintendent and produce the policies to the Minister or his Superintendent for inspection upon demand.

8. The Operator shall also at the Operator's own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of His Majesty against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of His Majesty for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported in any motor vehicle provided by the Operator. The premiums for such insurance...
shall be paid by the Operator and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of His Majesty.

9. The Operator shall employ as drivers and assistants of such vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and at once shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle operated in carrying out this agreement if so requested in writing by the Minister or Superintendent aforesaid.

10. The Operator shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no adult person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Operator duly appointed to assist the chauffeur or any person designated by the Minister or Superintendent aforesaid shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while such vehicle is being operated for the purposes set out in this agreement.

11. The Operator agrees that while any of his vehicles shall be operated for the purposes of this agreement on any private road or other place not being a highway or public thoroughfare within the meaning of any provincial statute, municipal ordinance or regulations made thereunder his liability shall be the same as is imposed upon him while such vehicle is operated on a highway.

12. For the transportation service hereinbefore described the Minister shall pay to the Operator fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each school day on which such service has been supplied to the satisfaction of the Minister or Superintendent aforesaid.

13. This agreement shall come into effect from the fifth day of January, One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty-One, and shall remain in effect unless and until notice is given by either party to the other party of intention to terminate the said agreement. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given and received not less than one
month prior to the date on which the agreement is to be terminated.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties to this agreement have hereunto set their hands and seal.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered

in the presence of

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this day

of , 1951.

BETWEEN

HIS MAJESTY THE KING in right of Canada as represented by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, hereinafter called "The Minister"

OF THE FIRST PART

and

MANITOBA MOTOR TRANSIT LIMITED of the City of Brandon in the Province of Manitoba, hereinafter called "The Operator"

OF THE SECOND PART

WHEREAS it is deemed necessary to provide for the transportation to and from schools in the City of Brandon of certain Indian school children who are being maintained at the Brandon Indian Residential School;

AND WHEREAS the Minister has entered into an arrangement with the Operator for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto;

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto as follows:

1. The Operator shall inaugurate and maintain commencing the 5th day of January, 1951, and continuing until this agreement shall be terminated in the manner hereinafter described, a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such schools as the Minister shall from time to time designate and notify to the Operator, within the limits of the City of Brandon, such children as shall from time to time be designated by the Minister or his Superintendent of the Portage la Prairie Indian Agency and notified by him to the Operator.
2. Subject to the provisions of the Manitoba Highway Traffic Act and regulations made thereunder and to any ordinances or by-laws of the City of Brandon each child shall be taken on board the vehicle and shall be permitted to alight therefrom at such points within the City of Brandon as may be designated by the Minister or Superintendent as most convenient.

3. The Operator shall ensure that the vehicle or vehicles shall for the purposes of loading and unloading be brought to such point within the grounds of the Brandon Indian Residential School as may from time to time be designated by the Minister or his Superintendent aforesaid.

4. The Operator shall conform to the instructions of the principal of the aforesaid residential school with regard to the time of departure of the vehicles employed in the carrying out of this agreement from the residential school in the mornings and with regard to the time of return to the residential school in the afternoons and the Operator shall take all reasonable measures to ensure that the aforesaid pupils arrive at and depart from the aforesaid city schools conveniently for the proper discharge of the school duties of such pupils.

5. The Operator shall comply with all and every provision of the Manitoba Highway Traffic Act (Revised Statutes of Manitoba, 1940, Chapter 93) and shall comply with any ordinance or by-laws of the City of Brandon now or hereafter in force and applicable.

6. The Operator shall maintain a good, safe, efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Operator shall not be bound to maintain the service on any day or days
when the usual route or any alternative route is rendered impassible or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Operator but the Operator shall not be entitled to any remuneration for such day or days.

7. The Operator shall at the Operator's own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any of the Operator's vehicles and in respect of any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Minister and such insurance shall cover the Operator and all or any liability of His Majesty in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Operator shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Minister or his Superintendent and produce the policies to the Minister or his Superintendent for inspection upon demand.

8. The Operator shall also at the Operator's own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of His Majesty against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of His Majesty for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported in any motor vehicle.
provided by the Operator for the purposes set out in this agreement. The premiums for such insurance shall be paid by the Operator and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of His Majesty.

9. The Operator shall pay all operating costs.

10. The Operator shall employ as drivers and assistants of such vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and at once shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle operated in carrying out this agreement if so requested in writing by the Minister or Superintendent aforesaid.

11. The Operator shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no adult person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Operator duly appointed to assist the chauffeur or any person designated by the Minister, Superintendent or Principal shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while such vehicle is being operated for the purposes set out in this agreement.

12. The Operator agrees that while any of his vehicles shall be operated for the purposes of this agreement on any private road or other place not being a highway or public thoroughfare within the meaning of any provincial statute, municipal ordinance or regulations made thereunder his liability shall be the same as is imposed upon him while such vehicle is operated on a highway.

13. For the transportation service hereinbefore described the Minister shall pay to the Operator fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each school day on which such service has been supplied to the satisfaction of the Minister or Superintendent aforesaid.

14. This agreement shall come into effect from the fifth day of January, One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty-One, and shall
remain in effect unless and until notice is given by either party to the other party of intention to terminate the said agreement. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given and received not less than one month prior to the date on which the agreement is to be terminated.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties to this agreement have hereunto set their hands and seal.

COMPLAINANT - Robert G. KIRKNESS, Clandebaye, Man.

ACCUSED - Wesley HUNDLE and Richard KIRWATIN, T.I., Juveniles, Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

CHARGE - that Wesley HUNDLE and Richard KIRWATIN, children, did on or about the 18th day of April A.D., 1951, at Clandebaye, in the said Province, commit a delinquency, in that they did unlawfully break and enter the Canadian Pacific Railway Bank-house, situated at Clandebaye, Manitoba, and therein did steal one pair high-top leather boots, of the value of Fifteen Dollars ($15.00) the property of Robert G. KIRKNESS, Clandebaye, Manitoba, contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided.

16-4-51

1. At approximately 8:40 a.m. this date, a phone call was received at this office from Mr. Robert G. KIRKNESS, an employee of the C.P.R. section gang, at Clandebaye, Man., who advised that the C.P.R. station house and bunk house at Clandebaye had been broken into sometime between 7:00 p.m. the 17-4-51 and the 8:00 a.m. the 18-4-51, and that a pair of men's, high-top work boots had been stolen from the bunk house. KIRKNESS further stated that two half-breeds or Indians had been seen hanging around the station the evening previous, and he believed they might have been responsible for this offense.

2. Upon receipt of this information, immediate patrol was made by the writer to Clandebaye, where KIRKNESS was interviewed, also Mr. Mike OKO, Foreman of the section gang. OKO stated he had quit work at approximately 7:00 p.m. the evening previous, and on leaving the station, he had noticed two half-breeds or Indians hanging around the station. OKO informed them that they could not stay there and told them to leave, which they did. OKO did not see them after this. He stated further that he had returned to the station at approximately 8:00 a.m. of the 18th., at which time he found that someone had been in the station. OKO stated he had found nothing stolen, but he had found evidence of three empty egg crates which had been left inside the station, had been burned in the stove. Upon arrival of KIRKNESS to the bunk house, which is situated across the train tracks from the station, they found someone had also been in the bunk house, and had stolen a pair of high top, ten inch, man's work boots, belonging to KIRKNESS. It was believed that nothing else had been taken.

3. Investigation was made of the train station, and it was found that entry had been gained through the door. I might explain that the station is a one-roomed building.

FILE NUMBERS, HEADING AND MARGINAL REFERENCE ARE TO BE PROPERLY FILLED IN.
BUILDING, which serves as a lodging house and waiting room both, there is no agent in attendance. The door of the station is not locked, although it is kept closed with a hook-and-eye type catch, there was no evidence of any damage done in opening the door. Found inside the station was a common type gunny sack and a handkerchief, neither bore any special mark of identification. It was learned that there had been three empty egg crates inside the station on the evening previous, but investigation showed these had been broken up and burned in the stove inside the station. It was believed nothing else had been taken or disturbed. Several footprints were noted on the ground surface immediately around the station, but these could have been made by any number of people either working or waiting at the station. The wooden surfaces of the station did not appear suitable for fingerprint purposes.

4. Investigation was then made of the bunk house, which is situated approximately 100 yards north of the station, on the other side of the train tracks. It too is a one-roomed building, and is suitable for living in, but is presently used for the workmen to change in, there was no-one sleeping in it the night of the break-in. It was ascertained that entry had been gained to the bunk house through the door, which had been locked with a Yale type lock. KIRKNESS explained that the key to this door was usually kept just inside a screen window beside the door, and one could easily reach it by opening one side of the screen, this is apparently what happened, as it was found the key had been disturbed, further that the door bore no signs of having been forced. A further check was made of the bunk house by KIRKNESS, but he could find nothing else missing, apart from his work boots. Footprint impressions were found in the soft earth underneath one window, but these were not believed suitable for reproduction. The wooden surfaces of the bunk house did not appear suitable for fingerprint purposes.

5. OKO described the two men he had seen there the evening previous as being either Half-breed or Indians, 20 to 25 years, #1. approximately 5'8", wearing a red and black plaid shirt, overalls, and a cap - #2. shorter in height than #1, wearing a light plaid shirt, overalls, and cap. OKO could not enlarge at all on this information.

6. With this in mind, a patrol was made of Clandeboye and district, but no-one could remember having seen two men of these descriptions previously. It was learned that there were two camps of Indians who were trapping muskrats, approximately 4 miles east of Clandeboye, and it was thought possible that the two described men might have been on their way to these camps. A patrol was made to these camps, and the men interviewed, but all stated they had not seen anyone answering the descriptions given. Check was made at a number of farm houses along the way, but nothing of any value was learned.

7. Patrol returned to Clandeboye and continued north on PTH #9, and it was learned that two men answering these descriptions had been seen at Petersfield at approximately 7:00 a.m. that morning, the 13-4-51. Extensive enquiries were made at Petersfield, but nothing further was learned. It was believed at this time that the two men might have been hitch-hiking.
HITCH-HIKING further north, and patrol was continued on to Nettley, Man. It was learned at this point that the two men had stopped there at approximately 9:00 or 10:00 a.m., and had been fed at William ROBINSON's farm. Mrs. ROBINSON was interviewed, and a different description obtained, in that the two suspects were young boys, around 16 or 17 years, and that the tallest one was wearing a fedora hat, with a string around his chin to hold the hat on. The rest of Mrs. ROBINSON's description tallied with that obtained at Clandeboys. It was further learned that the two boys had stated they were on their way to Gimli, Man.

8. In view of this, patrol was continued further north to Winnipeg Beach, and a check was made with merchants, etc., of that town. Streets of down-town Winnipeg Beach, stores and pool halls were searched, but two boys answering these descriptions were not noticed. The N.C.O. I/c that Detachment was advised of the facts of this case, and was requested to be on the watch for these two boys.

9. Patrol was then continued to Gimli where a like search was made of restaurants, pool halls, etc., was made, but with no result. The Cst. I/c that Detachment was also given the facts of this case, to be on the watch for these two boys. Patrol was then made back to Selkirk, with enquiries conducted along the way.

10. At approximately 2:45 a.m. this date, a L.D. phone call was received from Arborg Detachment, advising they were holding two boys at that office, who had admitted breaking into the C.P.R. Station at Clandeboys the day previous. Arrangements were made for the escorting of these two boys back to Selkirk, and patrol was made immediately to Winnipeg Beach, where the Arborg detachment members were met, and the two prisoners handed over.

11. Upon arrival back at Selkirk, the two boys were questioned, and they were found to be Wesley RUNDLE, 16 years, and Richard KEWATIN, 15 years. It was also learned at this time that the two boys had escaped from the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., on Saturday afternoon, the 14-4-51, and had hitchhiked rides from Brandon to Selkirk, and had walked to Clandeboys they had intended to go to Fisher River, Man. The two boys admitted they had broken into the C.P.R. station and bunk house at Clandeboys, and in view of this they were given the usual police warning, after which they volunteered the following statements:

Statement of Wesley RUNDLE, 16 Years, Fisher River, Manitoba.

"On Tuesday, April 17, 1951, I came from Winnipeg to Selkirk accompanied by Richard KEWATIN, we were heading for Fisher River. We stopped in Selkirk for a while, and then we walked to Clandeboys. We got to Clandeboys about 9:00 o'clock at night and we decided to stay there overnight. We were walking up the railroad tracks and when we came to the train station we decided to stay there for the night. The door was locked but I undid it and Richard and I went in. It was cold in the station, so we took some egg crates that were in..."
THAT WE'RE IN there and broke them up and burned them to keep warm, then we slept in the station overnight.

The next morning, Wednesday, April 18, we got up about 5:00 a.m. and left the train station. I saw a bunk house across the tracks, so Richard and I went over to it. I decided to break into it, so I took the screen off one of the windows and was going to go in through the window, but I found the key to the door just inside the window sill, so I unlocked the door and Richard and I went inside. We looked around inside, and I saw a pair of boots on the floor, so I decided to take them. I put the boots on inside the bunk house and threw my boots away in the bush. Richard and I went through all the cupboards and drawers in the bunk house, and I took a pair of steel cleats for the boots. We left after and walked back through Clandeboye, and then north on the highway.

We left Clandeboye and got a ride in a car to Gimli. We kept on going and walked to Arborg.

When we got to Arborg we were looking for a place to stay, and we went to a house and we found it was the police office. They asked us questions and told them we had escaped from the Brandon Indian Residential School on Saturday. The police at Arborg then put Richard and me in their car and took us to Winnipeg Beach and another police car took us to Selkirk.

Wit: J.F. Friend, R.C.M.P. (Sgd) Wesley Rundle.

Statement of Richard KEWATIN, 15 years, Balcarres, Saskatchewan

"On Tuesday, April 17, 1951, I came from Winnipeg to Selkirk with Wesley Rundle. We stopped in Selkirk for a while, and then we walked on to Clandeboye, we were going to Wesley's place at Fisher River. We got to Clandeboye at about 7:00 o'clock and we decided to stay there overnight. We were walking near the train tracks and we went over to the station and went in, it was cold inside there so we made a fire out of some egg crates in the station.

We left the station the next morning and then we noticed a bunk house across the tracks so we decided to go over and break in. I helped Wesley take the screen off one of the windows and we saw a key inside the screen on the window sill. Wesley took the key and opened the door with it, then we went inside. We looked through the cupboards and drawers, and I took a pocket knife off the top of the cupboard. Wesley took a pair of boots and when he left we put them on.

We walked back through Clandeboye onto the highway, and then started walking north. We got a ride in a car to Gimli and then from Gimli we went to Arborg. We were looking for a place to stay overnight and we went to a house and found it was a police office. The police there asked us some questions, and we told them we had escaped from the Brandon Indian Residential School. Then the police put us in their car and took us to Winnipeg Beach and some more policemen met us there and took us to Selkirk.

Wit: J.F. Friend, R.C.M.P. (Sgd) Richard Kewatin.

12. The articles mentioned in the above statements which were stolen, the boots, steel cleats for the boots, and the pocket knife, were all recovered in possession of the two boys. Later the same a.m., the complainant KIRKNESS was...
WAS contacted, and he advised he was desirous of laying a charge as above against these two boys. Charge was laid same date before Mr. R. Millidge, J.P., Selkirk, and a Warrant to Apprehend was issued. The two boys were then escorted to the Vaughan St. Detention Home, Winnipeg, and handed over to authorities at that point, receipt being obtained.

13. At this same time, this matter was taken up with Mr. A. KITCHEN, Administration Officer, Juvenile Court, Winnipeg, and he was given the facts of this case. Mr. KITCHEN stated this would be referred to Judge E.J. NEALEY, Juvenile Judge, and in view of this, the two accused were remanded in custody without plea, to appear at Winnipeg Juvenile Court at 10:00 a.m., the 23-4-51.

14. Winnipeg Communications Branch was also given the facts of this case, and were requested to advise Brandon Sub-Division to contact the necessary authorities at the Residential School at that point.

20-4-51

15. With particular reference to the three egg crates which the two boys broke up and burned in the C.P.R. station at Clandeboye, the writer was advised by Investigator IRWIN, of the C.P.R. Investigation Branch, Winnipeg, that in view of the fact that the station at Clandeboye is what is called a "Flag Stop" with no agent in attendance, owners of any property left there do so at their own risk, and may hold no claim for any stolen property against the C.P.R. The owners of these egg crates, Mr. A. HOLLANDS, Clandeboye, and Mr. N. GOUTURE, also of Clandeboye, were advised of this, but they stated that in view of the fact that the egg crates are of no importance and little value, they wished no further action taken. Further that they were not desirous of any further police action.

16. In view of the above, file in this connection will be held open pending the appearances of the two accused in Juvenile Court on the 23-4-51. A further report will submitted after that time. Attached here to, please find Forms 246 covering the seizing of the stolen boots, heel cleats and knife. Extra copy of this report attached for the information of the authorities I/c of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

Mr. B. E. Olson,
Superintendent, Glandeboyne Agency,
Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Olson:

I wonder if you could obtain from one of your legal friends a ruling on the following problem:

Three Treaty Indians ages, 11, 12, 15 were had up under the Juvenile Delinquents Act for breaking and entering.

After hearing the evidence and the plea of Guilty by the boys the Judge ruled that the three boys

1. Were to be sent to Indian Residential Schools.
2. They would remain under the supervision of the Chief of the Bloodvein Band, who would receive the co-operation of the local Judge, until arrangements were made for the acceptance of the lads, in question, in Residential Schools.

After the trial the Prosecutor, Cons. Henzie stated that the boys were still his prisoners and with this idea in mind sent the following wire to his O.C. in Winnipeg Quote.

"Three Treaty Indians, Juveniles, convicted breaking and entering and theft, Bloodvein, Man. Sentenced to be placed in Indian Boarding Schools. May instructions be received reference their escort, transportation and custody". End of quote.

It will be noticed that no mention is made of ages or the Judge's decision regarding the supervision of their behaviour until their acceptance in Residential School.

I maintain that through the above action of the Cons. the decision of the Court was overruled by the prosecutor.

I ask you to obtain a ruling from a Private friend in the legal profession in case a like case occur at some future date. I may add that I let the Cons. carry out his wishes in fact have not mentioned any objections. I did this as the boys have remained on the Reserve until Cons. Henzie escorts them to Winnipeg. Nevertheless I maintain that a prosecutor cannot overrule a decision of a Judge. By the way, this is the first offence for these boys.

Yours sincerely, F. Leach
Bloodvein,
Matheson Island P.O.,
Manitoba.

August 23, 1950.

Selkirk, Man.

Dear Mr. Olson:

Freddy Bouchie Hamilton, age 11, Henry Duck age 15; and Charley Duck age nearly 12 were had up for breaking and entering the store of Ed. Kirkness at Bloodvein. These boys are not bad characters but as this was the third time that the doors of the same store had been tampered with I thought it better to send the boyds to a boarding school.

Freddy Bouchie, R.C., will be accepted at the McIntosh Residential School. Our Father Provincial approved of this. If you telephone No. 201227 or call at the Juniorat in St. Boniface immediate transport to McIntosh will be arranged.

October 16, 1951.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Further to your letter re "Truancy" at this school.

I have discussed the matter with Rev. Dr. Best and we have carefully considered all possible angles of the situation.

I am first to draw your attention to the fact that Mr. R.S. Davis has instituted numerous "investigations" during the last few years. Whether he has made reports to your office or not I, of course, do not know. The net result of the various visits of officials from the Portage La Prairie and Winnipeg offices in the past have been that additional trouble has been stirred up and for a few weeks the school has been seething with discontent.

I shall not permit any further "investigations", instigated by the Winnipeg office unless Dr. Best has been notified and given an opportunity to either be present or have a representative of the United Church present at the same time as the official of Indian Affairs.

During the past seven years I have from time to time drawn the attention of visiting Indian Affairs officials to the need for recreation space, playing fields on the school grounds level, and recreational equipment for outdoor sports. If, as, and when this matter receives attention I am prepared to employ a Playground Supervisor who will give direction and supervision.

I shall in future return immediately to their homes any pupils that I find have been sent to this school instead of to a reform school after having been brought up in police court for infractions of the law.

In this connection, most of our trouble stems from children who have been sent to this school against the will of their parents and who have been kept in the school through the summer holidays by direction of the Indian Supt. or Regional Supervisor. This action on the part of Indian Affairs officials gives the child a feeling of resentment against the school which becomes localized in their attitude toward the individual staff members in the school. This in a group of forty to fifty boys or girls eventually leads to serious trouble.
Mr. Philip Phelan

I have for several years been calling attention to the need for a shop in which we could hold Manual Training activities but no action has been taken.

Mr. Marcoux recently suggested to me that I make a request for an additional building in which we could have another classroom and also a manual training shop. However with the very real need for a good dairy barn to be built I do not feel that the matter of an extra classroom so that all the children would be in school all day for five days a week is just as pressing.

The majority of the children that come to this school will never go on to High School and Collegiate and for them the training in the practical work of the school is very important.

It must be always borne in mind that no school can at any time completely take the place of the home in the thought life of the child and strangers definitely cannot take the place of parents, no matter how much they may try so to do.

The problem in this school is not one that can be solved overnight, nor is there any easy solution. I am prepared as I always have been to work with anyone who has constructive suggestions to make but when people who have never spent any time in this school to observe the day to day operation of the different departments can only make destructive criticisms the problem becomes just so much more difficult. I have received some helpful suggestions from Mr. Marcoux but this is the first time that any help whatever has been offered.

Our main building is now in good condition and we are endeavouring to train the children to look after the equipment and keep damage to a minimum. The toilet facilities still leave much to be desired as they are old fashioned troughs with an overhead flush tank.

I am informed by the Engineering Services that long overdue repairs are to be made to our water system and it is hoped that when these are completed we will be able to spare sufficient water to have a skating rink for winter use. Unless these repairs are attended to immediately there will be too much frost in the ground for anything to be done before next May.

If you have any suggestions to make I shall be very glad to receive them and at least endeavour to carry them out.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg,
Manitoba.

October 16, 1951.

Dear Sir:

Since you interviewed the three boys from this school in Winnipeg recently we have had a great deal of trouble with them. Herbert Spence has been very insubordinate in his attitude to the various staff members and when I talked to him about it his reply was "Mr. Davis told me that if I did not get treated right to telephone him at Winnipeg collect, and I don't need to do anything if I don't want to."

This is to inform you that I will not any longer keep these boys in this school. Their influence following their interview with you has been definitely subversive.

The following pupils will be discharged with bus tickets to their home on Friday, October 19. They will leave Brandon on the bus at 11:45 A.M., arrive at Winnipeg 2:45 P.M., and leave for Hodgson at 6:00 P.M.

The names of the boys are as follows: Russel Smith aged 16, the teacher of the senior room refuses to have this boy in her class any longer; Milford Spence aged 16, this boy has repeatedly absented himself from classes on the pretext of working for some of the outside staff members. Herbert Spence aged 15 insubordination and swearing at staff members.

I do not know just what you did say to the boys but whatever it was they returned to the school with the impression that you would give them support in whatever they did. This is of course definitely subversive of the discipline of this school and can no longer be tolerated.

Copy to: Mr. P. Phelan, Rev. George Dorey, Rev. C.H. Best.

Yours truly,

Principal.

25 - Sept - 51

1. 9 A.M. this date, Norman HAILES, Carberry, Manitoba telephoned this office to advise that two young Indian boys, who he believed were from Brandon, had called at his house this A.M. for something to eat. He had taken them in and they were now at his place.

2. The two boys were found to be from the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Manitoba. They had left Brandon in the afternoon of 24 Sept 51 and were cold and hungry. The names and ages of these two boys are:
   - Henry TROUT - age 13 years, Treaty Indian.
   - Donald BEE - age 13 years, Treaty Indian.

3. Brandon Sub-Division were advised by telephone and about 10:30 A.M. both boys were turned over to Mr. STROPP, Supt. Indian Residential School, Brandon who had come to Carberry for them.

Mr. STROPP advised that there were four boys away from this school and he believed they had been together. However the two boys, TROUT & BEE did not appear to know where the other two boys were. Later Mr. STROPP's assistant called at this office looking for the other two missing boys and later in the day a telephone message was received from Mr. STROPP advising that the two missing boys had returned to the School.

CONCLUDED HERE

Dear Mr. Sinclair:

On the June 30, 1950 Quarterly Return for the Brandon Indian Residential School, the Principal had shown pupil "Susangnak, age five from the Coral Harbour Band (Esquinoux) with remarks opposite his name reading as follows:

"Admitted from Brandon San during flood crisis to make room for evacuees from Winnipeg hospital. He is not T.B. Band # E3-626."

This boy's name continued to appear on subsequent Quarterly Returns although we had not received any correspondence regarding him. We have now received a letter from our Regional Supervisor's office in Winnipeg reading as follows:

"The Principal, Rev. O.B. Strapp has brought to my attention the fact that one pupil is an Eskimo, Susangnak, 7 years old, from Gull Harbor.

Mr. Strapp mentioned that this boy does not fit in here. He has lost his language, speaks Cree and English now. It is feared that when time comes for his discharge he will be a misfit in his community.

It is recommended that another place, more suitable, be found for him".
This Branch has been allowing the Brandon Indian Residential School the usual Per Capita Grant for this boy. The time has now arrived, however, when he should be placed elsewhere.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you will arrange to transfer this boy from the Brandon Indian Residential School as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Acknowledgement is made of your above noted letter with enclosures mentioned therein.

Concerning the placement of the three children numbers, 337-8-9 now at Portage La Prairie Residential School, please see attached copy of letter received from the Principal of the Portage Residential School dated October 10, 1951 advising of the transfer. In view of his statement that Regional Superintendent Mr. Davis was privy to that arrangement and that the transfer would unite the brothers and sisters and the transaction appeared very much in order and the parents of all the children concerned were very much satisfied. It was presumed that notification of these changes would be conveyed to Department by the Principals of the schools by means of their quarterly reports. In the case of Elizabeth Apetagon #0404 now at Portage La Prairie School while application and approval was received for Brandon it was felt by the writer that this girl's delayed entrance to school would be more acceptable at Portage than at Brandon which latter institution had received a greater number of new pupils from this Agency this term. Principal Mc Lean was able to find room for her and her parents were quite satisfied.

Lack of my signature on the twenty-four applications submitted under cover of my letter of September 13th last is an oversight for which you may have my apology. These signed applications are now returned with applications of numbers 337-8-9 changed to show
Indian Residential School

Portage La Prairie, Man
October 10th, 1951.

Mr. J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent Indian Agency,
Norway House,
Manitoba

Dear Mr. Minnis:

I have your letter of October 4th, and note that Elizabeth Apetagon has not yet been approved. For our records will you please send the treaty numbers, birthdays and year of birth of the eleven new admittances.

When the new children came some already here felt very badly when they learned their brothers and sisters were going to Brandon School. One day later when Mr. Davis and Mr. Strapp were both here we talked it over and it was agreed that we trade three in order to keep the families together. On September 19th, I sent you a list of the children here from your Agency but neglected to draw your attention to the fact that we had traded Publius Harper, Talbot Harper and Julia Harper for Tiras Beardy, John James Monias and John Angus Mc Kay. Tiras Beardy's sister Barbara, and brother Epstein have been here for the past two years; John James Monias has a sister Isabel here for one year; and John Angus Mc Kay has a brother Peter here also a year. Our children are all very pleased and happy over the present arrangement.

I do hope that this is satisfactory to you and does not cause you any inconvenience.

Yours truly,

L. Mc Lean
Principal

Re: Burney & Granvell Borgoone

The above noted non-Indians, who's mother was Moravian, married a non-Indian, who deserted her and five children, some 25 or thirty years ago. With the results the children was placed in Indian Residential schools. Granvell was admitted to Mount Elgin in 1923, and the following year, he and his brother Burney were sent to Brandon Residential School, where they stayed until they came of age, the whereabouts of the father is not known; the mother died twenty years ago.

These men are now trying to establish their relationship to a deceased brother Le-Roy Borgoone, killed while with the United States Army. There is an office record of the mother Irene Borgoone, but there is no record of any of the family.

It is presumed that the Department have a record of their admittance to the Residential schools, which might show their mother Irene Borgoone as guardian. If there is such a record we would be pleased to receive a copy of the same, there is an estate in connection with the brother LeRoy of which the United States army is endeavouring to dispose of.

1. Sandy Family - This family is in the Portage la Prairie Agency in the Province of Manitoba and both parents are living. The father has forwarded a statutory declaration stating that he has renounced his adherence and allegiance to the Catholic Church and has been baptized a member of the Church of Christ (Protestant). He also states that his wife is already a Protestant and a graduate of the Brandon residential school. Mr. Sandy requests admission for his son Harvey Joseph Sandy age 10 to the Brandon (U.C.) residential school.

Superintendent Rayson has not signed the application but in an accompanying letter writes as follows:

"In addition to the application I am enclosing in triplicate a Statutory Declaration showing a change of religion from Roman Catholic to Church of Christ, Protestant.

I interviewed Joseph Sandy regarding this change and he has advised that this is his wish and therefore in view of this circumstance it would appear in the best interest to have the child admitted to the Brandon Indian Residential School."

I concur in Rayson's recommendation. (Sgd) L.F.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of January 31st, #133-0-14, concerning the milking cows of this school.

When we took over this school eight years ago there was a fine herd of Holstein cattle but for a number of years they had not been tested. We were doubtful of some of them and arranged with the Department to have the test made. Every milking cow went down and the herd was practically wiped out. We started a new herd that autumn with purebred dual-purpose Shorthorns. Every animal purchased was T.B. tested. In 1933 we received our accredited herd certificate and, fortunately, have retained it constantly ever since. The last annual test is dated May 18th, 1937. We have in all 56 females in the herd, about twenty milking at one time.

We also maintain annually the blood test for Bang's Disease.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.

P.S. We do not purchase any milk.

J. A. D.
Dear Sir:

As we require a new herd sire in connection with our Purebred Shorthorn herd, I thought it advisable to go to Ontario to secure one. I made this trip serve as holiday, and was away just one month.

J.A. Doyle.
Principal.
The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am sorry to have to report that when we went to the cow-barn on Sunday morning we found one of our most valuable heifers dead. As we could discover no cause, we phoned Dr. Harry Ross, who does our veterinary work. He came out immediately and diagnosed the trouble as black-leg. We immediately burned the carcass and everything pertaining to it and had him go ahead at once and vaccinate all the younger animals in the herd, fifty head in all. He will also do our new herd sire which we expect to arrive on Monday next. Dr. Ross told us that if twenty-four hours lapsed without any further trouble we were likely safe from any spread of the disease in the herd. It is now forty-eight hours, and no symptoms have occurred.

We have no idea whatever as to how the disease was contracted. No outside animal has been brought on the place for months, and none of the cattle that were in the stable at the time have been off the farm, except a few heifers that have been taken over to the Experimental Farm during the recent months, and there has been no trouble of this kind in their herd.

Dr. Ross' bill for this service will be approximately $20.00. Unless I am instructed otherwise I will forward it when it arrives, to your office. I am

Yours respectfully,

JAD/RS.

Dear Sir:

We have deemed it necessary to break some additional land in connection with the farm here which has never been under cultivation.

During these dry years when we had great difficulty in contending against soil drifting in the lighter land, we found it necessary to seed to permanent grass two fields containing 21 and 27 acres each in the highest and lightest part of the section of land lying to the North. This reduced our crop acreage.

During the years when there was normal rainfall and plenty of moisture the north part of the south field of the section of land was so wet it could not be cultivated, and now during the dry years it has become dry enough to work. So we have decided to break 45 acres in this field and 8 acres in the field corresponding to this land in the east third of this section. This entails fencing these two pieces, the small piece on one side and the larger piece on two sides which makes an even mile of fencing, and are hereby requesting that you supply us with the material for this fence and we will build it ourselves.

It will require 200 posts. These are round cedar posts, 5 inch, and will cost $60.00. I have secured from the Johnson Hardware Co., Ltd. a quotation on the wire required. This is a 7 wire woven fence, 42 inches high, with one strand of barbed wire on the top. This costs a little less than the ten wire fence which has been put up in the past. The quotation for the fencing, barbed wire and staples is $175.98.

Trusting you will be able to give us this material.

I am, Yours respectfully,

JAB/TS

Principal

May 28th, 1917.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Rev. Mr. Hetherington, who was my assistant two years ago, organized the Boy Scouts in connection with the Brandon Industrial Institute. We have about forty members in the troop. I have gone to the expense of getting them a special Boy Scout outfit which cost $300. My son, Fred, was appointed assistant Scout Master. Lieut. Hetherington went overseas with the 203rd Battalion, and was wounded on the 15th of April, and died on the 15th.

The boys are very anxious that they shall continue this Scout work. I have secured the assistance of a returned soldier to help in the movement, and the boys are very anxious to have a bugle band, consisting of about ten bugles and two or three drums. The cost will be in the neighborhood of $125 or $150. I would consider it a great favor if the Department would encourage this movement by providing these bugles and drums. Personally I am strongly of the opinion that the movement is a great help to the building up of character, and in the physical training of the boys. Favorable consideration of this request will be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Your letter of June 8, #135-0-3, came in last night and was exceedingly disconcerting.

Notwithstanding our constant efforts to carry out rigid economy in all expenditures consistent with having the children well-fed, decently clothed, and efficiently taught, we were compelled to end the fiscal year with a deficit of $2050.49. Just at that time we received your notice of the 10% cut retroactive to January 1st. I immediately had to make serious cuts in salaries, making these also retroactive and had to cut out other expenses which seemed necessary and had been counting all along on the full amount of the education grant to clear off our indebtedness and meet a few other items of urgent need. And I trust yet that it may come through in full.

As to the extra expenses incurred by carrying on High School work I beg to submit the situation as it appears from our standpoint. For this work we require an extra and well-qualified teacher. I am paying her this year in cash $655.00, a very reasonable value of her board would be $240. I have paid out for the three boys attending the Technical School in fees, supplies required in the shop and tools, $32.75. Then the item of extra clothing for young men and women of this type is considerable. Even at $10.00 extra, which I am sure does not cover it would be $290.00. The transportation of those attending Normal, Collegiate, and Technical School entails about 3400 miles with a car, over half of this at least could be charged wholly to their account, which is worth at least, in gas and wear and tear of car $35.00. Then the high school pupils are in school the whole day and therefore unable to give any valuable help in connection with the farm. There are 14 boys and the 200 half days that they would otherwise give to farm work would easily be worth to us $350. We have to pay much more than that for extra help.

These items amount to $1882.75.

Dear Sir:

After favorable correspondence with you last year we started three boys in a Three-Year's Course at the Technical School for Automotive Mechanics in Brandon. So far the venture has turned out very satisfactory. All three boys passed with good standing and are showing decided aptitude and efficiency in this kind of work. Maurice Grey, while home during the summer on the reserve at Sintaluta, reconstructed a McLaughlin car owned by his family into a truck. His work in doing this attracted the attention and approval of the Indians on the reserve and some who visited them from other reserves.

This year six other boys requested to be allowed to take this Course. But a regulation of the City School Board limited the attendance of boys from outside the city and only four of the six were admitted, to commence the Course this year. All four seem to be doing well, though we had some doubts in regard to one of them and arranged with the Principal to substitute another boy if he did not make good. He is exceeding our expectations.

It is quite probable that there will be more applications on the part of both boys and parents to take this Course than we can accommodate. It is probable that four a year will be the limit. If four enter each year it will soon mean that twelve of our boys will be taking this Course, four graduating and four entering each year. When we return to anything like normal conditions there should be good openings for well-trained and efficient mechanics. It seems desirable, therefore, that we should take advantage of this opportunity to give as many as possible of our boys who are trustworthy and who show aptitude for this work this very splendid training, which is given in Brandon and only in a few other places in Western Canada.
Indian Residential School

Brandon, Man.,

I am writing you more fully in this connection that I may have your direction as to what policy should be adopted for the future and what relief the Department might be able to give us in following out this policy.

Dear Sir:

I have just received a letter from Rev. K. J. Beaton of our Home Mission Office suggesting that I send you a few copies of the circular letter which I sent this year to parents, Indian Agents and Missionaries among the Indians. I am therefore enclosing four copies herewith.

I have felt very much recently like writing you in regard to the Technical School here. On account of financial difficulties the Provincial Government has reduced its grant for this school very seriously and as the Dominion grant for this kind of education is an amount equal to the Provincial grant the funds available for the school will be so reduced as to make its continuation problematical. Negotiations are now being carried on by which the Dominion Government is requested to accept a grant from the Municipality in lieu of the amount which the Provincial Government has previously paid and make their grant the same as in former years. I have been informed that a great deal of influence will have to be exercised on the Dominion Government to secure this result.

On account of the above facts I felt I wanted to state to you my convictions in regard to the service this Technical School is rendering to our bows. If you see fit to do so it might be that a word from you would carry considerable weight with the Minister of Labor in regard to the grant requested.

I am quite convinced that Technical and Vocational Education are bound to receive greater emphasis in the future and mechanically trained men will be in greater demand than ever and these schools can render a very great service in this direction especially at a time like this when so many boys in their later teens are unemployed and can be trained for useful and productive service instead of drifting into idle and useless lives which will become a menace in the future.

I wish also to say that this School and the course given to our boys has given all seven of them a new ambition in life. They are taking a great interest in their work and are having a splendid affect on the spirit of the School. The fact that all seven have passed with the lowest average being 72% has been an inspiration to the other pupils.

If this School continues and your Department approves of it I would have no difficulty in placing three or four new boys in the School each year thus having nine to twelve in attendance regularly and three or four graduating each year.

Ottawa, July 28, 1933.

Dear Dr. Doyle:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the Technical School in Brandon.

I visited the Labour Department and discussed this matter. The Act under which grants were set aside for technical education expressly prohibits the Dominion Government from accepting a grant from the municipality towards the cost of running expenses of technical schools in lieu of the grant from the Provincial Government. I was informed that there was a balance to the credit of the Manitoba Government for technical education to the amount of $400,000 but that, as the Provincial Government was unable to contribute towards the cost of technical schools, it was doubtful if this amount would not lapse. I may add that all grants for technical education will lapse as from March 31, 1934, unless further extended by Act of Parliament.

Should the authorities in Brandon who are responsible for the conducting of the Technical School be unable to continue this activity during the coming school year, the only recourse, in so far as the Indian pupils who have been attending are concerned, is to grant them their discharge and allow them to return to their homes. However, should it be possible that arrangements can be completed to continue the Technical School during the coming academic year, this Department will continue to provide the advanced educational grant at the rate of $50 for each pupil, as was done last year.

I am pleased to note that the seven boys who attended technical school last year took such an interest in their work and obtained such excellent results. It is noted that, should the school continue, you will likely be placing three or four new boys, thus having from nine to twelve in attendance regularly.

With reference to the pupils who are taking advanced educational work in the Brandon School, the Department will await a reply to letter dated June 26th, last, when further consideration will be given as to the grant that can be allowed in their case. Our

Dear Sir:

I am writing you in regard to Gladys Haywahe, No. 0387, who is taking Grade XI work with a view of training as a nurse. Mr. R. J. Reid, Principal of the Collegiate, called me in the other day and urged that Gladys should not be required to write on all five subjects, remaining to complete her Grade XI, at this time. She has been kept out of school on account of illness and temporary quarantine for fear of Scarlet Fever and Mr. Reid thinks that if she took two subjects now and the other three next midsummer she would be practically assured of completing this Grade successfully. But he fears, if required to take all five at this time, she would not be successful on all of them.

Mr. Reid had every good word to say in regard to Gladys' attitude and application to her work and I am glad to report that her attitude and conduct in the school as well as her efficiency in taking responsibility have been excellent. I am writing, therefore, to ask that she be allowed to continue with us until midsummer. I might add that Inspector Hamilton knows this girl and her family very well and with us is very anxious that she should be given all possible assistance and encouragement in attaining the objective of training as a nurse on which her heart is very definitely set. She certainly lacks nothing in ambition and perseverance.

Trusting that you may see fit to grant our request in this respect,

I am,

yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

I am writing concerning an ex-pupil, Walter Baldhead, No. 408. Last year he took his final year in Technical School, also Grade X in connection with our classes here at the school and cleared both successfully. He worked on a farm in the summer and fall and has put in most of the winter in the coal mines in southern Manitoba. He has saved $65.00 and is with us for a few days at present until he gets other employment, the mines having closed down. He is anxious to take up electrical engineering as soon as he has funds enough to warrant him in starting a course. We are informed through the agent at Kamsack that there are funds to his credit in the Department. He is anxious to know the amount that he may make his plans with the above purpose in view.

We have found Walter decidedly ambitious, willing to work and with sufficient stick-to-iteness to make it quite hopeful that he will make good if given a chance.

If you will kindly give me the information desired I will pass it on to him and will be glad to co-operate with you in anything you may suggest for the safeguarding of the proper use of his money if it is deemed advisable that he should continue his education.

Dear Sir:

Last school year Ewart Monias took Normal while in attendance here and in the early summer was appointed teacher at Nelson House. When his appointment was made he expected to go as a married man and the arrangement with Jessie Bear, #402, was quite definite before holidays. However, when she returned from holidays she was quite doubtful in the matter and his marriage was indefinitely postponed. Subsequent correspondence, however, has made their engagement quite definite and it seemed advisable also that the marriage should take place before the winter travelling to the North should become impossible. Last week I received a wire from Wabowden urging that she be sent forward at once. So she is now on her way to Nelson House and they will be married on her arrival. I might add that Jessie is a very satisfactory type of girl. She is, or will very shortly be, twenty years of age. Brandon, Man., July 1, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I am writing in connection with Walter Baldhead, who graduated from here two years ago, and wish to refer to my letter to you, dated March 16, 1936, and your reply of March 19, #133-0-22, and beg to say that Walter has attended Collegiate during the past year, taking Grade XI and has just completed writing his examinations. His reports during the year have been favorable. He has been able to finance his living expenses from his own funds, that is, from money saved out of his wages, except $60.00, which he now owes for board. He also had some money from the sale of horses on the reserve.

Walter has requested me to write you, asking for $60.00 to meet this outstanding account, to be charged to funds to his credit in your office.

Walter is exceedingly anxious to go forward with his school work and is making request that the Department re-admit him in the school here and finance him as a higher education pupil after his own funds are exhausted. He will work out during the summer and should be able to save approximately $40.00 and will be glad to apply this on his school work next year. It is with absolute confidence that I recommend that this privilege be granted to him. He is above the average as a student, especially in his dogged perseverance.
and has a very commendable ambition to get an education and qualify himself for some worthwhile service in life.

Trusting that you may see fit to grant Walter this privilege and opportunity,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D., Principal.

Ottawa, July 6, 1937.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the first instant, with reference to Walter Baldhead. At the present time there is an amount of $177.35 to his credit. A cheque for $60.00 will be drawn from this account and sent to you.

It is noted from the last paragraph of your letter that Walter wishes to continue at school. In your letter of March 16th, 1936, you indicated that it was his intention to study electrical engineering. There are so many white persons who have taken different university courses and are now out of work that I feel it would be a mistake on Baldhead's part to endeavour to take the course mentioned. I would strongly recommend either the diploma course in Agriculture, requiring two years, or the graduate course in Agriculture, requiring four years. Either of these courses can be taken at the Faculty of Agriculture at the University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. By taking either course, this boy would fit himself for work in which openings are generally available and would make it possible for him to be of some real value to his own people.

Please discuss his future with him again, and let me have your opinion. If he decides to take the course which I suggest in this letter, you might let me know the approximate amount of help that you think the Department should allow him during the academic year 1937-38.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you for your letter of July 6th, #132-0-22, concerning Walter Baldhead. I note that you state that a cheque for $60.00 drawn on his account will be sent forward in my care. I have today received a cheque from Ottawa for $59.24. I do not quite understand why this amount is sent as it does not seem to cover the total amount to his credit in your office. I will, however, put this in the Bank to his credit and await further information from you.

Walter is now working on a farm east of Brandon but was over for a short visit on Sunday afternoon and we talked over the matter of his further education. Since then I have had conversation with Mr. Tinline, Superintendent of the Experimental Farm here, and a young Mr. Good, who is at the present time taking the degree course at the Faculty of Agriculture at the University of Manitoba. I then drove out to see Walter last night and while he would like very much to take the degree course, he has decided that in the light of all the circumstances it would be better take the diploma course, chiefly because it would give him a more practical training, fitting him for the service he might be called upon to render if he were employed in connection with one of the reserves in the advanced programme which is being adopted.
The Secretary - 2

July 13, 1937.

As to the expense of this course I have not definite figures by me at this time but, from the information received from Mr. Good, I would think that if the Department made provision for Walter to the extent of from $75.00 to $100.00 he would be safely cared for for the coming year.

We appreciate very much your interest in this boy and I feel confident that he will make good.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of November 10th, 1937, and my letter to you dated May 3rd, 1938, bottom of page 1, I wish to refer to Herman Crate, #371.

Herman is, without doubt, one of the best and most promising boys who have attended this school. In appearance and attitude there is no trace of Indian characteristics. He has fair hair and white skin, is quite tall, athletic and naturally mechanical. He is a splendid student. He has an impelling ambition to make something of himself. He is a very ready and willing worker, reliable in every way. He will take over the tractor, wash a car, mend a chair, take dining-room duty or do anything he is asked to do in a fine spirit and with efficiency. The North country has a great attraction for him but he is not willing to go as a trapper or fisherman or even a guide. He states that if there is something that he could qualify for in connection with radio, survey work, mining engineering or the mechanical side of airplane service, he would be glad to devote himself to any necessary course of study or preparation. I have suggested the agricultural course but it does not appeal to him as much as something that would take him to the North country.

I appreciate very much your personal interest in boys of this kind and if in the light of what I have written you wish to suggest something further and definite in regard to Herman, he will be glad to consider it and I will certainly spare no pains in helping him toward achieving the success which he is ambitious to attain.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to Herman Crate.

I note that this boy will likely obtain Grade 12 standing at the close of the present academic year. In view of the large number of university graduates who find it difficult to secure employment at the present time I doubt the advisability of incurring additional expenditure on this boy's behalf. He is now 19 years of age and I feel that the Department has dealt very generously with him. I am sorry that he did not see fit to take advantage of the opportunity of accepting the training offered at Riding Mountain Park.

I note from the last paragraph of your letter that you intend to employ him at the school next year. If he saves his money he should be able to provide some additional training from his own funds, if he feels so inclined.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir;

I am in receipt of your letter in reply to mine of July 27th with reference to the request for transfer of the above mentioned Pupils of this School to the Brandon Indian Residential School to continue studies in High School.

On receipt of your letter I interviewed the Parents of Doris Anderson, Maud Goforth and Gerald Bird, Catherine Ahenakew lives on the Sandy Lake Reserve in the Carlton Agency in Northern Saskatchewan and it has not been possible to interview her Parents, Thos Anderson and David Bird, also Goforth, are very anxious that their children should have an opportunity to take up High School studies and prepare for the professions of their choice. I have pointed out to them that these courses will take several years and that it will require a strong determination and deep concentration on the part of the children to achieve their goal, the children assure me that they are prepared to apply themselves to the utmost of their ability in order that they may qualify themselves to work in their chosen fields.

Mr Anderson and Mr Bird have offered to bear part of the expense of this training to the extent of $75.00 per Annum, I cannot speak for Mr Ahenakew, but I am sure that he would be willing to contribute a like amount toward the expense of his daughters training, in the case of Mr Goforth; this man is not the type to extend himself sufficiently to enable him to make any definite contribution but his daughter is very anxious to continue and if the Department could see their way clear to extend High School privileges to her I am sure she would make the very best use of the advantages offered.

Doris Anderson, Catherine Ahenakew and Gerald Bird have very good ability and have proven exceptional Pupils and I would appreciate it very much if they could be given the opportunity.
for further advancement.

Dear Sir:

I have two boys, Joseph Mason, No. 422, and Allan Thomas, No. 434, who wish to attend the Technical School for Automotive Mechanics in Brandon, during this coming year. They have had this in mind for over a year, and I have hesitated recommending it, as I was not satisfied with the way the School has been run during this last year or so, and felt that unless there was a radical change, that our boys would not receive the benefit for the time and money expended. That change has taken place. A new Principal has been secured, and the course has been reduced to one year instead of covering three years, and the outline of training emphasizes those practical uses of gasoline and electricity, and general machine-shop work which come into practical use either in a shop or on a farm. I have looked into the matter as thoroughly as I can at its present stage of development, and I feel quite confident the course will be of real benefit to those adapted to this kind of training.

Joseph Mason is on our books as seventeen. He tells me, however, that he will not be seventeen until next month. He has completed Grade VIII, is a

Dear Sir,

Fraser Kejick, #20 Shoal Lake Band, aged 21 next month, asked me if he could go to Brandon Indian Residential School to continue his studies.

This boy was a pupil at the Cecilia Jeffrey School here, later attending the Kenora High School, and staying at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School had talked the matter over with the Principal of the Brandon School, and recommended his acceptance there. I have also received a letter from the Principal of that School informing me that he will be very pleased to take him for Grade X work, and that his pupils are taking High School and Collegiate work and doing very well.

I have also discussed the matter with the Principal of the High School, and he approves the suggestion.

I would therefore recommend that the admission of this boy be approved to the Brandon Residential School, and that his transportation and necessary expenses for meals &c be authorized.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant with reference to Fraser Kejick who has been attending high school at Kenora.

Recent information received from the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School indicates that a one year course of vocational training can now be obtained at the Brandon Technical School. The Department is not prepared to approve transferring Fraser Kejick from Cecilia Jeffrey to Brandon in order to take up the regular high school work. We are willing, however, for him to transfer provided he takes the one year vocational course. If he is willing to do so you may arrange for sending him to Brandon immediately. Payment of his transportation will be made on receipt from you of a certified account in triplicate.

Dear Sir:

I am writing again in regard to Walter Baldhead, a former pupil, about whom we had considerable correspondence last year, and for whom it was finally arranged that he should attend the Agricultural College in Winnipeg, taking the Diploma Course.

After leaving the College in the spring he got work through the employment bureau here, with Mr. Dan Eisler, near Souris. A few days after he went to work for Mr. Eisler, I happened to be in Souris, and found that Walter had gone to a very difficult place. This man has a record of constant trouble with his hired help; one spring had six men in succession during seeding. Walter stayed till after haying, and when he felt he could not stay any longer, secured another man to take his place. Eisler refused to pay Walter, so Walter secured the services of a lawyer in Souris, who secured a statement from Eisler that he would pay Walter $58.00 at the end of October. Walter then got work with a Mr. Latcham south of here, and will have $80.00 coming to him when he is through, which makes a total of $138.00. His prospective expenses will be as follows:

- College Board & Fees: $171.00
- Personal Expense, 5 months, including clothes: $35.00
- Other Students' Fees, including pool fee for Medical Service: $20.00
- Expenses re Christmas Holiday when College is closed: $10.00
