Sep 7th 1939

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Sir,

I have asked Indian Agent Waite to forward applications for transfer of four pupils from this school to Brandon Indian School to take the High School Course.

These girls are good students and excellent character. They are worthy of the continued opportunity they will find at Brandon.

The parents or Guardians of three of these pupils are willing to allow the children to be transferred. The father of the fourth girl (0221 Helen Myerion) wants me to ask for the discharge of Helen to go and live with him. The girl does not want to go and I think it would be a cruel thing to send her away in charge of her father, he is not capable of caring for her in any way, and certainly not from a moral standpoint. Two years ago Helen's older sister Lucy left the school and went to her father, (the mother died some years ago) I have a letter today from Lucy asking me to take her in the school. In less than one week after Lucy left the School her father allowed her to co-habit with a half-breed and in less than three months she was in jail for drunkenness. The father is one of the worst drinkers on Long Plains Reserve. Therefore I would urge that the Request of the father be not considered and that Helen be allowed to continue her education. She is a splendid girl in every way and will I am sure be a credit to the school.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

0214 Grace Johnnie 16 years Grade 8 from Roseau Reserve
0217 Jean Prince " " " " Long Plains
0220 Edna Tanner " " " 7 " Swan Lake
0221 Helen Myerion " " " 8 " Long Plains
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Sept. 4th, 1939.

I beg to attach hereto a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Portage Residential School in which he makes certain recommendations in regard to a number of pupils of the school. I recommend that the first three on the list be allowed to take the high school course at Brandon. The last on the list, Helen Myerion is passed to the Department for decision. The father of the girl does not want her to go to Brandon, but wants her home. I interviewed the girl on Saturday last and she expressed the wish that she be allowed to attend the Brandon School. The girl is the daughter of Archie Myerion, No. 133 Long Plain Reserve. He is living with Mrs Simon Prince, No. 125 Long Plain Reserve. This is a common law wife. Under these conditions the home atmosphere is not all that could be desired, and it is my opinion that the girl would be better off with two years at Brandon School. There has been considerable controversy in regard to this matter and I would be pleased to have the Department decide the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of May 28th #133-0-22 has just come in, and I note that you are in error as to the arrangement concerning the grant for pupils taking advanced education.

When I took over the School twelve years ago $50.00 each was being paid for all pupils above grade 8. The first year we operated there were about 30 in the list, and we received approximately $1500.00. When Mr. Sutherland of the Dept. visited us about that time we negotiated a new arrangement whereby we would receive $25.00 for those taking their work in the School here, and $50.00 each for those attending the Collegiate, Normal School, Technical School, or Business College. This extra $25.00 was in consideration of three things: transportation which meant two trips a day, extra clothing required to correspond with Collegiate standards, then these pupils are not able to contribute anything to speak of to the work of the School.

If you will look over the records you will find that during these eleven years the School Board fees have been paid by the Department and not by us out of the $50.00 grant.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Dear Sir,

I received your letter of March 1st, file 133-0-22, when I was used up with the 'flu and so the reply has been held over for a little while.

Last year, in reference to high school students, you stated it was not the intention of the Department to give extra grants for pupils entering high school for the first time. So we were allowed extra grants this year only for pupils who had already started their high school work. I thus understood it was the matter of the special grant to which the Department took exception in these times. Our senior teacher teaches grades 9 and 10 in his classroom, grades 11 and 12 attend the Brandon Collegiate. The pupils who had passed their grade 8 and were not yet 16 automatically went on to grade 9 in our senior classroom. Some of the pupils mentioned in your letter were transferred from Round Lake School and some from File Hills School to take their grade 9. I have not the Department's letters in reference to this, but I have letters from the principals saying that the transfers were approved by the Department on the understanding there would be no extra grant.

In reference to Edwin Smith, there has been a little slip somewhere. He never has been taking Technical work. He has been taking grade 11 in the Brandon Collegiate, as per request made last year.
Dorothy Bear, #0508, failed in grade 10 last year, not grade 9, and has been repeating her year in our classroom. This year she has shown splendid progress in her grade.

In regard to those children who will be reaching sixteen years of age, I am making full report and recommendations to accompany the March Quarterly returns.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing reports for the four girls who have been attending Brandon Collegiate this past term, also a letter from Mr. J.R. Reid the Principal.

I had a conference with Mr. Reid this morning and he is of the opinion that only the strongest of our students can make the many adjustments that are necessary for them to make between the type of life they have to live in the residential school, with one teacher taking all subjects, and the entirely new set of conditions in the collegiate school where different teachers take individual subjects.

As you know, I took over this school about two and a half years ago and so have not had very much time in which to study the difficulties encountered by our students who attend the collegiate classes. I have formed the opinion that they would make much better progress if they entered the grade X classes in collegiate instead of taking the course in residential school. This would put them on the same level with all the other students who were starting collegiate classes and would permit them to make their adjustments under more favorable conditions.

I would appreciate your consideration of the course to be adopted in the case of these pupils. I do not feel that they would do very much to improve their standing if they reverted to grade X in residential school for the balance of their year, but can see how they might benefit greatly by attending classes at the collegiate in grade X for the balance of the year. They all have a clear
grade I standing and so would not be required to write the examinations at the end of the term.

I discussed this possibility with Mr. Reid and he is willing to try the experiment, provided a number of other students who did not pass their examinations revert to the grade X classes.

As Mr. Reid has yet to contact the parents of these other students he is not yet sure as to what the decision in their cases will be.

Collegiate classes resume on Monday January 6th.

I remain,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

9. Add any other useful information here.

At about 11:30 A.M., I was informed by the School Master that a boy had come in to say that Roderick had been run over. Immediately went to the scene of the accident. Saw that he was dead. Returned to the school and informed the Medical Attendant, the R.C.M.P. Officer and the Coroner, Mr. P.C. Robertson of Brandon.

The R.C.M.P. took charge and made an investigation, obtaining statements from the child who was driving the tractor and another person who was with him. The Coroner declared death was accidental with no blame attached to either of the parties and released the body.

C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of ____________________________ have been recorded? If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

Roderick Beardy is from Cross Lake, in the Norway House Agency. We have several day schools at this point and this boy should never have been sent into boarding school.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

June 4, 1949.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I do not know just why the complete report on this accident has not yet reached your office.

Within an hour after the accident I had notified Mr. W. Young of Griswold, Man., who is the nearest Indian Agent. Mr. Young contacted Mr. Hamilton and telephoned me that Mr. Davis, Regional Supervisor would convene the board of inquiry about 10:00 A.M. on Tuesday April 19, 1949.

Mr. Davis and Mr. Young visited the school and conducted the inquiry and Mr. Davis after making inquiry from the undertaker as to the cost of casket and box ($2.00) gave instruction that the funeral should be conducted that afternoon in the cemetery located on the school property. I had completed the prescribed form #414 and Mr. Davis took it away with him.

It was felt that the matter was an accident in which the human factor was responsible and both R.C.M.P. and the Coroner were satisfied that it apparently was unavoidable under the circumstances. The boy was riding on the tractor contrary to instructions and it is obviously impossible to have an instructor always with every boy on the farm. In some manner unknown to the other boys he fell off and was crushed by the rear wheel of the tractor. Death was instantaneous.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Mr. Strapp has written to say that a pupil, Roderick Beardy, died following an accident. There was an enquiry held by Mr. Davis and Mr. Young, after which Mr. Davis gave instructions to proceed with the funeral. Now, the question is -- who is going to pay the expenses? It may be quite satisfactory from the Department's standpoint to state that "when a pupil dies at an Indian residential school, it has always been the policy for the school to provide funeral expenses." If so, it is time there was a new policy set up.

The per capita which we receive to cover the expenses of the pupil ceases the day he dies, and I think that, that being so, your Department is responsible for dealing with the body after the pupil dies, or else continuing the per capita. We are only authorized to expend money which we receive.

Now, it is a question of who is going to pay the $22.00 for the cost of the funeral. As a matter of fact, the point is -- who ordered the funeral?

Perhaps, you would look into this matter and let me know what can be done, because, certainly, the Brandon School has no funds available to pay funeral expenses. I shall be glad to hear from you.

Sir,

I have had opportunity during the year to look over the work done by your Church at Cross Lake and while one could say some complimentary things about work carried on under the greatest difficulties I could wish that things were better than they are.

It may be well for you to consider the advisability of looking in the direction of Boarding School work. I am satisfied that this class of work gives better returns and is followed with greater satisfaction every way than is brought about by the Day Schools.

I have also had opportunity of observing closely your work at St Anthony's School Kenora. This is one of the Banner Schools of the Inspectorate but they are very much checkmated by limitations in accommodation. They need a better drainage system. They must have a better water supply. They lack room now that the number of scholars has been increased. I should like to see these needs supplied as soon as possible.

At Fort Alexander I find that the Father is somewhat involved. He had at the beginning of 1907 an outstanding...
deficit of $3506.29. Against this are some buildings which perhaps cost in the neighborhood of $2500.00 which have not been paid for. To His Honour the Minister of the Interior at Ottawa,

Honourable Sir,-

Permit me to present, with respect, for your consideration the following observations and the request that I have been asked to submit to you.

As Roman Catholic missionary since 1874 among the Indians of the Churchill and Nelson rivers, I have always been occupied with the spiritual and temporal affairs of my faithful people. Aged 61 years, I have spent nearly 35 of them with these poor brave natives.

Those of Cross Lake, where I have been for 7 years, and who are connected with the Norway House agency, urgently ask to have a boarding school on their reserve. I speak in the name of the Roman Catholic population of the place.

Their country is poor in fur, the fisheries of white men have ruined their lakes and rivers; in order to earn their living they are obliged to go far away from the reserve in order to seek elsewhere the means of a livelihood, and thus their children have to give up the day school and forget their lessons. These poor Indians can still find food, but they have nothing to clothe themselves with. It would be a great benefit for them if the Government, usually so paternal towards the natives of the country, would come to their assistance. The greatest good for them and what they desire earnestly would be to give them a boarding school at Cross Lake, so that their children might be kept there, cared for, clothed,
fed and educated from five or six years of age until twelve or fifteen. The parents would then be able more easily to go and work elsewhere, and their children would be taken care of and well brought up. I have said very often to the agent, and to the inspectors of reserves, that the young generation of our Indians will never be well brought up unless we have for them a boarding school at Cross Lake; and in speaking thus I am thinking especially of their morality. Experience and the exercise of my ministry prove to me that it is impossible to make this young generation moral without a boarding school. If the Government will grant it to us, we shall have at once at least four good nuns for this purpose.

The Methodists have a school at Norway House. Our Roman Catholics cannot send their children to that school, and besides there would be no room for all the children, and then it must be said that the morality leaves much to be desired in this school as proved by regrettable facts that have occurred twice within a short time; nearly all the Protestants desire to see a Roman Catholic boarding school at Cross Lake.

At Cross Lake there is fairly good land for cultivation, of which to make gardens and fields; there is plenty of hay for stock, and fish are fairly abundant, so that everything contributes to the easy maintenance of a boarding school. Building timber is at their doors, so to speak.

We have at Cross Lake 46 Roman Catholic families and 37 Methodist. The majority of the population is thus Roman Catholic. We have at least 50 children who could attend school, although our day school counts on only from 15 to 25 usually.

If we had a boarding school, all the children would go there, and we have other Roman Catholic children.
besides in the district who would go to our school. The Methodist clergymen say everywhere that we shall never have a school and that the Government will never grant favours to the Roman Catholics. I know that this is not true, but I wish that it were not true at Cross Lake. If the Government grants us a boarding school at Cross Lake, we shall have some nuns, and one of them who speaks English well would teach the children, and the other nuns would engage in charitable work, as for example, take care of the sick children on the reserve. I recollect that in 1887 measles spread among our population; there were 75 deaths in two months. Neither companies, merchants nor any white men concerned themselves about these poor sick people. I spent all my time in visiting them, caring for them, and administering to them. I spent all I had in their assistance. Bishop Tache knew it; he complimented me and thanked me for it; but I never received anything from the public; but at the present time, on the eve of seeing our country invaded by white men, at the moment when they are engaged in the building of the railway between the Nelson and the Churchill, I ask as a favour that the Canadian Government be kind enough to have pity on our Indians.

We have two missions well established on the Nelson, at Cross Lake, and at Norway House.

We have a day school at Cross Lake. We have none yet at Norway House; now we ask for a boarding school at Cross Lake and a day school at Norway House. For nearly thirty years I worked in the midst of the Indians of the Churchill and of the Nelson. This is the first considerable favour that I have asked of the Government.

Let me hope that you will comply with my request. The Indians and the Roman Catholic missionaries of Cross Lake and Norway House will always be much obliged to the Government. I am, Hon. Sir, with respect,

Your humble servant,
Etienne Bonald, O.M.I.
Priest, Missionary

Norway House, January 1911

The Honorable Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ontario.

Honorable Sir,

Application has been made, I understand, to the Government by the Roman Catholic Church for a grant in support of a Boarding School to be situated here. Please allow me to draw your attention to some facts with regard to this locality which ought to be taken into consideration before the Government launch upon the scheme.

Norway House is the centre of a section of country nearly solidly Methodist for four hundred miles from North to South and two hundred from East to West. The only constituency that the Catholic Church has in this whole district from which to draw children for a Boarding School is one family here with six children in it. You will know that when they range up from infancy there could not be more than four of school age. I think there are only three of school age. They have one boy in another family who is now seventeen and would be beyond school age before the school could be built. They have three other families but no children of school age in them.

They have quite a few people at Grass Lake, sixty-five miles North of here but they have had their school there for two years and could not get any of the children into it. Their present move is to bring the staff and outfit up here from Grass Lake. But you will readily see that since the people would not put their children in while it was there much less will they send them here since they have added to their former objections this that the Catholic Church has not kept faith with them having promised them the Boarding School and a sawmill both of which they are locating here if you agree to give the grant. They have a few families at Nelson House two hundred miles North but these people have steadily refused to send their children out to any school.
The Methodist Church is now in its seventy first year in its occupancy of this district and has established missions at every point where the Indians congregate. The following Reserves and Bands of Indians are located in this District: Severn River, Fisher River, Little Grand Rapids, Poplar River, Blood Vein, Norsay House, Grass Lake, Nelson House, Split Lake, Oxford House, Gods Lake, Island Lake, Sandy Lake. The Church of England has Missions at two of these Reserves. For about twelve years past the Catholics have been trying to gain a foothold in this district with but little success. It seems to me that it would be a monstrous thing for any Government to support by school grants any one denomination in its efforts to beset the adherents of another. They have equal rights with others to grants in support of schools for their own people but when they have absolutely no constituency tributary to the country concerned it would seem to us most unjust to use the taxes paid by Methodist people in common with others for the purpose of overthrowing the Methodist Church. A grant to a Roman Catholic School here would be simply a bonus wherewith to fight the Methodist Church. We cannot bring ourselves to think that once the Government is cognizant of these facts they would entertain the proposition of a grant for one moment. The injustice of it all is too apparent, too glaring to escape recognition. Our political party, led as it is by an honored Roman Catholic could scarcely afford to sell open eyed into such a mud hole since it would expose our Premier to a square charge of religious partiality even to the extent of the use of public funds for the advance of his religious views and his particular church.

Yours Respectfully,

J. A. Lonsley.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

I have to report further on the educational situation at Norway House, and would refer to my memorandum of the 10th of February written upon Bishop Charlebois' request that the Department would guarantee a per capita grant for 40 pupils for a new Roman Catholic Boarding School at Norway House. In this connection the letter from Dr. Egerton Shore, with enclosure from the Rev. J. A. Lousley, Principal of the Methodist Boarding School at Norway House, should be read. The facts from the standpoint of the Roman Catholics are shown in Bishop Charlebois' letter below my memorandum of the 10th February.

This is a difficult matter to deal with as a decision is likely to awaken criticism from either one party or the other, but that is no reason why it should not be dealt with justly and to some extent in accordance with usage. Mr. Lousley, it appears to me, mixes the missionary question with the question of Indian education. With the former, we, as a Department of Government, have nothing whatever to do and our jurisdiction and responsibility extends only to the educational field. I do not think that we could admit, with reference to the latter point, that any Church has a right to exclude
educational effort from a certain field because it has thrown its missionary aegis over the territory.

To take the present case as an example, it would surely be untenable for the Methodists to claim that because they have established a Boarding School at Norway House, recognized by the Department, and receive grants for certain day schools, they are thereby entitled to claim exclusive rights to the teaching privileges in the vast district comprised in Mr. Lousley's letter. Certainly, it is a fact that a very small proportion of the children who could attend a Boarding School, can be accommodated in the Norway House building, and the day schools by reason of the hunting and fishing pursuits of the parents cannot be operated with any degree of success. There is cooperation between the Government and several religious denominations in the education of the Indians, particularly with reference to the establishment and maintenance of residential schools, and the Churches have been given to understand that the Department will not be responsible in any way for a residential school erected without its sanction. Under this rule Bishop Charlebois comes to us with his case. If it were a known fact that every Indian in this territory was an adherent of the Methodist Church it would be oppressive were the Government to recognize and contribute funds towards the support of a Roman Catholic or Church of England Boarding School, but in the country with
which we are dealing there must be hundreds of children who are to all intents and purposes pagans, whose parents are not adherents of the Methodist Church and who equally with all Indians require educational facilities. Now if the Methodists are treated fairly by the Government with reference to their needs in the Norway House district, why should they complain if the Government also recognizes the existence of the Roman Catholic Church in a district in which they have already a footing and in which they endeavor to provide for the education of pagan children.

The school regulations, which have the force of law, provide that no Protestant child shall be committed to a Roman Catholic School and vice versa. This refers to "legal commitment" but the regulations of the Department are even more stringent and will not allow a Protestant child to be taken into residence in a Catholic school and vice versa, so the Methodist children are fully protected and cannot be taken into the Roman Catholic school.

It appears to me that in considering the situation at Norway House the application of Bishop Charlebois, the protests of the Methodist Church, and the present condition of the Methodist Schools in that district should all be carefully weighed. At present, Parliament has provided no funds for the per capita grant to the school desired by Bishop Charlebois and although the Methodist Church has for several years asked for a grant for a new school building at Norway House we have not been able to meet the demand. I think that action
should be postponed until the Government sees fit to give the Methodists a new Boarding School with accommodation for 135 pupils at Norway House, and to give a grant for 40 pupils to the R.C. Boarding School, and that both items be considered in connection with the Estimates for 1912-13. If the Government grants this money the Methodists will have no cause for complaint as the large capital expenditure which they are unable to make will be made by the Government. The Roman Catholics will have no cause for complaint because we will become responsible for the maintenance grant of a school which they have funds to build in a field in which they have not many adherents but in which the pagan element is sufficiently strong to warrant a second Residential School.

The plans and specifications for the proposed Roman Catholic Boarding School at Norway House, which are not on file in the Department, call for a very large building with accommodation for 100 pupils and a staff of about 20. The building will be constructed of wood on a cement foundation and the Church has a sawmill on the site and is getting out the necessary building material. The church owns the land on which the building is to be erected and when it is put up it will be a church owned building and come under class "A" and be entitled to a per capita grant of $125.00. If it were a Government owned building the per capita grant would only be $100.00.

Under the terms of the agreement in regard to the
the management of Indian boarding schools the Department could not contribute towards the erection of this building, as only two classes are recognized, church owned and Government owned buildings. Building operations are now under way and this will be a church owned building in the fullest sense of the term and if the church had wished the Department to assume the cost of the building it would have had to be put up by public tender under Section 36, Chapter 39 of the Public Works Acts, Revised Statutes of Canada, Vol.1, and erected on Government land.

The Department is putting up a boarding school building at Norway House to be conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church, the cost of which will not be more than half the amount required for the Roman Catholic school and, as the Methodists have been a long time in the field, they would naturally object to the Roman Catholics being given a building costing twice as much as the Department is allowing them.

There is usually a considerable unexpended balance left over from the School Vote each year and if the Department would be justified in making a grant towards this building the money could be found for the purpose.

The staff of this school is composed of as follows; The Revd Father Lecoeq, Principal, The Revd Father Thomas, Assistant, Sister Superior, Marguerite Mary, Matron, Sister Mary de Lourdes, Teacher, Sister St John, Cooking Dept., Sister Bernadette, Seamstress, and two Lay Brothers who attend to all the outside work.

Accommodation

The Boarding School although a small building has ample accommodation for the number of children in residence. The building is a frame building 20x30 feet, two storeys in height, with a kitchen attached to the main building, and is in very good condition. There is another building of 16x20ft, which is built of logs, in which the Revds Father Lecoeq and Father Thomas and the two Lay Brothers reside also the boys in the school have their sleeping quarters upstairs in this building, which is nice and warm in the coldest of weather. The Nuns four in number, along with the girls of the school have their sleeping quarters in the main building, which is kept warm day and night, thus making it very comfortable for the children.

The main building downstairs is divided into 1 dining room, for the staff 1 dining room for the children, 1 bed-room large enough for the four Nuns, and 1 large Bed-room for the girls, 1 large room used as a recreation room for the boys, while the dining room is used for the same purpose for the girls.

The kitchen is a building attached to the main building and therefore does not interfere with the arrangements (over)
arrangements, for the children in the main building. Upstairs this is divided into a Chapel and a Class Room for the children in residence. All of this I may state is kept scrupulously clean and neat. The rooms in the main building downstairs are daily disinfected in the morning so as to purify the air and keep the rooms in a healthy condition.

Ventilation/
This is secured by opening the windows and doors when required.

Heating/
This is obtained by using furnace stoves downstairs, which supplies upstairs with hot-air and makes the school and chapel very comfortable.

Residence/
The number of children in residence are 5 treaty Indian children, and 9 half-breed children whose mothers have died this winter, the Nuns taking care of these children for the present until the parents can keep them home.

Studies etc./
The studies taught the children are those which are approved of by the Department of Indian Affairs, viz; Reading, Writing, Spelling, Dictation, Drawing, Composition, Hygiene, Calisthenics, Geography, Grammar, Domestic Economy which includes Politeness and Cleanliness, Vocal Music, Plain Sewing, Fancy Sewing, Knitting, Cooking, Baking, Laundry work, and fancy work in knitting, crocheting, darning, lace work, and embroidery.

Thursday afternoons are used for giving the boys instructions in light labour, such as piling wood and cleaning up all refuse about the place in the winter, and in summer by assisting in the garden, and other light labours. The girls on Thursday afternoons are instructed in fancy work, sewing, and knitting, also in light household work. On Saturdays if there is no light work for the boys to do they attend school for half a day.

Day School here at Norway House as it appears in the Blue Book for 1912. As I suppose the intention of the Department is grounded on the reports of this school for the last few years.

The Report Of The Superintendent of Indian Education for 1912, page 411 say that the Roman Catholic School here has an enrollment of 9 boys and 7 girls, 16 in all. From personal knowledge and also from the word of your Agent here, Mr. Stewart, the Roman Catholic people here have only two (2) scholars of school age belonging to this Reserve. They have had some half breed children attending their school also a few children from Cross Lake Band which may be Treaty children.

It has always appeared to me as a great injustice that the Catholic people should have even a grant for a day school here when they have not the required number of children. That imported children from a neighboring Reserve where they already have a day school and where they have children enough to justify a claim for a boarding school should be considered reason for a boarding school here seems strange to me. The Methodist Church has been doing missionary and educational work here for the last seventy two years and yet when our average attendance ran below six here at Rossville your agent, Mr. Calverley, warned us that we had better raise it or we would be likely to lose the Government grant. How then is it possible for the R.C. Church to be given a starting grant when they have only two pupils all told of school age? Much less is there any justification for the granting of help towards a Boarding School.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Dr. Roche -

In forwarding the Memorandum to Council to you dated the 12th January, accepting the lowest tender for the construction of the Roman Catholic boarding school building at Cross Lake, I beg to point out that this school is to provide for the children of the Roman Catholic Indians in the diocese of Keewatin, and that the activities of the church so far as they are aided by the Government, are to be limited to this school. A few residential pupils were accommodated at Norway House but these pupils are to be transferred to the Cross Lake school when it is completed.

As the Department is constantly being pressed for the erection of buildings for residential schools, principally in remote districts, where the Indians have not at present such educational advantages, I think it well to endeavour to fix a policy for the
Department with reference to future grants for educational purposes. So far as these demands are concerned, the educational field may be divided into two classes.

(1) Schools which are already established in more or less settled districts. The requisitions made upon us for building expenditure for this class of schools are for repairs and enlargements, and in some cases complete rebuilding. It should be remembered that most of these schools were erected by the church authorities or by the Department without any attention to sanitary arrangements. In many cases they have fallen into disrepair and are not suitable for the work which is carried on within their walls.

(2) Schools which are intended to supplement the missionaries' efforts to evangelize the Indians. The majority of these applications must necessarily come from remote districts where the Indians earn their livelihood by hunting and fishing.

It seems to me clear that our first duty is to meet the needs which arise in class 1, and to consider
it our first object to thoroughly equip the old institutions.

When the question of Indian Education was being considered by your predecessor in office in the autumn of 1910, and when the per capita grants were increased and the schools standardized, we stated on the authority of Hon. Mr. Oliver that the Government was willing to spend a moderate amount from year to year in establishing new and modern buildings, but would not undertake to furnish modern buildings in all cases where they are required within a short space of time.

Our main Estimates for the current year provide for $342,000.00 for buildings for residential schools and $10,925.00 for buildings for day schools. It seems to me that that is a fair annual expenditure for some years to come. At that rate of expenditure we should be able in two years to meet all the requirements of the older institutions.

I trust this outline of policy will meet with your approval.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Feb. 5th, 1915.

Subject: Official trip to Split Lake.

Sir,

I beg to forward a report of my official trip to Split Lake to look into the condition of the Indians in that portion of this Agency and also to look into the freighting of the I.P. Treaty and Destitute Supplies to Split Lake and Nelson House reserves.

On the 8th of January I left the Agency for Split Lake and arrived at Cross Lake on the 11th. I remained at Cross Lake on Sunday and on Monday the 17th, I left Cross Lake for Split Lake and arrived there on the 17th after a fairly good journey, with the exception of one day at Thicket Portage where we had to lay over on account of a blizzard. On Monday the 15th, I held a meeting with the Chief William KitchiKeesick and Mr Fox also being present, the other councillors were not present as they were away hunting.

I am glad to report that while a few of the Indians at Split Lake are poor and destitute and are receiving assistance, yet there is no real destitution, I think now that I went there and saw the condition of the Indians at Split Lake myself, and explained to them how they could avoid being dependent on the Government for their food and clothing, that they will make stronger efforts to hunt fur and food in the lakes close to their reserve. I pointed out to them that I had induced a trader to come amongst them who would pay better prices for their fur than the H.E. Company were doing, and that by hunting the kinds of fur that were fetching fair prices, they could easily be better off and more comfortable. I also explained to them that the Department would not assist able bodied men who would not try to help themselves. If a man who tried and failed, then...
possibly some assistance would be given him so that he could make another effort. The Chief promised to see that his people would obey these instructions, and that if they did not try to help themselves, they would only have themselves to blame for being destitute, and that no assistance would be given unless they made this effort. The Revd Mr Fox has kindly consented to act with the Chief and start all who are able to go and hunt, and possibly give some of them some assistance, so as to enable them to go to their hunting camps.

Re Freighting of their Treaty and Destitute Supplies

I also spoke to them of how that their Treaty and Destitute Supplies would probably come by rail as far as Thicket Portage next spring, which would be much closer than coming to Norway House. I made a careful calculation of what the rate per pound would be, and told them it would be $4\frac{1}{2}$ a pound with rations included. The Chief has promised to get seven canoes to freight their supplies. The Nelson House Indians have also agreed to come to Thicket Portage for their supplies. The money they earn on their freighting to be paid them at Treaty time. Mr Cowan a merchant at Thicket Portage has promised to receive and store the I.B. supplies for these two reserves, and also to furnish them with rations for their trip home.

I would here beg to state that I think this the most direct way of getting the supplies forwarded for these two reserves, Nelson House and Split Lake. Next year the supplies could be forwarded to the Manitou rapids on the Nelson river, which would be much shorter again for the Split Lake Indians, but I think Thicket Portage would be closer for the Nelson House Indians than coming to the Manitou. The only advantage to the Nelson House Indians in coming to the Manitou, would be that there would not be so much portaging to do, and their supplies could be landed at Nelson House in a much better and cleaner condition.

I would like to hear from the Department
as soon as possible, if it was decided to freight the Treaty and Restitute supplies for these two reserves via the Pas to Thicket Portage, so that I could let the Indians know if they were to come to Thicket Portage for their supplies instead of coming all the way to Norway House, before winter travelling was done.

For Split Lake the Revd Mr Fox could be informed at Winnipeg at the Indian Office, as Mr Fox is attending a Masonic meeting or function, some time this month at Winnipeg, and a telegram or letter stating the wishes of the Department in that respect would find Mr Fox at Winnipeg. Mr Fox could then inform the Indians at Split Lake what route to take, whether to Norway House or Thicket Portage. On my return to Cross Lake I re-inspected the Roman Catholic boarding school and I will make a separate report of this inspection.
Subject: Inspection of the Roman Catholic Boarding School, Cross Lake

On Monday the 25th of January I duly inspected the Roman Catholic boarding school called St Joseph's at Cross Lake. I now beg to forward a full report on this school.

The staff of the school consists of the following members:

The Revd Father Lecocq. Principal.
The Revd Father Thomas. Assistant Principal,
The Revd Sister Superior Marguerite Marie, Matron.
The Revd Sister Camille, Assistant Matron,
The Revd Sister Alphonsus de Liguori, Teacher,
The Revd Sister Bernadette, Sewing Teacher,
The Revd Sister St Jean, In charge of the kitchen,
Brother Gauthier, Mechanical Superintendent,
Brother Cordau, Assistant
Mr Desautel, Layman and Teamster.

This completes a list of the staff at present; another teacher is to be added to the staff in the coming summer, so as to be able to give their best attention to the education of the Roman Catholic children on this reserve and other reserves. I took the measurements of the different buildings in use so that a complete idea would be had of this school.

Measurement of Buildings

The main building used as school and which is attached to the church is 40 x 56 feet with one story. The residence of Father Lecocq and male assistants with a dormitory for the boys upstairs measures, 28ft x 34ft x 16 ft x 34 ft. A store building which can be used for further school purposes measures, 20ft x 30ft.

In the spring time when warmer weather appears, tents will be erected as dormitories for the pupils. One large tent size, 40ft x 40ft will be capable of housing all the girl pupils with two sisters in charge. Two tents 14ft x 28ft will be erected for the boys with two brothers in charge, thus you will see that it is the intention of the Principal Father
Father Lecocq and his able assistants to keep up their boarding school in a very efficient manner. The day school will be kept separate and which will be used as a preparatory school for the boarding school, on much the same lines as the Methodist boarding and day school at Norway House is conducted.

At present all the girls are housed in the main building with the sisters in charge. These dormitories I inspected and found them to be spotlessly clean in every particular; ventilation was provided for by having all the windows opened all day. Another feature which speaks well for the Sister Superior in charge is, that every day these dormitories are disinfected so as to prevent any sickness invading these dormitories.

The boys are housed at the Principal's residence upstairs, the lower part of the building is divided into two fairly large rooms, one room being used as a day school, which is taught by the Revd Sister Superior. The other room is used by the Principal as his private room and office.

In the event of the Department allowing the Catholics to admit more pupils, the store building will be re-modelled with dormitories upstairs and placed in charge of Mr Desautel. Downstairs will be used as an additional class room, in fact everything possible will be done by the Revd Father Lecocq to spare no expense in housing, feeding and clothing admitted pupils to this school, if permitted by the Department to take Applications for just as many pupils as there is room for. I may also mention, so well is every detail looked after for the care of these children, that there is no overcrowding. The Principal estimates that he can take care of 25 pupils with the accommodations that he has, and trusts the Department will meet his wishes in this respect. I also inspected the class rooms, and found that there are a total of 4 children attending this school classed as follows:

Hygiene is a favorite subject at this school, and some of the essays on how to keep a home, are very good, and if only they practise what they are taught now and firmly believe it, they will make good examples for the other Indians on this reserve.

The Brothers instruct the boys in
in carpentering, gardening, and other useful outdoor work. One of the boys is now a good shoemaker and is able to turn out a good job of mending boots. The girls are taught by the Sisters all manner of housework and two of the girls are assisting Sister St Jean in the kitchen and learning how to cook. All kinds of sewing, knitting, fancy work, and mending are done by the girls also, and they have a very competent instructor in the person of Sister Bernadette. It is the intention of the Sisters to give an exhibition of all the work done by the children of this school at the next Annuity payments.

The Principal Father Lecocq has asked me in this report to emphasize the fact, that it is purely a boarding school that he is managing, and wishes to be recognized as such. He took the children of his school at Norway House and all the fixings belonging to the boarding school on the Jack River at his own expense to Cross Lake, as he did not wish the children to lose the advantage they already had, by waiting for the new school to be built.

During this hard winter it has been a Godsend to the Catholic Indians of Cross Lake, that they had a chance to place some of their children in a school of this kind, when they could only barely provide their food, and not their clothing and in some instances in which they could not even provide food enough. It would come as a great hardship to these poor Indians who have given their children to be educated, fed, and clothed, and also, how to live cleaner lives, to be forced to take their children back to their homes, after seeing the good and thoughtful care taken of them. It is to be hoped that the Department will assist Father Lecocq in his good intentions and grant him his boarding school. I respectfully submit this report for your consideration.

The Consecration at Cross Lake.

We offer to our readers this week a full account of the journey to the opening of the Indian School over 400 miles north of Winnipeg.

The journey was long, tedious, tiresome, yet dangerous, and it shows the intrepid courage of His Grace Archbishop Sullivan and his ardent desire to appreciate the work that has been done by the Oblate Fathers in this district that he roughed the journey with the party.

The visit was full of inspiration, so full redolent of the sacrifices of Catholic effort and enterprise, and it was not brought to the success that the visitors saw without consecrated lives being given up for its fruition.

Isolated from the things that are considered necessary for civilized life, at least one priest and one sister gave up their lives here in the wilderness owing to the privations that they had to undergo, and that their ordeal has been the inspiration of the others who followed them so one will galebay.

Father Lessig spent the winter one year in the woods cutting logs to build the school, but before these reached the place intended, the winds and storms scattered his efforts, and the logs were monuments seen on the beaches preaching the sermon of his servant in his attempt to build a sanctuary in the wilderness.

Bishop Charlebois was elated, he had baptized the first child of the mission on one of his lone visits in the wilderness, and his personality was a cameo amongst the notables at the festivities.

The material efforts of all concerned have been a success, and with such self-sacrifice in the past, the Catholic church has no reason to fear that her gospel will not bring blessings and graces to those whom she offers the message of the Christ crucified, who died for all men, excluding neither race or color.
Une œuvre apostolique dans la sauvagerie

Une excursion dont le souvenir vivra longtemps dans la mémoire de ceux qui y prirent part, c'est celle organisée par le R.P. Lecoeur, o.m.i., vers les régions lointaines de Cross Lake. En cet endroit il y a une mission inconnue de sauvageons. Mgr Morin est là avec nous et une équipe de travaux apostoliques de toutes sortes, le R.P. Lecoeur s'est donné entièrement à cette mission et au prix d'immenses sacrifices, il a réussi à établir sur la mission. Il vient d'y terminer la construction d'une grande école pour les petits sauvages.

Ce dévouement méritait une profonde sympathie de la part de Mgr l'archevêque et des nombreux amis du bon père. Aussi Mgr Béliveau n'a pas hésité un instant à faire de ce voyage long et périlleux pour aller assister à la bénédiction de l'école et prouver d'une manière tangible combien il savait apprécier l'œuvre accomplie. Beaucoup de clergé nombreux s'est joint à lui, même que quelques laïques.

Au nombre des prêtres on comptait : Mgr Dugas, P.A.V.G., les PP. Cahill, Lecoeur, Marceau, Rapet, Thomas, Guy, Perreault, Vézina, le honoraire Oblate de Marie ; le R.P. Louis, trappiste, le R.P. Girard, rédemptoriste, le R.P. Grangette, dominicain, et MM. les abbés Jubinville, Giron, Bélanger, Joubert, Picot, Leroux, Moreau, Cournoyer.

Parmi les laïques se trouvaient MM. Forget, gérant de la Banque d'Hochelaga, Lachance, M.D., Bertrand, avocat, Tremblay, entrepreneur, Guibert, Panet, Duveyron, Stortz, Pepin, Vermaudon, Leveque, Pelletier, Doucet, Chauchat, Kinsella, rédacteur à la North-West Review.

Pour égayer le voyage, les musiciens et quelques-uns sont membres de la fanfare La Vérendrye, organisèrent une fanfare et firent retentir le lac Winnipeg d'harmonies pour lui jusqu'à là inconnues.

30 août

Un dernier coup de sifflet et le "Wolverine" quitte Selkirk. Le Wolverine est un joli bateau à vapeur de 285 tonnes appartenant à "The Northern Fish Co." Sans avoir le confort des grands navires, il est bien aménagé. Il a cabines, salon, bar, cuisine. La cuisine y est aussi excellente.

En quelques minutes nous perdons de vue les sombres entrepôts de poisson de Selkirk et descendons le courant de la rivière Redge. Les paysages deviennent plus beaux, abondant en fleurs et d'arbres verts sous les rayons du soleil d'automne. Lentement ce paysage change. Nous approchons du lac ; les bois se font plus rares et se sont de larges plaine qui encadrent la rivière. Ces plaines se montrent bientôt couvertes de nombreux petits lacs, qui abondent en canards et en renards. L'environnement est proche et la rivière se divise pour former un delta. Bientôt le lac apparaît immense et splendide. Ses flots sont bleus et légers, tandis que la roche est solide, massive. La nuit tombe, mais elle demeure calme et paisible.

La plus fraternelle gaîté règne à bord. On chante, la fanfare joue, puis la prière récitée sur le pont vient terminer une journée si bien commencée.

31 août

Le vent du nord s'est levé ; il souffle avec violence ; le lac est gris, il fait froid. Le vent se fait sentir et déjà plusieurs en subissent les effets. Les prêtres sont désappointés de ne pouvoir pas dire la messe. Il y a des chapelles portatives, et tous les groupes nombreux ont pu céder à tous les mouvements désordonnés du bateau. Nous longeons la rive gauche du lac, une rive inhabitable et sauvage. À 8h30 heures, le "Wolverine" s'arrête à Little Bull Head pour s'approvisionner de combustible. Tous en profitent pour se remettre un peu le cœur en courant les petits bords environnants. Nous sentons que nous approchons de la fin du voyage de l'automne. Le lac est de nouveau sauvage avec ses îles démodées et ses rives faites de rochers et de langue de terre. Cette nature change tout à coup, et se fait pittoresque. Ce sont maintenant des îlots arrosés et richement boisés, des rivages aux haies nombreuses et colorées, des tons côtés de merveilleux effets de lumière. Le "Victor" change à tout moment sa course, car la navigation est extrêmement difficile, et il faut un certain temps de manœuvre pour éviter les îles dans le lac est rempli. Le dîner nous est servi sur le pont, à la mode des marins.

À trois heures, le "Victor" est au quai du portage de Whiski Jack. En effet, d'ailleurs, les bagages sont chargés sur des chariots roulant sur des rails en bois et tirés par des chevaux. Le gouvernement ferait une bonne œuvre en donnant aux missionnaires de Cross Lake les moyens de remplacer ces pièces de bois par des véritables rails. Cela rendrait le portage beaucoup moins pénible. Pendant que les chevaux tirent leurs charges, les voyageurs passent à pied et parcoururent rapidement la distance de cinq milles qui les sépare de Cross Lake. Ce n'est pas encore le terme, puisqu'il nous reste 13 milles avant l'arrivée à la destination. Quel est donc l'étonnement de tous de trouver toute une flottille de canots automobiles. Vraiment nous aurions aimé quelque chose de plus original dans cette province. Cependant nous avons réunis vite avec la gazoline en considérant l'immense serviette qu'elle va nous rendre. Nous saluons Mgr Charbonneau, depuis quelques temps à Osoyoos.
Lake, et venu à notre rencontre, et prenons place dans une grande berge. Les canots sont attelés à cette berge et la traînent lentement dans un roulement sonore de moteurs.

Enfin la mission apparaît à nos yeux. Des Indiens saluent notre arrivée par des salves, tandis que la fanfare leur répond par ses meilleurs airs.

L'école de Cross Lake dépasse toutes nos prévisions. Nous avons une maison de 104 par 40, à trois étages et construite en pierre solide. L'intérieur comprend plusieurs chambres, des classes, deux salles de récréation, deux dortoirs, un réfectoire et un grand salon. La chapelle est une construction moderne. La maison est éclairée à l'électricité, chauffée à la vapeur et desservie par un système d'aqueduc tout à fait moderne. Il ne manque pas de confort. Nous avons une école qui peut être considérée comme une merveille dans cette région lointaine. On ne saurait croire tout ce qu'il a fallu de travail, de persévérance et de patience pour les portes pour la construire. On a du transporter le matériel d'une très grande distance et par des voies de communication très primitives.

Ces mêmes Indiens ne sont rien de moins que des chrétiens de bonne volonté. Ils ont tout employé, même les moyens les plus bas. Ils ont fait circuler au milieu des sauvages les idées les plus alléchantes et les plus invraisemblables sur le compte des religieux; ils ont distribué la Bible à ceux qui pouvaient la lire; ils ont utilisé de toute leur influence auprès des autorités civiles. Le zèle intellectuel de Mgr P. Lecocq a triomphé de ces difficultés et l'œuvre de Dieu a vaincu celle de Satan.

La maison est construite dans un endroit assez à faire étonner, sur une petite échancrure par une baie qui forme un port où les navires sont toujours en sûreté.

Le travail accompli auprès des petits sauvages est lui aussi étonnant. Ces enfants des bois sont gentils et bien habillés, très propres et leur allure qui tient à la fois de la civilisation et de la sauvagerie.

3 septembre

C'est aujourd'hui dimanche et Mgr Charlebois célèbre la grand'messe, assisté du Rèv. Père P. Magnan, o.m.i. M. l'abbé Lefevre remplit les fonctions de diacre, le R. P. Dugas, o.m.i., de sous-diacre, et M. l'abbé Caron de célébrantaire. Mgr Charlebois donne une allocution et il exprime d'abord son regret de ne pouvoir pas parler sauvage, car il est représentant de l'Église et l'Église aime à s'adresser à ses enfants dans la langue qu'ils parlent.

Sa Grandeur prend pour texte de son sermon ses paroles de Notre-Seigneur à ses apôtres : "Allez, enseignez tous les peuples, les nations, le nom du Père, du Fils et du Saint-Esprit, etc." Par ces paroles Jésus-Christ donne à ses apôtres l'ordre de prêcher l'Évangile, d'enseigner ce qu'il leur a dit d'enseigner.

Dieu a fait homme ; il se fait petit enfant et grandit comme fils du charpentier Joseph ; mais dès l'âge de douze ans Il montre qu'Il est Dieu et le prouve ensuite par sa vie et ses miracles. Il vient nous guérir et nous faire connaître des choses que sans Lui nous n'aurions jamais connues ; Il veut nous dire que Dieu est notre Père, le chef d'une famille dont nous sommes tous les enfants. Vous donc, enfants des bois, vous êtes grands et nobles puisque vous êtes les enfants de Dieu.

Jésus-Christ laisse des apôtres pour continuer sa œuvre ; Il leur dit : "Allez, prêchez..." Il ne leur dit pas : "Allez, distribuez des livres." Il dit : "Je suis la voie, la vérité, la vie." Je suis la voie qui conduit au ciel, je suis la vie des âmes. Il est une Bible et Il en fond qu'une ! Il n'y a qu'un seul troupier et un seul pasteur ; il n'y a aussi qu'une seule vérité et en Afrique, comme en Amérique, comme en Europe, nous devons être successivement les apôtres, présenter la même doctrine. Jésus-Christ désire que ses prêtres ne se marient pas afin qu'ils soient plus libres de se dévouer pour le salut des âmes. "Vous trouverez des femmes, des Gospel-girls, qui ressemblent à être mères, afin d'avoir des coeurs de mères pour tous ceux qui tombent sous leur direction." Ce n'est que dans la véritable Église que l'on trouve ces responsabilités, comme elles existent dans toutes les autres religions. Les missionnaires ne sont pas en quête de richesses ; ils ne veulent que les âmes pour les conduire au ciel. Pour sanctifier les âmes, Jésus-Christ établit des sacrements, signes sensibles qui atteignent le corps et l'âme et donnent la grâce.

Nous sommes venus ici pour appuyer les enseignements que les missionnaires vous donnent et vous provoquer que vous êtes de la même Église que nous, du même troupeau de Jésus-Christ.

J'invite le missionnaire à vous traduire ces mots à vous dire que nous croyons et pratiquons les mêmes choses et que nous espérons tous d'être réunis un jour en Dieu siéges.

Le R. P. Bonnald, o.m.i., traduit en vermonais le discours.

Au dîner, Mgr Charlebois adresse des paroles de bienvenue aux visiteurs, et particulièrement à Mgr Béliveau. C'est, dit-il, le plus beau jour pour Cross Lake. Ensuite, le R. P. Bonnald, fondateur de la mission fondée en 1901 par le R. P. Bonnald, qui passa le premier hiver dans une cabane de sauvages. Les conversions se firent bientôt nombreuses et il devint nécessaire de construire une école. La mission passa par de nombreuses épreuves, mais elle vit aujourd'hui son plein épanouissement. Il faut adresser des félicitations au R. P. Lecocq qui a construit l'école et au père de la mission, le saint Joseph qui a protégé l'oeuvre. Le R. P. Lecocq n'a mélangé ni activité ni dévouement. Il était impossible de faire mieux. Le bois n'était pas assez dur, il fallait de la patience. Mgr Charlebois, Gélieuse et Frère Gauthier et Cordes, qui ont si bien aidé le R. P. Lecocq. Il rappelle le souvenir de Mgr Langevin, dont le dévouement fut si grand et si efficace. Les R. P. Béliveau, Perrot, Forget et Thémas ont aussi beaucoup fait pour l'oeuvre. Le Département des Indiens mérite des remerciements. Monseigneur remercie tous les visiteurs et dit cette année sera dans la tradition indien l'année de la grande fête.

Mgr Béliveau prend ensuite la parole. Il fait remarquer que les rôles sont intervertis. Nous devons remercier au lieu d'être remerciés. L'immense imitation nous a donné l'occasion de nous contempler les beautés naturelles de cette partie de notre pays ; car il n'est pas facile d'oublier le beau spectacle qu'offre le parcours de Winnipeg à Cross Lake. Ensuite, en qui est pas cette imitation nous fournit une occasion de profonde éducation. Le spectacle de ce qui s'est fait et se fait encore à Cross Lake et dans d'autres parties de l'Ontario nous montre que l'esprit apostolique n'est pas disparu de la terre. Les Oblats de Marie Immaculée font revivre dans leurs missions les jours apostoliques. On se demande parfois si les conditions qui existent dans ces régions sauvages sont vraiment proportionnées aux sacrifices considérables que demandent ces missions. Les Oblats jugent comme jugeait le Divin Maître. Une chose est certaine : si les Indiens n'étaient pas en vain qu'ils ont pris pour devise : "Evangeliser les pauvres." C'est surtout sous ce rapport que nous devons de la reconnaissance à ceux qui nous ont instruits. Ils nous aident à monter vers le ciel.
ses comme Notre-Seigneur en a juge lui-même.

Ainsi Dieu se plaît-il à bénir spécialement ceux qui font cette œuvre. Une communauté dont les membres font aussi allégrement des œuvres qui demandent une si grande dépense peut être assurée de l'assistance divine.

Mgr Langevin est été heureux d'être ici aujourd'hui; lui sait que le charme des excursions et leur donner un caractère spécial. Ses œuvres font nombreuses, et l'une d'elles, la fondation de la congrégation des Missionnaires Oblats du Sacré-Coeur et de Marie Immaculée, mérite une considération particulière. Le développement observé par cette Congrégation qui travaille ici depuis quelques années, lui attireront des bénédictions abondantes.

Mgr Dugas, P.A., V.C., félicite amicalement le R. P. Lecoe et tous ceux qui l'ont secondé. Il admire les petits Indiens qui sont charmants dans leurs manières, dans leur chant et dans leur piété.

Le R. P. Lecoe, dont la mission est si profonde qu'il ne peut retenir ses sanglots et remet au lendemain ce qu'il a dit à ses visiteurs et à ses aides.

Dans la soirée, après les cérémonies, il y a confirmation par Mgr Bélievau, suivie du Salut du T. S. Sacrement, puis bénédiction de l'école et d'une grande croix plantée sur les bords du lac en face de l'école.

Au souper M. l'abbé Jubinville, curé de la cathédrale, et M. le Dr Lafrance, parlant l'un au nom des prêtres, l'autre au nom des laïques, ont prononcé un discours. Le R. P. Lecoe a une bonne offre de tous les excursionnistes. C'est le désir des donateurs que la somme soit partagée entre le Père Lecoe et les bons soeurs des Oblats.

Dans la soirée les Indiens contemplent un spectacle sans précédent pour eux, un magnifique feu d'artifice lancé sur les bords du lac.

4 septembre

C'est aujourd'hui grand dîner à l'école. L'autorité civile y est représentée par deux agents de police montée. Des traitres, amis des missionnaires et les écoliers de l'école se joignent ainsi. Le R. P. Lecoe prend la parole.

"Après ce qui m'a été dit hier, j'aurais certainement mauvaise grâce, si je n'étais pas de bonne humeur qui peut être encore. Les propos élogieux que, dans votre grande charité, vous avez eu le devoir adresser à un humble missionnaire me touchent d'autant plus que ces honneurs sont directement à la Communauté des Oblats de Marie Immaculée dont je suis membre et aux ouvriers et ouvrières qui m'ont été adjoints pour mener à bonne fin ce que nous avons commencé."

Le changement maintenant terminées. Nous reviendrons un peu fatigués, il est vrai, mais l'âme embaumée des choses éternelles et sublimes qu'ils ont vues là-bas.

Nous avons sous les yeux le rapport enfantin du Free Press. Ce rapport nous étonne. Nous attendons à mieux que cela. Le représentant du Free Press, M. Colman, par son article, part à une excursion organisée par des gens sérieux et dans un but sérieux; il fait partout traité comme un des excursionistes, partageant avec l'hospitalité des Pères; il est à convaincre les missionnaires les plus propres à éveiller des sentiments nobles et généreux. Tout cela n'a pu déterminer sur lui, et n'a laissé place qu'à des trivialités du plus mauvais goût.

À cet âge, cet individu se rendrait compte qu'il lui manquait cette éducation nécessaire au gentilhomme, mais à lire on constate qu'il est plus savoureux que les Indiens qu'il décrit d'une façon si dégoûtante.

Dear Sir:

The Benediction of the Indian Boarding School of Cross Lake took place on the third instant and the festival continued on the fourth. I am one of the excursionists to Cross Lake. Father Lecoq who remained there prayed me to write to you.

Every one was delighted at the fine site of the School and at the aspect of the building and its so fine equipment. We were also marvelled to see the little Indian children so well trained.

I have heard Father Louis,- an old Country French man and one who knows, - say : This School would be a fine building in Winnipeg, in Ottawa as well as in Paris. Imagine how grand it looks in that wilderness.

All those present regretted very much the absence of a representative of your Department.

His Grace Archbishop Beliveau upon the invitation of Right Reverend Bishop Charlebois hath made himself
a duty to be present. R.R. Bishop Charlebois was back in time from Fort Nelson to attend, and quite a number of priests and of laymen (about fifty) were in attendance.

Father Lecoq hath caused the Indians to be informed of the festival, and although the hunting season had begun quite a number of them were present.

R.R. Bishop Charlebois and Father Lecoq in addressing the Indians and the people in attendance expressed their gratitude towards the Dominion Government and the Department of Indian Affairs for the magnificent school the reserve of Cross Lake had been endowed with. Here I may say that Father Lecoq referred particularly to your kindness and to your constant readiness to help him on all occasion he called upon you.

At the request of the Reverend Father I send you per concurrent mail films of photographs taken by me, and I would be very much obliged if you would let me have a couple of copies of each of the films,- one copy I am to transmit to Father Lecoq and the other would be for me. Also at Father Lecoq's request I mail you one copy of the NORTH WEST REVIEW and one of LA LIBERTE containing a report of the celebration held at Cross Lake.
on the occasion of the Benediction of the School.

I remain, dear Sir,

Your humble servant:

Sir,

I beg to advise you that I made a trip to Cross Lake. Leaving here the morning of the 10th and returning the night of the 14th. I inspected the day school and the boarding school, had a talk with the Chief and Councilors relative to affairs on the reserve, saw Mrs Gaudia about destitute rations and sick Indians, visited a few sick for Mrs Gaudia and arranged with the traders to have their accounts in by the end of the month.

Conditions at the boarding school both as to the health of the pupils and their progress I found satisfactory. The four orphans who are under the school age were well clothed and looked well cared for and happy.

As was to be expected, the influenza has interfered considerably with attendance at the day school and the pupils attending do not look either will clothed or too well nourished. The teacher has done what she can to brighten up the room, but it is impossible to create a cheerful atmosphere where building and furniture is so dilapidated.

The chief tells me that the band has never been so hard up, the fur catch is about a third of an average year and there is no work of any sort to be had at present the potato crop was very poor. The fall catch of fish was good but is about exhausted and it will be about a month before the fish begin to come into the river, so it looks as if assistance will have to be continued to these people for some time yet. To date rations issued to the band will amount to about £1500.00, and as far as I could see good care has been taken to see that the Department has not been imposed on, either by the Indians or the trader.
The Principal of the boarding school showed me the tables which they made for the children's dining room, a voucher for same is being forwarded by this mail. The tables are strongly built and ought to last for a considerable time. The top is of two inch plank covered by two inch cement and finished with a keen cement which resembles marble. While I think that there is value for the expense charged, I told the Principal that I thought if the estimate had been submitted before starting with the work it is probable that a cheaper table would have been approved.

I am also forwarding a plan and estimate for an ice house for the boarding school. On receipt of letter 321295-5 dated January 4th, I forwarded a copy to the Principal of the Boarding School, he had not received it hence the delay in forwarding particulars as requested. I hope this delay will not result in delaying your order for proceeding with the work.

Also a plan and estimate for a day school at Cross Lake. While it calls for more than you may care to expend at this time, still I thought it would give you an idea of the cost of construction at that point. Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed copy of Cross Lake Indian Boarding School's Financial Statement for the year ending March 31st, 1918.

The deficit appears to be $3713.17, but I take the liberty to point out that the wages of the principal employees of the School, the Brothers, to the amount of $2850.00 though charged in the Expenditure, were not actually paid up and are cancelled in the Receipts' statement. If these wages are taken into consideration the Deficit would be brought up to $6563.17. Let me add also that the Principal of the School, Rev. Fr H. Boissin O.M.I., who is giving all his time and attention to his duties is not taking any salary. In my judgment he should do so as he is entitled to it and if such a course was followed I venture to say that the $3000.00 mark would be reached for the deficit.

This deficit has been paid by His Lordship Bishop O. Charlebois O.M.I. partly from money which he has obtained through begging (literally) and which was destined to the religious works of his poor Diocese, partly from charity gifts intended for his Indians, partly from money borrowed in order to meet up expenses.

You will readily understand that we are in a very serious position and consequently the present letter is an urgent appeal for help as we cannot bear the strain any longer and moreover as His Lordship is in need of the money he has so liberally advanced.

Let me say that the Department seems to have a great deal in order to cope with the situation arising out of the present war circumstances in granting an additional per capita grant of $10.00, but I feel sorry to say that in the case of Cross Lake School this generous treatment has not been sufficient. The situation of the School and the difficulty of access are a cause of enormous expenses and even if the greatest of cares is taken supplies are lost or deteriorated in the different portages. Another consideration is that as yet there is no farm in connection with the School and everything is to be brought from Winnipeg or other places. The potato crop of last year was a total
On account of the cold and unhappily, the potatoes bought in Winnipeg in perfect condition reached the School in a rotten state. I do not mention flour and other commodities which are generally received in damaged condition totally independent of the shippers' care and attention. I may mention that the flour supply for the present year has reached Cross Lake in a very good state.

We have been obliged to buy oats from Winnipeg and last Winter from Le Pas. A few tons of hay were also sent from the latter place on horse trains from Mile 137, Hudson's Bay Railway, and the fanciful price paid may be easily guessed, as well as that of the meat which came from the same point.

Another source of expenses was the buying of Fish which is a necessity in those regions. Having been unable to secure nets the Principal was obliged to buy Fish from local fishermen and the price paid was quite an item in the expense column.

I might add a few other considerations but I have taken already enough of your valuable time for this matter. However, I think that you are conversant enough with the facts to be in a sufficient position to take a generous course on behalf of Cross Lake School. I do not wish to point out the course to be followed but I would suggest the granting of a special bonus which would bring relief and permit us to continue the work which has been declared so satisfactory by the resident Agent.

As promised I will call at your Office about the 21st or 22nd and hope to be favored with good news about the present request.

Yours very truly,

Joseph

Sir,

I have the honor to report that on Dec. 2nd I inspected the Roman Catholic Boarding School (St. Joseph's) at Cross Lake.

I found everything at the School in excellent order. All the rooms and halls were clean and well kept, the children were very clean, well clothed, and appeared very healthy. Some of the rooms are too small; in fact the accommodation at this School should be increased. The dormitories were in excellent order, but somewhat crowded. The air-space of the main dormitories, however, was nearly doubled by leaving open the trapdoors into the attics above. The boys' playroom is very much too small.

The work in the class rooms is excellent, that in the senior room unusually good for Indian children. The girls and boys were very alert and responsive, and the discipline unusually good. Both teachers are new members of the Staff since the Summer vacation.

The School grew sufficient vegetables for their own use in their garden, having had a good yield. They have horses, cows, pigs and chickens, thus producing a large part of their own food stuffs. They have built this year, a new log stable, which is very comfortable. Hay for stock is more easily procured at Cross Lake than at Norway House. Fish are also fairly plentiful.

The pupils here receive some instruction in the care of stock, handling of timber and freight, running of gasoline and steam engines, handling of boats, running a sawmill and planer, some weaving, sewing, and the ordinary domestic duties of the institution.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that on the 14th Inst. I made an inspection of Cross Lake Indian Boarding School. The whole building, from basement to garret was in excellent order and scrupulously clean. The day was cold, but the temperature within the building was warm and comfortable. As stated in former reports, the rooms are small for the number of children, and would ordinarily be considered overcrowded, but the ventilation system appears to work so well, that the atmosphere is fresh and sweet, even in the dormitories a short time after the children were out of them.

The diet of the children appears to be satisfactory as the average health is good. There are two or three cases of sickness, but the sick children are receiving excellent care.

The children are being taught many useful industries. All take part in keeping the dormitories, halls, etc., in spotless condition. Girls learn to cook, sew, wash iron, etc., very much as they will have to do it in their own homes later, without elaborate machinery. Both boys and girls learn to knit, mend, weave, make garments, etc. The boys learn some engineering, some electrical work, carpentry, little shoe-making, blacksmithing, caring for and handling of stock, gardening, handling of cattle, etc.

In the class room excellent work is being done, and real progress made. There is no grade above Grade 6, but this School was opened only a few years ago. The teachers here appear to have overcome the common difficulty in Indian schools everywhere, and the children speak and read distinctly, apparently with understanding, and sufficiently loud. Both are trained and experienced teachers. Writing, drawing and exercise books show great care, neatness and accuracy.

The grounds, stables and equipment are all well kept and in good condition.

Referring to the enclosed Return, it will be found that the number of pupils in this school has fallen below the number allowed.

A number of reasons might be assigned for this, some of which are beyond the control of the Department, such as, "The reaction from the first enthusiasm of the Indians for the new school," "The discovery on the part of the Protestant parents that their children in this school are actually being educated as Roman Catholics," "The Indians, having played the two churches against each other to the limit, find it no longer effective," "The ill health of a number of the larger girls during the past year, with the death of some."

There is another reason which may be beyond the control of the Department, and which arises from the action of the Roman Catholic Church at Norway House, and which might be, at least, discouraged. There are a number of Roman Catholic families at Norway House. The Roman Catholic Mission here was practically closed for some years. This property is not on the Reserve. During the past year, a priest has been in charge, and a number of new buildings have been erected, and the old ones repaired. This summer a Brother has been added, also a Teacher and his wife. A school has been opened. Some children attend as day pupils, and some are boarders. For the latter, the parents pay a small sum per month for board. Some of the children are non-treaty, and some are Treaty. In my opinion, and I have already suggested this to the priest in charge, the Indian children who are residents at his school, should be candidates for the Cross Lake Boarding School, and he is competing with their own school. He assured me that he would accept pupils only for one year, after which he thought the parents would agree to send them to Cross Lake.

It is probable that the Department will be approached with a request to recognize this school at Norway House, and to make a grant toward its maintenance. Under the present circumstances, I would not recommend any assistance, unless as to a small day school, the larger proportion of the pupils of which are non-treaty.

As regards Cross Lake Boarding School, the Principal has suggested compulsion, but I do not think the time opportune for this, since the sickness and death of the large girls at the school has created a strong feeling among the Indians, and with a reason which is, to their minds, sound.

I am merely forwarding this to the Department as information which should be in their hands, and am not suggesting that any action be taken at the present time.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant
