Sir,

I beg to report that on Jan. 9th I made an inspection of St. Joseph's Indian Boarding School at Cross Lake, this Agency.

In the class rooms the work is of a high order. Good practical work is taught, and the teaching is excellent. Progress is shown from visit to visit, although at this visit the children did not appear to grasp their work as well as usual. This was probably due to the fact that my visit was on the third day of school after a couple of weeks absence from the class rooms during the Christmas holidays, and the children had not yet settled to regular routine work.

The health of the children is very good, and is improving. Since my last visit, the children all had measles, but with two or three exceptions, no bad after effects have developed. As the weather was cold, the girls were not playing outside at the time of my visit, but the boys were spending a fair proportion of their time in the open air.

The children were well clothed, and apparently well fed. The school building was spotless and in perfect order. The outbuildings were well kept. Only one is in milk, but quite a number of eggs were being gathered daily from the large number of hens. A good supply of potatoes and other vegetables were grown in the school garden last season. Beef is being secured from The Pas at a reasonable price, although the freight almost equals the original price. There is a good supply of fish on hand.

The Government property here is well cared for. I find that one division of the septic tank has fallen in. This will require replacement in the early summer.

The new addition has been walled in two stories above the basement, and is a good wall. A part of the flooring has also been done. This addition, when completed, will make the accommodations very much better, allowing more room. In my opinion, this school has been overcrowded, as the dormitories and classrooms are too small for the number of pupils allowed. The ventilation system appears to work perfectly, as I have not at any time been able to detect any taint in the air, although the rooms have been too full of pupils.

Sir:

On Monday, Sept. 17th, the staff and pupils of St. Joseph's Indian Residential School, Cross Lake, held a picnic about a mile from the school, across the bay to the east. One of the smaller boys, Albert Dorion, of Berens River, a lad about twelve years of age, got separated from the other boys while chasing squirrels in the woods. His absence was not noted among the crowd until the boys were getting aboard the boat to return to the school. A search was at once made by the Principal, the members of the staff and some of the larger boys. Tracks could be found in places, but owing to the nature of the country, and some bush, these could not be followed closely.

A continuous search was kept up, the Indian men from the reserve joining in, there being about forty men searching. The school bell and mill whistle were sounded at intervals. Food, clothing and notes were placed in the woods where it was thought the boy might find them, with messages giving instructions to the boy as to what to do should he find any of these.

On Friday morning a letter from the Principal reached me at Norway House. I at once notified the R.C.M.P. Police, and asked their assistance. I also requested the Royal Canadian Air Force to make a flight over the area near the place where the boy was lost, in the hope that the observer might be able to pick out the boy if along the shores of the waters, or in open muskeg.

A moth plane, with Flight Sergt. Winny and mechanic McKenzie as observer, left Norway House about 12.30 of Friday noon. On the way to Cross Lake, when nearing the latter, a close lookout was kept along the shores. When flying over the North East shore of Pipestone Lake, a white spot was observed on the rocks. On circling round and flying at a lower altitude, this spot became active, and the lost boy got up and waved his arms. He had been asleep until awakened by the noise of the engines.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
The boy had left his coat behind at the boat when going to chase squirrels; his trousers were torn to pieces scrambling through the bushes, and when found, his clothing was of very little use for warmth. The weather had been cold, and the season being late, there was little to be found in the way of fruits in the woods. He stated that a bear had chased him and that he was tired. At this season of the year he would have perished very soon. He had no matches.

When found, the boy was taken in the plane, direct to the school. He appeared to be little the worse for his experience, of four days in the woods, but he was glad to get back, and he was certainly hungry.

I feel that we should be deeply grateful to the Royal Canadian Air Force for the prompt and efficient assistance rendered. The place where the boy was found was at a considerable distance from the canoe route, and as there are numerous islands in the lake, and the boy did not know the country, he might have again wandered back into the bush, and been lost long enough to perish. Flying Officer Davy, in charge of the station at Norway House, is to be commended for his readiness to co-operate, and the promptness with which he sent out the plane for the search.

Your obedient servant

Boy Is Found by Airmen After a 60 Mile Walk

Twelve-year-old Indian Lad Had Strayed from Schoolhouse in Northern Manitoba.

Lost for five days in the densely timbered wilderness surrounding the St. Joseph's Roman Catholic mission school on Lake Manitoba, a twelve-year-old Indian boy who had walked over sixty miles in an endeavor to find his way home again was found by two Royal Canadian Air Force fliers forty minutes after the order was issued for an aerial search, according to a report just sent in to headquarters.

The boy strayed from the school into the bush and failed to show up again. He lay motionless on the ground hunted frantically for food, he getting farther and farther away from home, struggled through the thick underbrush, tearing his clothing to ribbons and scratching his flesh as it came in contact with thorns and sappings which covered his path. Without food the lad was forced to subsist on what he could find as he strove to regain his home. Wild berries, roots and bark were his daily fare until the fifth day when he was found sleeping on a rocky point jutting from the shores of Cross Lake.

After it became fairly certain that the ground parties would not find him until it was too late, the principal of the school, Rev. Father G. L. Trudelle, O.M.I., requested the Air Force to aid in the search. The order was accordingly issued from the Winnipeg air station to the sub-station at Norway House, asking that an aerial search be started at once.

Flight Sergt. H. J. Winny was immediately despatched in a De Havilland "Moonee" plane with Corporal J. C. MacKenzie as observer. The two men flew low from Lake Manitoba to Pipestone Lake and from there through Cross Lake. Over Cross Lake they saw two small white objects on a rocky point. At first they thought they were merely outcroppings of stone. They flew lower still and circled to investigate. One of the objects moved, stood up and moved frantically at them. They came down very close in to the rock and found the object of their quest sitting on the rock waiting for them, many miles from the nearest ground party.

He was almost naked, and had been asleep in the sun with the tattered remains of his shirt spread out on the rock beside him. At first he had refused them but as they circled low the noise of the engine had roused him from his slumber. He was hungry and tired, while his feet were torn and scratched from his long struggle through the bush, but he appeared to be quite strong and perfectly rational despite his condition.

Asked if he was afraid to fly home, he beamed and said "No." Ten minutes after landing the fliers started back to the school with the exhausted lad sitting on the knees of the observer in the front seat of the little plane.

Three hours after the aerial search had commenced the boy was in bed having the first comfortable sleep he had had in five days.

Local officials say it seems that the report on this operation constitutes the finest story of a successful and speedily terminated flying search which they have encountered. They were all inclined to praise the youngster for his presence of mind in getting out on a point where he was conscious rather than staying in the bushes where they had done.

The whole operation took three hours. The boy was found in forty minutes, and the total flying time of the party was one hour and fifty minutes.
Ottawa, February 26, 1930.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Just a few lines to let you know what the situation is regarding the Crosse Lake disaster. I first heard of this on the C. P. R. train on my way down to Portage La Prairie and immediately got in touch with The Pas and found that Bishop Charebois had left a few hours before for Crosse Lake by plane. I left word that I should be called up as soon as the plane returned and on the same evening I received a message saying that the plane had returned after leaving the Bishop at Crosse Lake, bringing back five of the sisters, two of them very seriously injured. One with a broken back and the other with a broken leg. I was unable, however, to get any information as to what was actually required in the way of food and clothing till the Bishop returned the next day and on Friday evening he called me up on the phone and was able to give me the ages of the eighty children and I proceeded at once to secure complete outfits of clothing. I spent all day Saturday doing this and it was necessary to send the large consignment forward by express in order to make connection with the freight train going North from the Pas on Tuesday morning and if connection are made I hope that this clothing and blankets will be in the hands of the Principal of the school by Thursday. On Friday I wired Agent Gordon at Norway House and found that he had left for the scene of the disaster. He has since returned and informs me that eleven children and one sister had perished, that the school was completely gutted, that the police are attempting to recover the bodies, that the other children were well with the exception of minor frost bites, that the food supplies were safe, that the staff and children were occupying the traders house and that some of the others are back on the reserves and that some of those that are
living at a distance can be sent home as soon as the clothing arrives. He makes some suggestions regarding the fitting up of the old mission buildings in order to carry on the work; however, this is a matter that can be taken up later by correspondence. I believe everything possible has been done to make matters as easy as possible for the sufferers and I will be only too glad to carry out any instructions which you wish to give promptly. I may say that I sent forward a very complete outfit for the children. I understand that two of the sisters who were seriously injured are now in the St. Boniface Hospital and that one of them is very low.

Gordon suggests that Norway House children return home also the Island Lake and Gods Lake children be placed at the Roman Catholic Mission. He also suggests that the Nelson House and La Pas children be sent to Sturgeon Landing school. He also recommends the discharge of several of the older children. He will write a full report to you which will be received in due course. They have been unable to ascertain the cause of the fire.

Yours faithfully,

W. M. Graham.

La tragédie de Cross Lake, Manitoba

46 fillettes et 48 garçons ont échappé aux flammes, mais 5 religieuses sont blessées.

A 150 milles au nord de Le Pas

(Du correspondant de la "Presse" à Le Pas, Manitoba)

TOUT reposait paisiblement mardi soir dernier dans le pensionnat de Cross Lake, situé à 150 milles au nord-est de Le Pas, dans les solitudes glaciales du Manitoba septentrional. À deux heures du matin, le frère Lambert, gardien de nuit, fit sa ronde et ne remarqua rien de suspect. À cette heure, la Rév. Soeur supérieure Marguerite-Marie s'apprêtait à se coucher après une veilleuse des flammes. L'incendie s'était déclaré probablement dans le pensionnat. La lumière de la lampe religieuse se leva, alla réveiller les jeunes filles au début du troisième étage et les religieuses. Les jeunes filles sortirent en bon ordre, les plus grandes portant une ou deux de leurs camarades dans l'espoir de sauver les autres.

Lutte dans les ténèbres

Presque aussitôt les lumières s'éteignirent. Le feu grandit attaquant le moteur fournissant l'électricité. Dans l'obscurité illuminée par des flammes, les religieuses s'efforcèrent de sauver leurs enfants. Soeur Marie-des-Anges, qui accompagnait les enfants à la sortie, s'aperçut qu'il manquait encore un troisième enfant, elle ne savait pas où il était. Elle ne put pas sauver sa vie qu'elle se jetait du troisième étage dans l'incendie ravageant le bâtiment. Le feu avait atteint le troisième étage avant que l'incendie ne soit maîtrisé.

Le feu devint terrible

Les petits garçons racontent que Soeur Marie-des-Anges, se conduisant comme de petits hommes, les aident à enlever les religieuses en criant : "Voulez-vous que nous allions sauver les petites filles ? Il était malheureusement trop tard."

Dévouement des religieuses

L'école était sous la direction du P. Laviolette, qui, après avoir fait des prodiges de valeur ainsi que le P. Laviolette, pour sauver les enfants, chercha à éteindre l'incendie. À ce stade, il voulut se jeter dans les flammes mais trois religieuses du couvent le retinrent. En effet, il y avait encore dans l'institution les frères Charles, Antoine, Lambert, Dumas et deux autres qui étaient prêts à faire la chaîne pour combattre l'incendie, car Taguacoeuf était isolé.

Un sacrifice héroïque

L'héroïque soeur supérieure Marguerite-Marie romanta à trois religieuses qui, après que des élèves manquaient et disparurent à jamais. Soeur Marie-des-Anges fut la dernière à s'apercevoir lorsqu'elle sentit du troisième. Dix enfants indiens périrent avec l'héroïque religieuse.

La liste des morts

Voici leurs noms :

Charlotte Mercier, 11 ans.

La plupart de la sorte succombèrent de ces flammes. Elles ont été consumées par un tourbillon de flammes. Les filles et garçons ont pu se sauver.

S.G. Mgr Charlebois

Un avion Fairchild appartenant à la Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company a été envoyé à Cross Lake pour secourir les victimes de l'incendie. Le pilote est arrivé à Cross Lake à 12 h. 30 p.m. et a effectué plusieurs vols de 45 minutes chacun. Soeur Jeanne de Chantal a été la colonne vertébrale brisée et elle est morte.

Exposés au froid

Tous les rescapés étaient exposés au froid. Trois enfants souffrent d'exposition. Les religieuses ont emprunté des robes aux indiens d'une réserve voisine où les enfants ne sont pas affectés. Soeur Sainte-Agathe, Soeur Sainte-Marie-des-Anges et Soeur Saint-Antoine de Padoue ont échappé aux flammes et prennent soin de ces enfants. Leurs familles ont été obligées de retourner dans leurs familles à 400 milles de là.

Les victimes qui ont péri appartaient aux familles de Cross Lake et de Fort-Roy. L'histoire de la tragédie de Cross Lake est maintenant célèbre cette année son vingtième anniversaire de vie religieuse. Elle est dans Cross Lake depuis l'ouverture de l'école en 1914 et fut supérieure durant ces années. Les ancêtres de Mgr Charlebois ont été les premiers à être sacrifiés.

Perdre considérable

Les pertes ont été estimées à plus de $250,000 ; le pensionnat était une bâtisse en pierre, à trois étages et à six compartiments. Elle est située sur la route de marin, qu'un pan de mur noir et des pans de bois décomposés. Des représentants du département des affaires indiennes, M. Gagnon de l'état et Tweedale de l'armée ont été invités par S.G. Mgr Charlebois dans cette cruche épuisée. Depuis dix ans, la Grande-Bretagne a donné des secours dans les flammes quatre octobre et une fois par an.

Les Indiens de la réserve aident à chercher des secours lorsqu'ils viennent le pensionnat en feu. L'un alla chercher de l'eau à Cross Lake House, un autre se rendit au mile 137 du chemin de fer de la baie d'Hudson, où il télégraphia à Mgr Charlebois.

Voyage de la Soeur supérieure

Soeur Sainte-Marie-Joseph, du couvent de Sainte-Croix-de-la-Salle, Sudbury, a été chargée de la congrégation à laquelle appartenait les religieuses de Cross Lake. Elle est passée à l'endroit où elle a été brûlée. A partir du mile 137, elle voyait une maison à chaque coin de la rue. Les religieuses attendent qu'elles vont reconstruire leur pensionnat.
Cross Lake Tragedy

From "La Presse" Montreal, Thursday Feb. 25th, 1930

At 7:30 a.m., Brother Lambert, who is the night watchman, went around and saw nothing abnormal. At three o'clock, the Rev. Sister Superior Marguerite Marie woke up and saw some smoke and heard the crackling of the flames. The fire had evidently started in the cellar. She instantly got up and woke the young girls in the dormitory on the third floor; the young girls walked out in good order, some of the oldest carrying the youngest.

Almost immediately, the lights went out. The flames having reached the electric wires, in the dark, the sisters sought to save the children. Sister Mary of the Angels was counting the children as they passed out, and found there were several missing; she went up to the third floor against the smoke and flames. She saved her life by jumping from the third story into the snow; several other sisters had to jump from the third story which had almost been reached by the flames.

Sister Superior Marguerite Marie, noticing that some children were missing, went back into the burning building where she finished with ten children. These are the names of the dead:

The retreat of the sisters superior and these ten children was cut off by a rush of flames. 46 young girls and 48 young boys escaped.
Several of the Sisters were hurt during the fire. Sister Jeanne de Chantal had her vertebral column broken. Sister St. Agathe had her ankle broken. Sister Marie des Anges had her feet frozen; they are at present at St. Antoine Hospital at the Pas, under the care of Doctor Stevenson and Dr. Lucien Roch, the latter being newly arrived from Montreal.
All those who were saved had to run away in whatever clothes they had and many suffered from exposure. They were borrowed blankets from the neighbouring Sioux Reserve.
The children who perished belonged to families from Grass Lake and Norway House.
The losses are estimated to be over $25,000.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Just a few lines to let you know that I have not been able to get much further information in connection with the burning of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. I had a telephone conversation with Bishop Charlebois on Thursday last, and told him you were anxious that everything possible should be done to make matters easier for them. I advised him that I had purchased a large supply of clothing, including mocassins, caps, underwear, and suits for boys and girls, which was forwarded on the last instant, and of course has reached its destination long before this. I practised as much economy as I possibly could, but still the account will naturally run into a lot of money. These bills will be forwarded to the Department in due course.

I gathered from the Bishop's conversation that there was nothing more could be done by the Department at present.

The minute word was received at The Pas that the school was burned, the Indian Agent wired here for authority to have a plane go north, which authority of course was given, and he writes to say that the use of the plane was of great benefit and that he considers it was the means of saving the lives of two of the Sisters who were seriously injured.

Dear Sir:

According to your instructions I left Dauphin for The Pas on March the 1st, to make an investigation into the Cross Lake Mission School Fire.

I spent most of the day of March the 2nd, making arrangements for transportation and finally arrangements were made with the Western Canada Airways for a plane to go to Cross Lake on the 3rd of March.

I left The Pas on March the 3rd and proceeded to Cross Lake accompanied by Constable Peach and Dr. Shanks (Coroner).

Before going to Cross Lake on the morning of March 3rd I went to interview Bishop Charlebois at The Pas but found that he had gone to Winnipeg the evening of March the second.

I next interviewed Sister St. Agatha, who is in the St. Antony Hospital at The Pas, suffering from a broken leg and shock. I also interviewed Sister St. Marie de Anges who is suffering from a frozen foot caused from standing on the platform of the fire escape while she directed the children down the fire escape.

The other three sisters who came to The Pas with the above named Sisters are now in Winnipeg at the St. Boniface Hospital where one of them is suffering from a fractured spine.

After talking to Sisters Maire des Anges and Sister St. Agatha, for a short time, I came to the conclusion that to understand their stories properly it would be necessary to see the buildings and the lay-out.

I then returned to the Police Office where I was informed that the plane was ready and we left shortly for Cross Lake.

That evening I made a plan of the building drawing a separate sketch of each floor, and I have written in where all persons were sleeping. I consider the plan of the building with the explanations thereon will give a clearer idea of what occurred than any written explanation could.

As it took considerable time to make the plan of the building, Dr. Shanks and Constable Peach went on with their investigation while I was getting the lay-out of the building.

On the following morning I interviewed the Principal, Father Trudeau, and his assistants, also the sisters that Constable Peach had interviewed the night before. They told me the same story they had told Constable Peach.
I next proceeded to make a thorough inspection of the ruins, accompanied by Dr. Shanks and Constable Pesch.

We found that the building was completely gutted but all evidence pointed to the fire having burned more fiercely in the old part of the building. The white wall plaster in the basement of the new wing and in the basement of the chapel is still adhering to the stone walls, but in the basement of the old building it is completely destroyed. Also the evidence of Father Trudeau points to this fact, and I have set forth his views as to where the fire was burning most fiercely when he saw it, on the plan of the basement.

Brother Antony Bealweg who was doing janitor duty the night of the fire, had left for the railroad before we arrived and we were unable to interview him.

He will arrive in the Pas on March the 8th when Inspector Day will have him interviewed and will forward a copy of his statement to me.

Brother Dumaine, an old man who was sleeping in the big boy's dormitory, had also left before we arrived and we were unable to interview him. He had left for Norway House with Sgt. Saul and the Indian Agent, Mr. Gordon.

In making my inspection of the ruins, I found the heating boilers intact, their furnace doors were still closed, and from our inquiries we could not find anything of a dangerous combustible nature that had been stored in the basement.

The story of the disaster seems to be about as follows:

The sisters and the pupils retired about ten o'clock the night of February 23rd., and Father Trudeau had gone around the basement between eleven and twelve o'clock that night and everything was all right at that time.

Inquiries brought out the fact that Brother Bealweg was supposed to have gone to look after the fires about 2 p.m., and there was no sign of fire then, and just before 3 p.m., the basement and ground floor of the old part of the building was found to be all in flames with flames coming up stairways to the second floor.

When we consider that the old building itself is 110 feet long we get some idea of how rapidly the flames must have spread in less than one hour from the time they could have started, and the theory that the fire started from the electric wiring does not appear feasible to me as the wiring was all open wiring of the knob and tube type. This view is also held by Constable Pesch and Dr. Shanks.

Sister St. Angus who was the first to awaken on the second floor, by the smell of smoke (and as she described it) a roaring noise below her. She was sleeping in a double room with four other sisters and after awakening them she ran across the hall to the Sister Superior's room to awaken her but Sister Superior was already
awake and met her at the door. Sister Superior told Sister Angus to go and awaken the Priest and Brothers for help and that she would go up to the girls dormitory and awaken them. The last Sister Angus saw of Sister Superior was when she entered the stairs leading to the girls dormitory on the third floor. She was never seen to have reached the girls dormitory but is supposed to have died in the stairway.

Sister Angus on Sister Superior's instructions tried to descend to the ground floor at the east end of the building to awaken the Priest and brothers but was unable to do so owing to the smoke and flames coming up the stairway.

As can be seen from the plan of the second storey there is no doorway leading from the second storey of the old building to the second storey of the new wing where the priest and brothers were sleeping. The only way that Sister Angus could get to their rooms was to descend to the ground floor or to ascend to the third floor.

Returning along the hallway she picked up the little four year old child that was sleeping in the Sister Superior's room and being unable to descend either stairways she went through the girl's infirmary to front balcony where she found a heavy comforter which she threw on the ground and endeavored to throw the little child on to it. On account of the darkness and the distance she was unable to do so and the child landed into the snow bank uninjured. Sister Angus was later rescued from this balcony by Father Trudeau and one of the brothers who caught her in a blanket when she jumped from the balcony.

As evidence to show how far the fire advanced when it was discovered and how fast it was spreading, the four sisters who Sister Angus awakened before leaving her room did not have time to get out of their rooms, and into the room known as the sister's living room where the fire escape was, they had to jump out of their rooms' windows and this is where Sister Jeanne de Chantel had her back fractured.

In the boy's and girl's dormitory on the third floor there is a solid wall dividing the boys room from the girl's room. Leading from the girl's dormitory is a stairway at the west end, and the only other means of exit is sliding type fire escape and all the children that were saved came down these fire escapes.

In the boy's dormitory there were two stairways and two fire escapes.

There being only one fire escape in the girl's dormitory and this coupled with the fact that the fire was mostly in the old building at the start, accounts for the heavy fatalities amongst the girl pupils.

Both the sisters in the boys and girls dormitories were awakened by the smoke and they had no means of knowing who awakened
First.

When the sisters awoke they could not get any light in the small boy's and girl's dormitory (see plan). This would indicate that the light circuit was broken in the old building although there was light in the dormitories in the new building for about five minutes after they awakened.

As to the cause of the fire the theory has been advanced that it may have been caused from the electric wiring; I cannot agree with this although I cannot disapprove it. Also Brother Coulter who is general repair man and engineer is not satisfied that this is the cause, he was away the night the fire occurred and of course cannot give his impression of the fire.

From the rapidity that the fire gained headway it would appear to me that the fire may have been caused by spontaneous combustion, as it is quite evident that the fire did not smoulder any great length of time as an electrical fire would do.

However, I can find no direct evidence to support the theory of spontaneous combustion, and doubtless the actual cause of the fire will remain a mystery.

The Coroner, Dr. Shanks, after making his investigation considered an inquest unnecessary, and therefore, issued Coroner's warrant for the burial of the remains.

After making my investigation I could not help coming to the conclusion that if the building had been equipped with proper stair fire escapes, and an adequate means of giving an alarm in case of fire, that could be turned in from any floor in the building, there would have been very little, if any, loss of life.

There is no doubt in my mind that the system of fire escapes used certainly slowed down the work of clearing the building, and as Sister Marie de Anges testified to the fact that she had to stand at the head of the escape and almost force the small girls down as they did not wish to descend the cold iron pipe with only their night clothes, and it was in directing the children at the head of the escape that the Sister froze her feet.

I consider the task that the sisters sleeping in the dormitories accomplished in the dark by getting as many of their charges out as they did little short of miraculous.

I feel that I should make the following recommendations in regard to Mission Schools:

1. That the Dominion Indian Department should have all their Mission Schools inspected by some competent inspector.

2. That all schools be equipped with outside fire escapes (steel, if possible).

3. That adequate means for giving alarm in case of fire be
installed, and be so connected that alarm could be rung from each storey; and in the case of a large school like the Grass Lake School, the alarm should be so arranged that it could be turned in from three or four places on each floor.

With this report I am forwarding you pictures of the Grass Lake School before the fire and pictures of the ruins as they are now standing, also the plans I have made of the building, and Constable Touch's report.

About thirty-five of the pupils and part of the staff are now housed in a six room house and the rest of the pupils are stationed with Indian families around the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

"J. L. Fuller",
Inspector.

Dear Mr. MacNamara:

I wish to thank you for your letter of the 14th instant, with enclosures, concerning the unfortunate fire at the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. I may say, in reply, that the Department realizes its responsibility at these institutions, even when they have been erected by one or other of the churches, and has bent every energy towards minimizing the danger of loss of life by fire. Within the past year or two, thousands of dollars have been expended on fire escapes, extinguishers and water supply systems. Time and again, all principals have been ordered to have regular fire drill.

The Department is satisfied that outside steel fire escapes are necessary and that alarm systems should be provided. These have been, and are being, installed. Further, commencing with last year, only fireproof construction has been specified for new buildings. The Department is constantly renewing its regulations and emphasis is placed on the prevention of fire. I am glad to have your suggestions in this important matter.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mr Scott:

Please accept my thanks for your telegram of February 26th, in connection with the disaster at Cross Lake. When I came back from Cross Lake on February 28th, I at once telephoned full particulars to Mr Wm. M. Graham, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, who was at Winnipeg at the time, and he informed me that he would at once telegraph to you. Mr Graham was good enough to order a supply of the most necessary articles of clothing which should arrive here to-morrow or Tuesday morning. He also authorized us to purchase locally the most necessary kitchen utensils and a few tools which are being sent forward to Cross Lake at the earliest possible moment.

Sister Jeanne de Chantal, who suffered a broken spine, has been sent to Winnipeg and we have received word that she made a fairly good journey considering her condition. There is one sister here suffering from a broken leg and another with frozen feet. of Father Trudeau and the four sisters who remain.

On the evening of February 25th, a messenger arrived from Cross Lake with a letter from Rev. G.H. Trudeau, principal of St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at that point. This letter informed me that the school had been burned that morning, with the loss of several lives, and all clothing and bedding, etc. The letter was written at 5 A.M. and stated that the fire had been discovered at 3 A.M. and that it was practically over.

I immediately sent word to my driver, arranged for an extra dog team and driver, secured rations, etc., also some clothing from the Norway House Residential school, a little from the Hospital and private persons, arranged for these to be taken back by the man who had brought the letter, and sent off messages to the Deputy Superintendent, the Indian Commissioner and Inspector John R. Bunn.

The next morning the Doctor and myself left for Cross Lake, and despite the fact that the roads were very bad, reached Cross Lake that evening, late. We found that Bishop Charlebois had come in by plane during the day, had sent the injured sisters and three others out by plane, had made out a list of clothing required, and was taking this back to the Pas.

The deaths in the fire accounted for the Sister MM Superior of the school, Marguerite Marie, eleven girl pupils and one boy. These were as follows:

- No. 97. Emile Dumas, Nelson House.
- 084. Mary Ann Francois, Nelson House.
- 087. Clemence Cook, Cross Lake.
- 097. Martha Scott, Cross Lake.
- 099. Nancy Flett, Thicket Portage, or Split Lake.
- 0100. Charlotte Mercredi, Thicket Portage.
- 0106. Hyla Moose, Nelson House.
- 0108. Agnes Thomas, Cross Lake.
- 0109. Nora Blacksmith, Cross Lake.
- 0111. Christie Ross, Cross Lake.
- 0112. Hyla Crair, Cross Lake.
- 0114. Annie Crane, Norway House.

The pupils had escaped with only their night clothes. The boys were a little better off than the girls, as they had more time in which to leave the building. None of the children saved were injured, except for one minor burn, and some frost bitten feet. After leaving the building, the children were hurried to the stable, and were later distributed among all available houses near by and on the reserve. The staff, with some of the children took up quarters in the unoccupied house of a trader.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The majority of the pupils from Norway House came home as soon as clothing could be found for them. Two boys, No. 93, from Island Lake, and No. 100, from Gods Lake, who are affected with T.B., are at the hospital. Some twelve boys, belonging to Island and Gods Lakes are at the R.C.Mission at Norway House, where they are being accommodated, fed and taught in classroom at the day school. I recommended that eleven children, from Nelson House, Cumberland House, The Pas, Berens River, and Thicket Portage, be transferred to the school at Sturgeon Landing. I also recommended the discharge of some twelve children, who are nearly of discharge age, or who are not likely to make good at school.

The majority of the Cross Lake children have been in their homes. The school has been issuing rations to the school children, as at this season the food supplies of the Indians are short. As soon as possible a day school will be opened for the Cross Lake children, the majority of whom can sleep at home, but be fed at the school. The food supplies were for the most part outside of the main building, and consequently were not lost in the fire.

These arrangements were made, but of course are subject to the approval of the Department. For the children at Norway House Mission, I would suggest that the grant be paid to the Principal of St. Joseph's school, and he can then settle with the Mission.

I made inquiries as to the cause of the fire, but without satisfactory results. The most probable causes would be as follows:

1. The heating plant. This I consider may be eliminated, as the plant was in the basement of the new wing, and the fire first reached the upstairs somewhere near the opposite end of the main building. The brother also stated that he put the fire in at 2 A.M., and at 3 A.M. the fire was well advanced, when the inmates were awakened by the smoke.

2. The kitchen range. This was on a cement floor, was a good distance from the wall, the smoke pipes had been cleaned about two weeks before, and were in good condition. The sister in charge of the kitchen left the kitchen at about 10 P.M., and stated that the fire in the range was then almost extinct. One of the sisters who was injured in dropping from a window, fell on the snow outside of the kitchen windows, and she stated that there were no flames visible in the kitchen at that time, and the fire was well advanced when she escaped from the window.

3. The gasoline and lighting plant and bake oven. These were in the basement of the chapel, which formed a wing, and which was the last to burn.

4. Cigarette stubs in the recreation room downstairs. Some of the men from the reserve spent the evening in this room, but I understood that the brother who attended the fire at 2 A.M. passed through this room on his way to the stairway which led to the corridor on the first floor, on his way to the chapel. Since he noticed no smoke in this room at 2 A.M., the fire could not have originated here.
5. Electric wiring—This is possible. The wiring was done some fifteen years ago. It was not in conduit, and I am told that in some places the wires passed through wooden beams without porcelain tubing. In such a case the fire would not start in the basement, but between floors and ceilings, or in partitions, and might be well under way before even smoke would be noticeable. The lights were off throughout the building almost immediately the fire was discovered.

6. Incendiarism. While this is possible, I think it very improbable. I can think of no one who would have any cause or desire to burn these buildings.

While it was unfortunate that the water system was out of commission because of freezing up of intake, which was due to very low water this season, I do not think the fire could have been checked even with plenty of water. The fire was so far advanced when discovered that there was little time for all to escape from the building, even though the doors from the dormitories opened directly upon the fire escapes. The stairways were impassible, owing to smoke and flames. Fire extinguishers were in convenient places, but were useless, owing to the advanced progress of the fire. From what I can learn, there was no panic in the dormitories. There was a monitor sleeping in a small room in the corner of each. The doors to the fire escapes were opened, the older children had been taught that each one should be responsible for the safety of a certain smaller child, and the children proceeded in orderly fashion. Those who were burned must have been dazed with sleep and smoke, and in the darkness were not observed. The girls' dormitory was a large room with about fifty beds; the fire escape was at one corner. In the darkness and smoke it would be an easy matter to become confused and lost.

I understand that the Sister Superior who lost her life went back in an effort to get the other girls out. The Principal attempted to reenter the building, but was prevented by the men about him. The sisters who jumped from the windows and the balcony could not get along the corridors to the fire escapes.

The remains recovered by the men, under the direction of the R.C.M. Police, were for the most part merely ashes.

The stone walls are standing, and to the casual observer or the layman appear to be damaged very little. Whether they would be safe for another building, with, of course, some repairs, I am unable to say.

Your obedient servant

REPORT.

Re: Roman Catholic Boarding School, Cross Lake, Man.
— Loss of, by fire.

First Report:
On the evening of the 25th ult., word was received at Norway House that the Roman Catholic Indian Boarding School at Cross Lake had been burned to the ground at 3 a.m. that morning and that one Sister & several children had been burnt to death.
On the following morning I left for Cross Lake by dog team to investigate. Indian Agent Mr. Gordon & Dr. Turpel of the Indian Dept. Also left for Cross Lake the same morning.
Upon arrival at Cross Lake at 8:30 a.m. on the morning of the 27th ult., I found the Cross Lake School as reported, entirely gutted; there being nothing but the stone walls standing. The debris within the walls was still a smouldering mass and nothing could be done there. Inquiries were made from those in charge of the School, resident children and people living at Cross Lake with a view to ascertaining as near as possible the origin of the fire.
It appears that at about 10 minutes to three on the morning of the 25th ult., residents in the school were awakened by the smell of smoke, which was quite dense, which appeared to emanate from the basement in the most central part of the building, the upper portion of which was occupied by the girl boarders. The bell alarm was sounded but by the time the children were properly aroused, exit by stairs was cut off by the flames & smoke & residents had to make their exits by the fire escapes. The rapidity with which the fire made headway, due partly to the north wind, is shown by the fact that scarcely anything was saved, most of the girls & Sisters getting out of the building in their night attire. The priests & boys mostly managed to get their clothes swing to the fact that their section of the building burned later. Under the circumstances considerable presence of mind & coolness must have been displayed by those in charge, the Sisters particularly, in the orderly way in which they herded their charges to the firescapes through the darkness and dense smoke. The Sister Superior, Margaret Marie gave her life in her efforts to make sure that all the children were safe; despite this fact twelve children smile Dumas, Mary Ann Francis, Ilia Moose, Clemence Cook, Martha Scott, Agnes Thomas, Nora Blacksmith, Christie Ross, Ilia Crate, Annie Crane, Nancy Flett and Charlotte Hereredi were burnt to death.
On the afternoon of the 26th ult. with a party of Indians I made a search among the debris for any remains of the victims but we were able to find very few charred bones in places which would account for the thirteen victims; most of the bones having been reduced to ash. These bones were buried at Cross Lake on the 4th inst.
Numerous rumours are rife as to the origin of the fire, these have all been investigated and found to have very little foundation in fact.
With regard to the origin of the fire, the following facts are known. The School had four heating appliances all of which were in different parts of the basement; a high pressure boiler which was not in use, a big heating boiler which was seen to be carrying less than one pound of steam at 2 a.m. on the morning of the fire, a bakery oven which was not in use and a cook stove standing on a cement base, nearest to where the fire originated, which was last attended to at about 9:30 p.m. on the evening before the fire.

and which when left was practically dead.

Brother Antoine made a tour of inspection of the building at midnight and again at 2 a.m. on the morning of the fire; on both occasions passing by where the fire was believed to originate but found nothing amiss.

Father Trudeau, the Priest in charge, informs me that on one or two occasions last summer he had heard mice in the walls of the building and suggests that a short circuit in the wiring between the ceiling of the basement & the main floor by the insulation being gnawed by mice & the bare wire coming in contact with possibly a nail. If ignition of debris between the floor was caused in this manner it would probably smoulder for sometime over a fairly large area before it finally burnt through the floor, obtained air & caused the conflagration; however the electric lights functioned for about two minutes after the fire was first observed & then went out.

In the basement of the school where the fire was believed to originate was a room containing a pool table for the recreation of the young men; this room was always vacated at 9.30 every evening. There is a possibility that a match stick or cigarette butt may have been thrown around the fire but it seems doubtful as the room in question had recently been thoroughly cleaned out & painted and in any case, as mentioned before, this room was passed at 2 a.m. by Brother Antoine on his tour of inspection. From what I have seen of the interior of the building prior to the fire, I should say that it is very doubtful that a fire could be started by the dropping of a match or cigarette end as although no dirt or rubbish was allowed to accumulate to become ignited. The suggestion of the fire being caused in some way by the electric wiring seems most reasonable to me.

On the morning of the 28th. ult. I attended a Council Meeting of the Indians with Mr. Gordon; the people were apparently quite satisfied that no blame could be attached to anyone for the fire but expressed the wish that a permanent night watchman had been employed. Since then however, different ridiculous rumours such as the fire having been conjured by men at distant points, have come to life due I think to a dream of that nature that a local Indian woman had.

Upon my return to Norway House I received the following radiogram from the C.C. Manitoba district:

"Radio me immediately as full details as possible regarding Cross Lake Fire for information of Coroner"

A.B.Allard

A night letter was despatched to the Officer Commanding Manitoba District on the 2nd. inst. giving details of fire.

On the 11th. inst. I received the following telegram from H.J.Martin, Commissioner Manitoba Provincial Police.

"John Flett of Island Lake was at Cross Lake prior to fire endeavouring to take his son away but was refused. The son Arthur Flett desired to go with father, but Principal would not permit this. Indians at Cross Lake believe that John Flett urged his son Arthur Flett to start fire. Arthur Flette was sleeping in the infirmary on second floor on night of fire with Donald Ross. Both boys believed to have been fully dressed at time of fire. John Flett told friend of his who usually slept at the school that he Flette was glad that his friend was going away from the school on February 24th. School burnt down on night of 24th. Arthur Flett has stated since the fire that he was glad the school burned as he would now be able to go home. Boys Arthur Flett & Donald Ross now at Norway House. John Flett believed to be there also. Please carefully interview these persons and advise as to interrogation of children."
and other Indians at Cross Lake. This forwarded direct to you by permission your Officer Commanding,

H.J.Martin, Commissioner Man. P.Police

On the 12th. inst., I interviewed Donald Ross and Arthur Flett, both of whom are in Norway House hospital with tuberculosis. On being questioned, Arthur Flett informed me that while at Cross Lake school, for some weeks past he has been confined to his bed in the infirmary with tuberculosis. The day before the fire he was out of his bed once at 11 p.m. to go to the lavatory, which was right in the infirmary. On the early morning of the 25th. ult., he was awakened by the smoke and had just time enough to get a blanket, throw it around him and escape down the fire escape, where he stood until Father Trudeau obtained some clothes for him.

While questioning this boy, Nurse Oliver informed me that he had received a letter from his father, John Flett at Island Lake, that morning. I obtained this letter which was in Cree hieroglyphics and had same transcribed, the following being the transcription:

Dear Son, To let you know I got home safe again. It took me seven days. Your sister & sister-in-law and one man were pretty sick. They were all sick the same time, but when I got here they were getting better. They are doing well every day getting strong, and none of your brothers are home yet. Today is a day later, they said they would be home. Now my son we were all sorry to hear of the school being burnt down. I just got home when I heard of the school to burn. Yes all the people were sorry but I cried myself for I felt so bad about it. I think that was very strange for the school looked so nice everything in around. That is why I think very bad about it and to be gone so soon. That is all my son. We all send kisses to you all. John Flett.

Upon being questioned, Donald Ross informed me that he had been awakened by the smoke on the morning of the 25th. but had time to grab his clothes, escape by the fire escape & dress out skin. Neither of these boys had been out of the infirmary on the day preceding the fire. I have been able to confirm these statement from eye-witnesses at Cross lake. Father Trudeau informs me that prior to the fire John Flett came to Cross Lake to visit his son, which the natives frequently do, coming often from great distances. Arthur Flett asked his father to take him home with him. John Flett mentioned his son's request to Father Trudeau who told him that he considered such action very inadvisable owing to the temperature that Arthur had been running, to which John Flett quite agreed and apparently went away quite satisfied.

I have been unable to see John Flett who is at Island Lake but I am quite satisfied, knowing both the man & the son, that there is absolutely no truth in the suggestion that either one of them deliberately caused the fire. Arthur Flett was one of the best boys in the school & Donald Ross bears a good reputation.

I have questioned the Indians around Cross Lake but have been unable to find anyone who heard Arthur Ross state that he was glad the school burnt down.

On making further enquiries yesterday I received information from one May MacIvor to the same effect as that contained in the radiogram from Commissioner Martin, and am of the opinion that the MacIvor family are the source of the rumour. Upon questioning the MacIvors however I was unable to obtain any further satisfaction than that they had heard this & that etc. but could not say from whence. Personally I think it
Is the out-cropping of a few facts and a very vivid imagination on the part of the Indians as the facts of the case contradict their rumour.

Sgt.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF WM. GORDON, INDIAN AGENT, NORWAY HOUSE, FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1930, ON THE NORWAY HOUSE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This is a day school carried on by the staff of the St. Joseph's Boarding School since the school was burned last February, or at least since it was possible to get the outhouse, a storehouse, in condition to carry on. This room is used as a classroom on week days and a chapel on Sundays. The furniture is home made, and while the benches are fairly comfortable, there are no desks, which makes seat work difficult. I found, however, neat writing and good drawing. Written number work was fairly good also. Reading was very good, and the children spoke clearly and with good voice, and very naturally. Considerable of the work is done orally, and in concert, which of course encourages the more bright children, and has doubtful value for the more plodding children. I found, however, that the children appear to understand very well the work being covered by them, and are quick and prompt with their answers. Spelling was good and oral number work excellent.

The children are supplied with a lunch at noon, and with a good substantial meal on dismissal of the classes. This is of great value to the children, especially in this year of scarcity of fur and the wherewithal to purchase flour and other store goods.
Sir,

I understand that a recent amendment has been made to Section 774 of the Criminal Code, whereby the authority of a Police Magistrate for the Province of Manitoba, has been extended to be on a par with those of Ontario for certain offences. If this be true, then I, as a Police Magistrate, holding a Commission as P.M. for Manitoba, have authority, with the consent of the accused, to hear and decide these cases, so long as a charge of manslaughter is not entered. This would simplify matters greatly, as I have no doubt the boys would consent to be tried by me, and would probably plead "Guilty".

Should the boys be sent up for trial, I would not be permitted at the Preliminary hearing, to ask them to plead to the charge, evidence would have to be secured, and at their trial, should they, on lawyer's advice, plead "Not Guilty", a great deal of time and expense would be necessary in order to produce sufficient evidence to secure a conviction.

I may say that I have no desire to take the responsibility of settling so grave cases, and I would not wish to do anything which would look like a "Hole in the corner" business, nor like "Railroading" the boys into prison, but on the other hand, if I have the authority to hear the cases, if the boys are willing to abide by my judgment, and if thus the time and expense which would otherwise be necessary in securing and presenting evidence before a higher court can be saved, I would not wish to be recreant to the trust imposed upon me.

May I ask for a very early reply, as any delay will carry us into the freeze-up. A wire to Inspector Bunn, to be forwarded, might be the quickest means of reply.

Your obedient servant

Wm. Gordon,
Indian Agent.
Sir,

I have to report that on Saturday last, Sept. 12th Sergt. D.C. Saul, officer in charge of the R.C.M.P. Police Detachment at Norway House, brought to my office a young man, George Paynter, who had confessed that he, in company with another boy, Nelson Hughes, had set fire to St. Joseph's Residential School at Cross Lake on the morning of February 25th, 1930.

Informations were laid against both of these boys on a charge of Arson, and George Paynter was remanded in custody for seven days, when he will again be remanded, while a warrant was issued for the arrest of Nelson Hughes who is reported at Nelson House, and Sergt. Saul left for Nelson House Sunday morning to bring Hughes in.

George Paynter (George Penders) was, at the time of the fire, pupil No. 62, of St. Joseph's Residential school, and was in his 17th year. He had been in school 10 years, and had reached Grade 6. He is said Treaty with No. 320, Norway House Band, as male dependent of the Chief, Wm. Thomas Towers. His parents are both dead. A few weeks before the fire he had run away from school, but was taken back, and punished. Some of the boys are said to have heard him making threats against the school, and one boy, Roderick McKay, ex-pupil No. 75 of St. Joseph's school, discharged Aug. 1929, but who was at the school working up to a couple of days before the fire, is said to have told at The Pas and at Cumberland House that the boy Paynter had told him (McKay) just before he left Cross Lake that he (Paynter) and another had made an attempt to set fire to the school but that they were nearly caught, but that they would do it yet. It was from these alleged statements of McKay's that the word came through Bishop Charlebois and Father Trudeau, Principal of St. Joseph's, which led to the questioning of the boy Paynter.

The second boy, Nelson Hughes, was about 17 years of age, in his graduation year, at the time of the fire. He is non-treaty, as his father was non-treaty, but since his mother was Treaty, and his father dead, he was admitted as a pupil of St. Joseph's school, in Sept. 1919. Since leaving school he has been convicted of theft and secured a short sentence. He has recently married at Nelson House.

HALF-BREED ARRESTED IN NORTH FOR BURNING OF CROSS LAKE SCHOOL

After Searching 19 Months, Sergeant Saul, R.C.M.P., Captures George Paynter

Sister Superior and Nine Pupils Perished in Cold Winter Night's Fire in February, 1930

Arrested Man is Said to Have Confessed to Crime, and Implicated Older Indian Friend

(Special Dispatch to the Free Press)

By Pat Blair, Special Correspondent

D. G. Saul, R.C.M.P., of Norway House, has one man under arrest and is hot on the trail of another who is connected with the burning, February 25, 1930, of the Indian school at Cross Lake when the Sister Superior and nine pupils perished.

With George Paynter, 22-year-old half-breed Indian in custody, Sergeant Saul passed through Thicket Portage Saturday in an canoe packed full of firewood and bound for Nelson House on the trail of another Indian, also wanted in connection with the fire.

Paynter is said to have confessed to aiding his older Indian friend in setting fire to the school on the cold winter night in February, 1930.

Known in the north country as one of the most daring of the Indians ever to patrol the lonely wastes of the Arctic, Paynter was arrested by Sergeant Saul since the night of the holocaust has been on the run incessantly. His investigation of 10 months was only recently rewarded with the arrest of the culprit.

Adding to the picturesque history of the case is the fact that he returned to headquarters at Norway House after a journey of more than 600 miles during the man hunt.

Panicking Indian Runners—The two young Indians, victims of the holocaust here a couple of days later, the school building at Cross Lake, 125 northwest of here, was in smouldering ruins.

It was during the early hours of the cold morning that flames swept through the structure.

Only the heroism of Sister Superior kept the fire from spreading, and she perished with her protégés as she was leading a group of Indian pupils, all between the ages of six and 14, in a corridor on the top story of the institution.

The Indian school, to which a pledge of $20,000 had been raised prior to the fire, was valued at $200,000.
Winnipeg, 29th September, 1931.

Horway House, Sept. 29th, 1931.

Dear Mr Bunn:

Received the message from Mr. Scott o.k. today at noon. Am very glad to be relieved of the responsibility of hearing and deciding these cases. I wrote to the Attorney General the same mail as I wrote to the Department (16th ?), but his reply is doubtless coming by mail. My letter to the Attorney General was for information re my jurisdiction in these cases. I am writing him again for instructions, as per advice in the message received today. Unless these instructions are in the letter which will be a reply to my former letter, they will probably have to be broadcast by radio, unless they can be sent in by plane.

Sergt. Saul, (R.C.M.P.) is away to Nelson House after the fellow Nelson Hughes. He may have to go to Indian Lake to get him. Has a warrant for his arrest. I have remanded from week to week the chap Paynter until the return of the Sergeant. I hope the instructions of the Attorney General arrive on the first boat, which may be in about Friday the 2nd October, sometime before you will receive this. This is a very bad time for anything like this to have to be settled, owing to the bad mail service for the past and for the next few weeks.

There has always been a suspicion that the fire originated in this way, or something similar, but suspicion is something not to be discussed, or even mentioned, if you wish the truth to come out. It is pretty hard to believe that the Indian boys would be guilty of such conduct. Of course the benefits of education are not sought after by boys of this stamp, and the rigorous discipline of the school is not congenial, even if salutary. Some changes in the brothers on the staff had been made just the last day, and the brother most respected by the boys was away.

As Police Magistrate for the Province of Manitoba, and the only one in this district, it may be necessary for me to hold the preliminary hearing. In any case I will await the instructions of the Attorney General.

Missionary at Cross Lake, called at this Detachment & informed me that he had received a letter from Bishop Charlebois in which the Bishop stated that while at Cumberland House this summer, an Indian had informed him that another Indian, Roderick McKay had said that he believed one George Paynter, Indian, had set fire to the school, as while McKay was at the school, Bender came to him and said "To-night I am going to set fire to the school, get ready to escape, take off the screen window so you can get out by the window"; a little later Bender came back to McKay's room and said "I did not succeed, I almost got caught by the Brother, I will try again later when you wont be here so you wont be exposed".

Since this fire took place on February 25th, 1920, there have been many rumours started as to the origin of the fire, all of which have been investigated without result and I was rather sceptical as to the truth in this.

On Sept. 12th, accompanied by Indian John Bradburn, I left for Cross Lake to interrogate some of the older boys with regard to this report. Roderick McKay was away from Cross Lake & it was not known exactly where he was.

Shortly after we had boiled our first kettle, I came to a camp of Indians where George Paynter was staying. I stepped to question this boy as to his activities on the night of the fire. At first he was very noncommittal and I could get no satisfactory replies from him. I told him of what Roderick McKay had stated and at first he denied the truth of this, later he admitted that he had tried to burn the school unsuccessfully two or three nights before the fire took place; shortly after he broke down and admitted the whole thing, giving me the following statement:

George Paynter's statement:
"I was at the school on the night of the fire at Cross Lake. I was sleeping in the big boys dormitory. Nelson Hughes told me about the fire. I just put my pants & coat & sweater on and socks. I remember telling Roderick McKay I was going to set fire to the school. I tried to set fire to the school but I couldn't, I went down to the basement for this purpose, then the Brother came, Brother Antoine, I got frightened and came up again. Nelson Hughes was with me, he was going to help me. Two nights after this the school took fire. Nelson Hughes & I set fire to the school when it burnt. About 3 o'clock on the morning of the 25th, February, Nelson Hughes got up & woke me up. I put on my pants. I did not want to go but Nelson forced me to go. I did not go down right away, he went first. Then he came up again & told me there was nobody there. I went after with Nelson & got gasoline from the barrel in the engine room. I sprinkled it on the wood & on the floor of the pool room. Then I set a match to it. I then went back to bed. Nelson went into the play-room. About 10 minutes after he came back to bed. About 10 or 15 minutes later the alarm was given & there was lots of smoke. The people were getting out of the school by this time. I did this because Nelson forced me to it."

(Sgd.) George Paynter
Upon receiving this information, I arrested Paynter and escorted him back to Norway House. Upon arrival there, about 6 p.m., I laid information before Wm. Gordon P.M. against Paynter under Section 511 C.C. of C., I also laid information against Nelson Hughes under the same section & obtained warrant to apprehend this man. Paynter appeared before Mr. Gordon the same evening and at my request the case was remanded from week to week until I could return with Hughes. Paynter was then escorted to the Detachment & left in the custody of S/Cst. Robinson until my return. S/Cst. Robinson was instructed to bring back the accused Paynter before Mr. Gordon for further remands until I should return.

On the morning of the 13th Sept. I left for Nelson House via Thicket Portage, to arrest Nelson Hughes. Indian John Bradburn was discharged at Cross Lake and Indians James Ross & Henry Hamilton employed as guides.

Upon arriving at Thicket Portage I telephoned through to the telegraph operator at Wabowden the following telegram to the Officer Commanding Winnipeg:

"The Brown Lake fire 1930 stop Have Indian George Paynter under arrest Norway House for burning school and have obtained full confession stop Hold warrant to apprehend Nelson Hughes half-breed accomplice stop Expect to execute same in couple of days stop Will submit full reports on return Norway House about 27th inst. (Sgd.) Sgt.Saul

Owing to very bad weather, engine trouble & difficulty in finding the route I did not arrive Nelson House until the evening of the 24th! Upon arriving at Nelson House I learnt that Hughes had gone with his wife & parents-in-law to Swan Lake, about 100 miles N.W. of Nelson House. I therefore left one of my men with Mr. Nutty, trader, and borrowed an Indian who knew the route to Swan Lake from him. We arrived at Swan Lake on the morning of the 27th. & I arrested Hughes, warning him in the prescribed form.

The same day we left on our return journey. While at Nelson House on our return, Hughes made the following statement to me:

Nelson Hughes statement:
On the night of the fire at Cross Lake, at about 3 o'clock in the morning, when George Paynter went downstairs, I went after him. George woke me up before he went down. He said "Get up & come downstairs" The evening before the fire took place George Paynter had been talking to me and told me that he was going to wake me up that night that he was going to do something, that he was going to set fire to the school. I said "I can't tell you yet" When George woke me up I knew what he was going to do. I did not tell anyone that George was going to burn the school. George told me also that he had tried to burn the school two or three nights before. I was not with him when he tried the first time. When I got up & followed George I had on just my night clothes, he had his pants & stockings on. I went as far as the refectory. George told me to stand there & watch to see that nobody came until he had started the fire. As soon as George got to the engine room I went back to bed. About five minutes later George came back. He told me that he had started the fire. About 10 or 15 minutes later the room became full of smoke & we all got up and got out of the building. The reason that I agreed to help George burn the school was that I was always mad at the Priest because he was always punishing me. I make this true statement of my own free will. (Sgd.) Nelson Hughes

Witness:- Sgt.D.C.Saul, W.E.W.Nutty.

On passing through Thicket Portage on my return journey, I sent the following telegram through to Wabowden to be despatched:

My wire 18th inst., stop Return to Detachment unavoidably delayed eight days stop Hughes under arrest has admitted guilt. (Sgd.) Sgt. Saul

On passing through Cross Lake on my return journey, I questioned some of the boys who had been in the dormitory with accused at the time of the fire, and learned that most of these boys had known all the time who had started the fire, but owing to the deaths incurred had been too frightened to breathe a word about it until it had come out. I left word with Indian boys, George Miller, Baptiste Crate & Edward McKay to come to Norway House to give evidence in this case. Upon their arrival there I found that Edward McKay's knowledge or the case was very slight so he was allowed to return to his home.

I arrived at Norway House with prisoner Hughes on the evening of the 5th inst.

On the morning of the 6th, Hughes appeared before Mr. Gordon P.M. & the case was remanded until the 10th inst.

The following message was received from SS Officer Commanding Winnipeg, through CKY broadcasting station:—
Bring Paynter & Hughes to Winnipeg on next boat leaving Selkirk Oct. 6th. (Sgd.) Supt. Field

On 10th inst. Paynter & Hughes were again brought before Mr. Gordon & there cases were again remanded until 3 p.m. of the 17th inst., it being expected that by this time they could be in Winnipeg.

Paynter is a Treaty Indian and was born sometime during the year 1913. He has borne a bad reputation since he was quite small but has been an exemplary prisoner since he has been in custody.

Hughes is a half-breed, married, he was born in October 1911. He bears a bad reputation and served a short term of imprisonment in 1930 for theft. He has behaved himself well since being in custody.

George Paynter, 20-year-old Indian youth, was sentenced to life imprisonment in the penitentiary in provincial police court today, when he pleaded guilty to setting fire to the Cross Lake convent Feb. 25, 1930, causing the loss of 14 lives. He admitted that he had been actuated by a spirit of revenge.

Paynter was charged with arson when he appeared before Magistrate R. M. Smith. Speaking through Norman Gaudin, of Norway House, interpreter of the Cree language, to hold his story.

Made Two Attempts

Paynter had been punished for infraction of the rules of the convent when he was an inmate. Nursing a grudge against his teachers he made two unsuccessful attempts to burn the building. Each time he was detected by a priest and returned to the dormitory.

Undeterred by his failures, but more modestly, Paynter planned a third time to start a fire. He warned one of his friends in the boys' dormitory to remove the dorm window to facilitate escape after the fire started.

That night he obtained a quantity of gasoline from the engine-room and sprinkled it upon the lower floor. He touched it and within a few minutes the building was a roaring furnace.

Twenty Boys Zero

The occupants of the boys' dormitory had been warned, escaped, but 12 girl pupils, one boy who was recovering from tuberculosis, and two of the teaching sisters were burned to death.

The temperature was 20 degrees below zero and the survivors suffered from cold and exposure during the night.

During the time on the bench Magistrate Nobbs has never before imposed a fine sentence. Nelson Hughes, alleged to be implicated with Paynter, appeared today and pleaded not guilty to the crime. He was remanded until Tuesday, Nov. 3.

On the 18th inst., I arrived at Winnipeg via S.S. Keenora with prisoner George Paynter & Nelson Hughes & immediately reported at "D" Div. Headquarters. Upon arrival there I received instructions to hand these two prisoners over to the Provincial Gaol, which was done, receipt being obtained.

On the 20th inst., the case was brought before Judge R.A.Hamilton of the Juvenile Court, Paynter having been a juvenile at the time the crime was committed. W.E.McLean, legal assistant of the Attorney General, Province of Manitoba, acting for the prosecution, the case was referred back to the ordinary courts by Judge Hamilton.

On the 20th inst., accused appeared before Magistrate R.M.Noble of the Provincial Police Court Winnipeg and was remanded until the 27th inst.

During the week intervening, the accused was interviewed at the Provincial Gaol by myself & the agent of the Attorney General, Mr.McLean, with a view to ascertaining whether he would elect to be tried summarily or otherwise. The very serious nature of the crime was fully explained to the accused also the term of imprisonment that he was liable to. Despite this, accused insisted that he wished to be tried summarily and wished to plead guilty.

On the 25th inst., the Attorney General's Dept. wired to the Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, enquiring whether the latter proposed to appoint counsel for the accused and received the reply that they only appointed counsel in charges of murder.

On the 27th inst., accused appeared before R.M.Noble P.M. in the Provincial Police Court Winnipeg.

Upon being asked to elect, through Cree interpreter M.Gaudin, accused stated that he wished to be tried summarily and pleaded guilty to the charge of arson.

Mr.McLean drew to the attention of the court the fact that thirteen lives had been lost in the fire, that accused had attempted to burn the building three nights previously and also that he was aware of the seriousness of his crime in view of the fact that he had stated to another prisoner at Norway House that he would probably be hanged.

Police Magistrate Noble sentenced the accused to the maximum penalty, life imprisonment in Stony Mountain Penitentiary.

Accused is a Treaty Indian and was born in the Norway House District.

Case Concluded.

The Honourable Maurice Dupre, K.C., L.L.D., P.C.,
Solicitor-General for Canada,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am writing for parole on behalf of Nelson Hughes who was convicted by a jury at Winnipeg in November, 1931 on a charge of Conspiracy in connection with the burning down of a school the property of the Dominion of Canada located at Cross Lake in Northern Manitoba.

This boy was tried before His Lordship Mr. Justice Robson and a jury on charges of Arson and Conspiracy but the jury found him not guilty on the former charge.

In so far as his trial in Winnipeg is concerned I have no complaint whatsoever. The presiding Judge was fair, the witnesses told the truth, and the jury gave the evidence great consideration before reaching the verdict.

I do submit that certain principles of government and control of the Indians and half-breeds are inter-mixed with this case.

I submit that a full and complete investigation should be made as to the reason why two school boys should set a school on fire.

From the evidence disclosed every boy in that school had a hatred of the officers in charge there. Such a condition is not right, nor is it moral in an Indian School.

The Indian boy and the half-breed boy attending school in this Province has distilled in him a sense of loyalty which was certainly lacking in the boys that were brought down to Winnipeg in connection with this trial.

I submit that the officers in charge of the school at Cross Lake had failed in their duty with the result that Hughes must suffer.

If this country of ours owes any duty to the Indian and half-breed in the far North, then I submit that someone has failed to discharge that duty in so far as Nelson Hughes was concerned.

I told the jury in my address and I think that Mr. Justice Robson will confirm my statement, that in the case of Hughes I tried to bring out all the evidence both for and against the accused so that we could get at the root of the trouble if such was possible. I did make certain progress in this regard but if the trial had have been held in the North Country closer to Cross Lake, then perhaps the Court and jury would have agreed with my contention that the State had failed in its duty to the Indian and half-breed of the North Country.

I submit that this is a matter which should have the careful consideration of your Department and that Hughes is entitled to consideration.

If the matter could be referred to the Indian Department I would be glad to express them additional facts in connection with this case.

Yours sincerely,

John L. Ross

Sir,

The Department has recently received a letter from Rev. G. E. Trudeau, O.M.I., in connection with the expenditures that have been incurred at Cross Lake since the school was destroyed by fire. As you are, no doubt, aware, the school authorities are requesting an additional amount and, in this connection, I might refer you to official letter of June 27th, 1930.

While the school authorities have submitted, from time to time, statements in connection with the expenditure that has been incurred up to March 31st, last, no receipts or other papers have yet been forwarded. These are necessary to meet the requirements of the Auditor General and I am writing Father Trudeau, requesting him to prepare a detailed statement of expenditures up to March 31st, both for the pupils attending the day school and the pupils who have been kept in residence. To this statement should be attached receipted accounts or cancelled cheques in order that the Department may have full details in connection with the expenditure incurred. When this is received, consideration will be given to what balance can be allowed. I would appreciate your giving Father Trudeau any assistance you can in the preparation of this.

From April 1st, 1932, the following arrangements will be in effect:

(1) A salary at the rate of $95 a teaching month will be allowed for the teacher of the day school now being conducted at Cross Lake and which is attended by, approximately, 30 pupils.

(2) A grant at the rate of $175 per capita will be allowed for approximately 12 pupils - some of whom are in residence at Cross Lake and the others at Norway House. Separate returns should be forwarded for the children attending the day school and those in residence. These returns, of course, should be forwarded through your office and certified by you. Reverend Father Trudeau is being so advised.

(3) The Department will only be able to allow a grant for a midday meal supplied to the pupils attending the day school. This will mean that the Department can allow from the Appropriation for Indian Education a grant towards the cost of only one meal a day. Please let me have a recommendation from you, stating what monthly amount you consider would be reasonable in this regard. I may say that, at other Indian schools where a midday meal is served, it is usual to supply a hot soup or cocoa and biscuit. In other words, the meal should not be elaborate, as our funds for this purpose are quite limited. As soon as we have your recommendation in this regard, the Department will advise you the exact amount that will be allowed.

Cher Monsieur,

Dernièrement j'ai reçu de la part des Indiens de la Réserve de Cross-Lake, une copie d'une pétition qui vous a été adressée. L'objet de cette pétition est de solliciter la reconstruction de l'Ecole pensionnat qui a été détruite par le feu dans la dite Réserve il y a deux ans.

Dear Sir:

I have received lately, from the Indians of the reserve of Cross-Lake, a copy of the petition which was addressed to you. The object of that petition is to solicit the reconstruction of the boarding school which was destroyed by fire on the said reserve about two years ago.

I can only manifest my strong approval to their request; because it is absolutely just. The 91 signees only represent the Catholics of Cross-Lake. There are, furthermore, the Catholics of Nelson-House, of God's-Lake, of Island-Lake and of Norway-House who wish just as ardently that the said school be rebuilt. They represent a very large district. There is no doubt, that a boarding school is urgent in that section of the country. The one which was destroyed must be rebuilt as soon as possible.

We hope that the Department will not lose sight of this obligation. As soon as the financial situation will permit, we hope that it will be taken into consideration.

I beg you to receive my most sincere regards.

O. Charlebois, O. M. I.,
Vic. Apost. of Keewatin.
