Sir:

Referring to your letter No.123-1-1, dated January 18th last, with regard to accepting grant earning pupils at the Roman Catholic Mission at Norway House,- I have taken the measurements of the dormitories and looked over the accommodations in the building.

There are three sleeping rooms in the main building, and one in the Priests House which may be used for the children. Measurements are as follows:

Little girls, 9' x 15' x 9' high; less monitors room.
Big girls, 32' x 16' x 9' high.
Little boys, 24' x 16' x 9' high.
Monitor's rooms are approximately 6'x8'x9'.

Big boys, 18' x 20' x 7' high.

The only provision for ventilation is by doors and windows. The building is steam heated, and has running water and electric lighting.

The cubical air space in the dormitories would total approximately 10,500 cubic feet.

The dining rooms are of good size, and the classroom has accommodation for 35 pupils.

If the Boarding School at Cross Lake is not likely to be rebuilt for some time, then the Roman Catholic Indians deserve some consideration with regard to Boarding School accommodation for their children. For this reason I would recommend that a per capita grant be provided for the number of children that may be allowed, according to dormitory space; with the understanding that Boarding School regulations must be strictly adhered to, particularly with regard to other boarders in the institution, and the health and religion of the children on admission. Such an arrangement would give the Department more direct supervision in these respects, than we have at the present time.

Your obedient servant

Wm Gordon,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of yours of January 29th Re expenditure incurred by us for the maintenance of the children at the Cross-Lake School from the date of the fire on February 25th, 1930 to March 31st, 1932.

First I wish to draw your attention on this point that the statements forwarded to the Department last September by Late Bishop Charlebois were covering only the expenditures made for the children attending day school. So these statements do not include expenses made for the boarders kept from the time of the fire, some at Cross-Lake and some at Norway-House. For these children the regular Quarterly Returns were regularly forwarded for which no per Capita Grant was received until June Quarter 1932.

As stated in a letter received from the Department No I23-I-3 dated June 27th, 1930 it was understood that the Department would pay the regular Per Capita Grant for the boarders kept at Cross-Lake and Norway-House, and then, special grant would be given for children attending day school, to whom two meals and clothes were given, on receipt of detailed statement showing the expenditure incurred for same.

Consequently having received $8000 we admit that this sum exceeds the expenses made for the children attending day school and being fed and clothed but the balance left $596.26 is far from being sufficient to cover the Grant per Capita which has been left unpaid from April 1st, 1930 to March 31st 1932.

Hoping this will be satisfactory, I remain,

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 21st instant, enclosing a petition from the Indians of Cross Lake, requesting that a residential school be erected, to replace the building destroyed by fire in 1930.

In reply I have to say that the Department will have no funds to consider the re-establishment of the Cross Lake Residential School and the erection of a suitable building. Your Lordship will understand that, during the past four years, there have been no funds available for the replacement or repairing of our present school establishment. There are, therefore, many demands, and it will likely require a period of two or three years before sufficient funds can be available to place our present school establishment in an efficient state. I am quite unable to say, at present, when Parliament would be able to provide the funds required for the erection of a new residential school building at Cross Lake and the furnishings and per capita grant for same. However, the need at this point will be kept in mind. It will be necessary, therefore, to carry on under the present arrangements for school facilities for the Indian children of the Cross Lake Band.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Following our conversation of this morning I would like to express to you my deep satisfaction and appreciation of your plan concerning the vocational training of Indian children. I think you have struck the right note. Education must be a development and not a distortion of natural talents and tendencies in children.

In the same line of thought I would like to supplement my remarks of this morning by saying that my opinion is that we should have at Cross Lake an institution which would be primarily a Day School but with accommodation for orphans, for destitute children and of those of the neighboring reserves, and which school adapted for about 65 children would suffice. This would be a center from which Indian crafts, agriculture and other useful trades could be taught. Since last year, in fact, agriculture has been specially organized for our former pupils by our Missionaries at Cross Lake.

What seems to be of immediate importance is the examination of the site and the bringing in of some of the material such as sand, etc.... Hoping that we may be favoured with a suitable solution to our problem through your kindness and influence.

I beg to remain yours sincerely,

"Martin Lajeunesse" O.M.I.

The Director,

In response to your request, I am submitting herewith certain comments and recommendations with respect to the rebuilding of the Cross Lake Residential School.

The Cross Lake Indian Residential School (R.C.) was destroyed by fire on February 25, 1930. At that time the school had an enrolment of 110 pupils with a per capita allowance from the Department of $175. The records indicate that, following the destruction of this school, an arrangement was made with the church authorities whereby they were allowed a per capita grant of $175 for 40 pupils. Of these pupils 10 are at Cross Lake and 30 are receiving instruction in a church-owned building at Norway House. In addition to this, a salary of $950 per annum has been allowed for a day school teacher at Cross Lake. The day school has an enrolment of 36 pupils.

I have discussed the problem confronting the church authorities and the Department at Cross Lake very fully with Bishop Lajeunesse. His Lordship interviewed me at my office a few months ago.

The last census report indicates that there are 635 Indians in the Cross Lake Band and, of these, 145 are of school age. Of the total population at Cross Lake approximately 50% (320) are recognized as adherents of the United Church and 315 are listed as Catholics. However, in considering the erection of a new school at this reserve, we must be careful to keep in mind the fact that there are 791 Indians at Norway House, of whom 180 are Catholics. If it is decided to establish a residential school...
school, accommodation would have to be provided for the orphan children from at least two and probably three reserves and, in addition to this, accommodation for certain local pupils for whom the parents may be unable to make provision.

I suggested to Bishop Lajeunesse that we should proceed with the erection of an improved day school just as soon as the money at our disposal would enable us to do so. I had in mind a school building consisting of two distinct and separate units - the first unit to consist of three or four classrooms with full basement accommodation and equipped to provide vocational instruction - net making, carpentry work, preserving of fruit, sewing, etc., and a second unit sufficiently removed from the first to escape fire hazards. In this second unit provision should be made for dormitory accommodation for approximately 50 pupils with living quarters for the members of the teaching staff. In this building, also, should be installed a furnace of sufficient capacity to provide heat for both buildings. The dining room facilities should be spacious enough to provide accommodation, not only for the resident pupils, but, in addition, accommodation for the day school pupils, who could be provided with a noonday lunch and by this provision encouraged to be regular in attendance at school.

I am not sufficiently familiar with the district to make any comment upon its agricultural possibilities. If the land is at all suitable for agricultural purposes, a small farm should be established at the school. It would be well, also, to canvass the possibilities of promoting a fur industry in the district. The care of mink, for example, would provide worth-while and profitable instruction for the pupils.

May I suggest, before a final decision is reached with respect to the rebuilding of this school,
that a thorough investigation of the district be made by Inspector Hamilton, who might be accompanied by a capable builder or contractor. Inspector Hamilton should be asked to report upon:

1. The selection of a centrally located and suitable site, close to an adequate water supply;
2. The extent to which it might be profitable to utilize the building materials, stones, etc., that are available at the old site;
3. The suitability of the district for farming operations and development of wild life;
4. The approximate cost of a building such as I have roughly suggested.

You are aware that it is our intention to ask for a substantial appropriation this year with the object of promoting a health programme, designed to arrest and ultimately eradicate the ravages of T.B. amongst the members of our Indian population. We have abundant evidence at our disposal to indicate that Indian reserves have become centres of infection and are actually a menace, not only to the residents of the reserves, but to the White population as well. I feel confident we shall have the active cooperation of the church authorities in working out this programme. It is too much, however, to expect that we shall be able to provide the funds necessary for this programme on the one hand and continue to multiply the number of Indian residential schools on the other. I have no reason to think that the churches will expect us to proceed with a pretentious building programme until adequate provision has been made for the members of our Indian population now suffering from tuberculosis. I remind you of this for the reason
the reason that in my judgment the cost of erecting a school at Cross Lake should be kept down to the lowest possible figure. I have given it special consideration for the simple reason that the proposal does not represent a request for a new school but is simply a replacement, the claims for which have been sympathetically considered since the school was destroyed by fire 7 years ago but action on which has been deferred owing to the limited financial resources available for such projects.

Sir,

A short time ago, I had occasion to escort a mental patient from this agency, to the Selkirk Mental Hospital, and while in Winnipeg, on 1st March, I called on Mr Inspector A.G. Hamilton at his office, and was fortunate enough, at the same time, to meet Mr M. Christianson, the General Superintendent of Agencies. We discussed many matters concerning the Indian work in general, but one thing was discussed at some length, namely, Indian Education, particularly as it applies to the Indians of this agency, and the northern districts generally.

At the conclusion of our talk, Mr Christianson asked me to write to you, and give you the views I held concerning this particular phase of the Indian work.

First of all, the problem of educating the children of the Indians who live in this north country, is entirely different from the problem of educating those who live outside on the prairies. The northern Indian has a distinctly different way of living and earning his living; and apart from the few traders, missionaries, and government officials, he comes into contact with but few of the white population.

The northern Indian does not really require very much education from a scholastic viewpoint. If he acquires a grade four standing, he has all that he needs in that way, and he can acquire this if he goes to school from the age of seven years until he is fourteen, or even thirteen, after which, his father or guardian, should take him in hand, and teach him how to earn his living.

The establishment of 'Residential Schools' in this north country, for the education of Indian children, is, in my opinion, a mistake. There are but three ways for the northern Indian to earn his livelihood, namely, Hunting, Trapping and Fishing, (apart from a little freighting he may get in the summer time), and none of these things can possibly be taught him at a residential school. The difference between the northern and the prairie Indian can here be noticed, as the prairie Indian usually returns to his reserve, after leaving the residential school, and begins to farm, having learned much of farming at the residential school, further. To build and equip a residential school, to accommodate say 100 pupils, would require a cash outlay of $150,000 at the very least. In addition, there would be the annual grant of $17,500. The same number of pupils could be given all the education -

R.A. Hoey Esq;
Superintendent of Welfare & Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.;
education they will ever need, in at most, three, Day Schools situated right on their reserves, and three such schools could be established at very much less cost than one Residential school, and the cost of operation would be very much less. There are, in this agency, ten day schools, (two of which are but 'seasonal' schools), which accommodate approximately twice as many pupils as the Norway House Residential School, and at little more than half the cost, and the pupils of these schools get, as a general rule, all the education they need.

With regard to the sending out of pupils from the north country to residential schools where a higher education is given, such as Brandon, and keeping them there until they are eighteen years of age; this, in my opinion, is the greatest mistake of all. There are two or three instances of this here at Norway House. These pupils returned here after graduating from Brandon school. They have a better scholastic education than those who remained here and went to day school, but they have absolutely no idea about making a living in the bush, and their higher education is of no benefit to them whatever.

The ideal way to educate the Indian children of this northern country is through the day schools, situated on their reserves. They are thus with their own people all the time, and in addition to daily attendance at the day school, they are learning from their parents the rudiments of the methods they themselves will have to adopt after they leave school, to make their living. This gives them better all round equipment for a livelihood than can be acquired by attending the residential schools.

The foregoing are simply my own opinions of course, and are the conclusions I have arrived at after three and a half years of experience in the north. As already stated, they are forwarded to you at Mr M. Christianson's request, and I trust they may be of some little use to you.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No; 123-1-1 of the 6th April, which I received yesterday the 19th April, having reference to the proposed erection of an improved Indian Day School at the Cross Lake Reserve, and enclosing a copy of a letter on the same subject, addressed by The Honourable the Minister, to the Rt Rev: Bishop Lajeunesse.

I have to-day dispatched a radio telegraphic message to you, advising that it is impossible to visit the Cross Lake Reserve by any method of travel now, until after the break up of the ice. The mail plane has ceased operations with yesterday's delivery of mail, and the ice conditions are now too bad to travel by dog team. I will, however, make the trip as soon as possible after open water.

In the meantime, until I can visit Cross Lake, I might reply to some portions of your letter.

With regard to a site for the school, at Cross Lake, there would be no difficulty of any sort.

As to material still available from the old school that was destroyed by fire, I may say that almost all the walls, of stone masonry, are still standing, about 30 feet or more high. These walls are very thick, and the razing of them would entail a considerable amount of labour, which will need to be considered in the cost, if this material is to be used in the construction of the new school.

With reference to the actual construction of the school, I would suggest that this be done by day labour, under the direct supervision of some capable and trustworthy foreman. If this method were adopted, the foreman would need to bring with him two or three experienced stone masons, and two or three carpenters, to do the actual building, and local Indians could be hired as labourers. In this case, it would be necessary of course to keep accurate record daily of the work done by each individual, and as there is no permanent Departmental employee located at Cre's Lake, this duty would have to be given to some other trustworthy person; probably the Priest in charge of the mission might look after this.

I do not favour the suggestion that a grant of approximately $25,000

R.A.Hoey Esq;
Suptt of Welfare & Training

$25,000 be handed to the church authorities, and allow them to proceed with the work of construction, because in the great majority of cases, the church officials are not business people, and they are more concerned with church interests in cases of this nature than they are with Indian Department interests, and at the conclusion of the project, the Indian Affairs Branch would almost certainly be asked to pay out considerably more funds than originally granted. I have learned this from experience.

With regard to the calling for tenders, and having the work done by contract; I do not think that the work could be done any more economically this way, than by day labour. With a contractor, it is of course all to his interest to get the job done as quickly as possible, and in this endeavour might possibly skimp the work in places, in order to make time. He would also no doubt want to bring his own crew with him, and this would deprive a number of the local Indians of much needed work. It would also be necessary to appoint an inspector of construction to oversee the work, which would be an added expense.

With regard to classroom accommodation: I am of the opinion that three rooms would be ample. According to the Minister's letter to the Bishop, the idea is, to provide for 50 resident pupils. The large majority of these would of course have to be recruited from other reserves of the agency, and there should be no difficulty in that. However, as to day school pupils, I may say that the highest quarterly average attendance attained during the past two years, was 20, and the average quarterly attendance for these two years, is 14.8. If classroom accommodation is provided for a total of 80 pupils, including the 50 resident ones, this should cover all the requirements I think, and three rooms, with the basement, would be sufficient, seating approximately 35 pupils each.

The lumber, sash, doors, windows, and other building materials for the construction, would have to be shipped in from Winnipeg.

I would like, here, to mention a point that has probably not as yet been considered; and that is, that this new school should be erected here at Norway House, instead of at Cross Lake. At Norway House, the school would be within easy reach of the agency, and the doctor and the hospital; and could be visited much more frequently than if it were at Cross Lake. If the school were established here of course, all the materials for the building would have to be provided, as there would not be any stone from the old building walls to use. However, the Rev. Father Chamberland, who is the Priest in charge to act as Principal at Cross Lake has spoken to me about this proposed new school, and it is his desire to have it erected at Whiskeyjack Portage, which is about 15 miles from the old school site at Cross Lake in which case again, none of the stone from the old building would be available for use. Another consideration is freighting facilities. At Norway House, all through the navigation season, we have a weekly boat from Winnipeg; whereas at Whiskeyjack, to where freight for Cross Lake is shipped, there are only two boat trips a year made, by a small tug and barge, one trip -
trip is made about the second week in June, and the other about two weeks before the close of navigation in the fall. This point should no doubt be considered whether the school is built either at Cross Lake or Whiskeyjack.

With regard to the resident pupils, which will have to be recruited from all the reserves of the agency, there is no greater merit in having the school at Cross Lake than at Norway House. As you are no doubt aware, since the old school was destroyed by fire, the Cross Lake P.C. Indian Residential School has been operated in two separate units, one at Cross Lake, and the other here at Norway House. The pupilage allowed is 30. At Cross Lake there are 10 resident girl pupils, and here at Norway House there are 20 resident pupils; 10 boys and 10 girls. If the building were built at Norway House, on the present R.C.Mission site, there would be no difficulty in getting needed materials week by week as required, whereas, as stated above, there are only two trips a year made by boat to carry freight to Cross Lake, and unless everything needed were sent out on the first trip, the work might possibly be held up. There is no telegraphic communication with Cross Lake, and mail service but once every two weeks, and at Norway House there is radio telegraph, and a weekly mail service. In these circumstances, if there happened to be a shortage of material at Cross Lake, it would take considerable time to procure it. At Cross Lake, they have a new day school building, erected about two years ago. If the proposed new improved school were to be built at Norway House, I would recommend that dormitory accommodation for about 60 pupils be provided, and the same classroom accommodation as suggested if the school were to be built at Cross Lake, namely, three rooms, for about 35 pupils each.

The advantages of having this school at Norway House occurred to me, and I have simply presented them for your consideration.

As the mail service to and from Norway House has now been suspended until open water, this letter will not reach you for some weeks after writing.

Sir,

With further reference to Mr. R.A. Hoey's letter No; 125-1-1 of the 6th April, and my reply thereto of the 20th April, regarding the proposed new improved Indian day school, which it is proposed to construct at the Roman Catholic Mission at the Cross Lake reserve, I beg to advise you that I returned last night from a visit to the Cross Lake reserve.

I spent a day at the R.C.Mission with the Rev. A. Chamberland O.M.I., the Priest in charge, and with him, went over the ground carefully.

As stated in my letter of the 20th April, there are still the masonry walls of the old school building standing, some of the materials of which could no doubt be used in the construction of the new school. These walls are about 30 feet high, I should judge, and are over two feet thick. There is one portion of these walls, which were the walls of the chapel portion of the old school, which are in very good condition, with the exception of two small cracks in the masonry. The outside measurements of this portion are 36' X 60', and one end adjoins the walls of the main building. Father Chamberland suggested that probably these walls might serve as they are, for one of the units of the new school, provided the two cracks mentioned were properly repaired, which would not be difficult. However, I think that a more expert opinion than mine should be secured before definitely deciding that these walls were sound enough to make use of as they are. There is a basement under this chapel portion, which is of course full of rubbish at present. There is stone in the old walls, sufficient to build both units of the proposed new school, and all the foundations, as well as one can tell at present, are still sound. Apart from the stone, there is no material left from the old school which could be used in the new one.

The site at Cross Lake is good, being on the lake shore, and of course close to an ample supply of good water. There is a very good lot of buildings, such as barn, machine shed, workshop, hen house, etc., and all these are in first class condition. There is also a small acreage of land cultivated, but sufficient to take care of their needs for garden purposes, grain for the animals and fowl, and so on.

All materials such as windows, doors, roofing, flooring, hardware etc., would have to be shipped in; from Winnipeg which is the nearest shipping center.

In my letter of the 20th April, I mentioned a suggestion—

that consideration might be given to Norway House as the location for the new school. I discussed this matter with Father Chamberland, but he could not, of course make any definite statement without the sanction of his Bishop. However, both Norway House and Cross Lake have each a number of advantages that the other lacks. Norway House has by far the better shipping and communication facilities. From Winnipeg, the freight rate to Norway House is 60¢ per 100 lbs, whereas the rate to Cross Lake, via Whiskeyjack Portage, (usually but twice a year), is between $1.25 and $1.50 per 100 lbs. Norway House has weekly freight and mail service throughout the summer. Cross Lake has but two freight deliveries a year; one in June and one in September and mail service every two weeks. Norway House has radio-telegraph service, and Cross Lake has none. At Norway House, however, they already have outbuildings, and a small acreage of farm land under cultivation. At Norway House they have some buildings, but there is practically no land that can be cultivated excepting small patches for gardens. It would be impossible to operate a farm, even a small one, in connection with the school at Norway House, but this is possible on a small scale at Cross Lake. The raising of cattle would be out of the question at Norway House, there being no pasturage or land to cultivate. However, it is the consensus of opinion here that the Indian schools would be better off as far as health is concerned, if the cows were done away with, and Drimilk or Trumilk used. At the present time, the United Church Residential School at Norway House keep a few cows, but all the milk they get is boiled before it is used. I am of the opinion that all these cows are T.B. infected, and Dr Turpel has expressed this opinion many times. If the new school were to be established at Norway House, it would be much better from the Agency and the Medical standpoints also.

This letter, and my letter to Mr R.A.Hoey of the 20th April, contain, I think, all the information requested in Mr Hoey's letter of the 6th April. If any further information is required I shall be glad to be advised.

Sir,

At the request of Councillor William Thomas Towers, No; 320 Norway House Band, I am writing to the Department to see if anything might be done, to have the case of George Paynter reviewed, with the object of securing this boy's freedom from the Stoney Mountain Penitentiary on parole.

The boy George Paynter, was convicted, I understand, in August 1930, of setting fire to the Cross Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, which resulted in the deaths of 12 of the pupils of the school, and the Sister Superior. I understand also, that the boy's preliminary hearing was held at Norway House, and that he was committed for trial. The trial was held in Winnipeg, and the boy was sentenced to life imprisonment, since which time he has been confined in the penitentiary at Stoney Mountain, Manitoba.

This boy, George Paynter, lost both parents when very young, and was adopted by William Thomas Towers at the age of 5 years. When 7 years of age, he was sent to the R.C. Residential School at Cross Lake, where he attended for approximately nine years. He was 16 years of age at the time of the burning of the school in February 1930. Another pupil was concerned in the burning of the school, with George Paynter, but was given a short term of imprisonment only, and released. This boy's name, I am told, was Nelson Hughes.

William Thomas Towers, the guardian of George Paynter, is, I may say, a very fine type of Indian. He is at present one of the Councillors of the Norway House Band, and has been a Chief. He also received the King's Coronation medal. He is a good living man, industrious very honest and dependable, and if George Paynter were allowed to return to him, he would be under good influence.

William Thomas Towers informs me that when George Paynter was at home from the school on holidays, he was always obedient, and never any trouble. If the boy's case were reviewed, his age at the time of the offence might be taken into consideration; also that he has now served almost eight years of his sentence.

Will you kindly advise me if anything might be done in the above matter,

Cross Lake, March 19th, 1941

Dear Sir;

It is the first opportunity I have this year to report about our Ex. Pupils Club. I should say, I think, that it has shown some improvements. Their garden, although this year's crop has been a failure all around, has yielded more than the previous summer. Three new houses have been built, and completed. Two have been started. The members have kept their good will and we expect them to make more efforts to improve their condition. However when one deals with the Indian problem, he has to keep in mind, that not only one aspect of their mentality, but to a certain extent all their nature have to be changed. It is evident that this can not be done in a couple years of training. One can not expect astonishing and immediate results. If there is any progress, even if hardly noticeable, we should be satisfied, because it is a step forward, a greater aptitude to receive more education, more training and thus to come to a better living.

I have kept in mind the idea of having a small carpenter shop for our alumni. This project starts to be realized at present. We use the old Day School for this purpose and the tools you have supplied. This, if properly managed, should bring them to make furnitures for their homes, toboggans, snow-shoes, etc. We have to bring ambition in their heart. We have to keep them busy. The more they will work, the more they will like to work and the more they will be fitted to do so.

There is lots they can do by their own means. They need somebody to push them to do it, to tell them how to do it, and encourage them while they do it.
Brother Menard has done very much in this regard so far. To meet adequately this problem it would require all his time, what he can not do, at the present time, although he is doing a great deal. If circumstances permit later, I would be only too glad to see him look after this question more extensively.

In a close future the number of our ex-pupils will amount to a couple hundred and over. We have this year more than seventy-five children from this reserve. You can see what opportunity we will have to train them. I am well convinced that the good done by the school will avail to very little if there is no post-school adapted training. When a graduate is leaving school and goes back home, in a very short time he is not different that the ordinary Indians. I believe that the real work has to be done after school time, I emphasize this and I am sure it is important.

New problems will have to be faced within twenty years. Twenty years ago the Cross Lake population was around four hundred. It is close now around eight hundred. This means that in a same period of time the population normally should be up to twelve hundred at least. The trapping ground will be the same, if not smaller as the Provincial Government has started to lease to white trappers trapping grounds around the country where our Indians are trapping. As probably it will be the same case for the surrounding reserves, you can see what will happen, and the gravity of the question. We should foresee this situation and act accordingly.

I am very pleased to hear that the Department is going to establish muskrats farms around this settlement and in many other places. It is a very wise, and vital undertaking, and should be given an immediate attention. The soonerest will be the better. These farms should provide a good amount of earning to the Indians. However, in the course of time if the number of these farms increases considerably the prices for the muskrats will drop probably. Nevertheless it will always be a great source of revenues.

I am confident that in these farms the beavers being well protected will multiply rapidly. To my opinion, if this happens and I believe it will, it should help very much the Indians. There will be always a good demand for beaver and the prices should keep high.
These sources of revenues are going to be the most important ones, but at the same time gardening, home industries, etc. will prove very helpful to them. They have to be increased and encouraged.

We have already try this with the Ex-Pupils and it is our intention to keep on. We are studying also about the goats. Doctor Corrigan has expressed us his great wish to see us experimenting with them. I have written to Rev. Father Brochet of Pine Falls to find out what are the results he has with them and the possibility to have the Indians keep them in a profitable way. I did not get the answer yet, but as soon as he replies to my letter, I will decide and let you know. So far I am inclined to think it would be a very useful animal for the Indians.

I am sending you a requisition for building materials and also for some tools. I am fully aware of the war conditions in which we are, but I would be very obliged if you could buy these necessary materials and tools.

I feel very thankful for what you have done in the past. I remain

Yours very truly,

Albert Chamberland O.M.I.

Honourable and Dear Sir:

In compliance with your wishes expressed during your recent visit here in The Pas, I am now exposing the conditions of tuberculosis in which the Indians of Norway House and neighborhood are suffering and I wish to offer you our services for the foundation of a sanatorium at that place.

In the five reserves coming under the jurisdiction of the Norway House agency (Norway House, Cross Lake, Oxford House, God's Lake and Island Lake) there are about four thousand (4,000) treaty Indians that are actually deprived of all medical care in what regards tuberculosis. During my visit in that district this summer, I was told that whenever a patient was found suffering from this disease, there was nothing further that could be done for him. He was obliged to return to his home to die a miserable death after having spread the germs of his disease among his own people at home and neighborhood.

The idea of having a sanatorium in this central district in the North does not originate with us; it was Dr. Turple who first expressed the thought. Dr. Corrigan also recognizes such a necessity.

The main reasons rendering such an institution indispensable can be grouped as follows:

1. The hospital at Norway House is already too small to accept ordinary cases and is actually unable to offer further accommodations for contagious cases as tuberculosis.
2. In having a separate building as a sanatorium for these cases, the same doctor could look after both groups of patients, hence a reason of economy on this point.

3. Owing to the weekly air mail service existing between Norway House and other points, considerable travelling expenses could be saved thereby.

4. Norway House is also central and can be supplied at low cost by water transportation over Lake Winnipeg.

5. Indians suffering from tuberculosis will easily come to Norway House which has ever been their centre for obtaining provisions and other supplies, while they would never go to Winnipeg where they would die of lonesomeness.

6. In the summer, travelling to Winnipeg from Norway House is not too costly and in the event of some patient requiring special surgical care, he could always be sent if necessary after being prepared and disposed to while at the Norway House sanatorium.

What we have to offer in co-operation with you in establishing such an institution is this:

Since the re-opening of the Indian Residential School at Cross Lake, we are no longer allowed to have any treaty children at the school at Norway House. Because of this, our school at Norway House is practically vacant. It is only being used as a day school, which we could easily otherwise provide by a separate building. Such a move would leave the actual school totally and immediately convertible into a sanatorium for tubercular cases. In fact, we could immediately have accommodations for fifteen patients without a single cent being disbursed by the Government for constructions.

We believe this undertaking so necessary and so urgent that we are willing to receive T.B. patients for whatever retribution the Department of Indian Affairs
Will judge reasonable. The basis for such estimations can well be that of the expenses per capita incurred for the maintenance of the Dynavor Sanatorium. All we ask is a little help to begin this work.

We hope, Honourable Sir, that this summary of information will enable you to understand the situation at Norway House and that despite our hard times you will be able to find means and ways to remedy existing conditions among the above mentioned Indians for what we think is a minimum initial cost and which can easily be effected this very summer.

signed: Martin "ajeunesse, O, M.I.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Rev. M. LaJeunesse, O.M.I., Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin, visited the Department recently and discussed with the officials of the Welfare & Training Service the possibility of increasing the pupilage at the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. In view of the fact that the Medical Officer at the Norway House Agency had expressed the opinion that the Cross Lake School was overcrowded, the Bishop suggested that the overcrowding at Cross Lake could be overcome by again placing children in the building owned by the Diocese of Keewatin near Norway House. This particular building has accommodation for approximately 25 children and was used for several years following the destruction of the Cross Lake Residential School by fire some years ago.

The Bishop pointed out that the overcrowding at the Cross Lake Residential School was due to the large number of children on the Cross Lake Reserve for whom educational facilities are necessary. By placing 25 children in the building at Norway House the number accommodated at the present Cross Lake Residential School could be reduced to 100. At the present time the authorized pupilage at Cross Lake is 100. The Bishop asked that the pupilage at the Beauval Residential School, which is also under his jurisdiction, be reduced from 100 to 80 and the
pupilage at Cross Lake increased from 100 to 120. This would not involve any increased expenditure on the part of the Department.

I feel that the Bishop's suggestion is worthy of favourable consideration and I, therefore, recommend that the Bishop's request be approved.

Dear Dr. Moore:

I have just returned from Cross Lake, where I held tonsil clinic in the school, where I operated on twenty-five children. While there I saw one of the pupils die of tubercular meningitis. This is the third student who has died at the Cross Lake School of tubercular meningitis in the past four months. The student I mention was a little girl seven years old, whom I had seen on my visit in March, and concerning whom I left instructions that she must be kept in bed. I find that my instructions regarding the other children whom I asked to be kept in bed had not been carried out.

I asked that all children from the Reserves other than Cross Lake call at Norway House on the way home for summer holidays to be x-rayed. For some reason this could not be arranged for the God's Lake children, but I did see those from Island Lake and Poplar River. I would recommend that some of these children should not return to school, as they are suffering from tuberculosis.

I feel that I must ask for a very definite ruling on the part of the Department as regards the Cross Lake School, otherwise I must refuse to take any responsibility for the health of these children, and I feel that the Department should protect itself by making such a ruling. As I wrote you in a previous letter, I had always believed that the dormitories at Cross Lake School were designed for 80 children, and yet during the past year they accommodated 100. Aside from the fact of what they are supposed to accommodate, I know that 100 is away too many, as in order to get 100 children in these dormitories, the beds must touch side by side and head to foot. I believe that this question should be settled immediately, and that Mr. Lazenby be instructed to take it up with the Principal either at Treaty time, or at the earliest possible, and by that
I do not mean writing a letter and forgetting about it. I have taken up the matter of overcrowding with the Principal myself, and he has signified to me that he intends to continue with 100 children, unless he received definite instructions from the Department to the contrary. He states that his school cannot operate on the present grant, and continue to make money, unless they have 100 children.

Furthermore, I would recommend, in fact I feel I should insist, that all children entering this school should be x-rayed, in order to protect myself and the Department. I have brought over from Cross Lake enough children whom I had x-rayed a year or two years ago, to know that many of them must have developed tuberculosis in the school during the past year.

I would also recommend that no children from Island Lake be allowed to enter this school, or the Norway House Boarding School. As I have told you before I believe that the Island Lake people have very little immunity to Tuberculosis and I do not believe they should be brought out and mixed with people who have practically 100% infection.

Could you please give me an early reply.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I received last night the copy of the letter that you sent to Bishop M. Lajeunesse on the 13th of July. I wish also to thank you sincerely for the copy of a report sent to the Department by Doctor Corrigan in reference to tuberculosis amongst the children of Cross Lake Residential School. As this report of Dr. Corrigan contains some exaggerations and false assertions, I feel that it is my duty to protest against such a statement by retracting some affirmations which to my opinion could not be proved by Dr. Corrigan, as they are merely the effects of his prejudicial ideas, seeing nothing else but tuberculosis all over.

I am just as much if not more interested than Dr. Corrigan to see that tuberculosis will not spread in the school and I told the Doctor that the children were not catching tuberculosis in the school, but on their reserves where they spend two months with people contaminated with disease such as T.B. They come back to school after holidays with that sickness and only waiting for a cold or an epidemic to awake and develop the germs of T.B.

I told the Doctor, that according to my opinion, it is impossible to free the school from such cases and if the Department wants to avoid such deficiency, he should start first by cleaning the Reserves and then this great problem would be easily solved for the schools.

In his report, the Doctor says that in the four past months, three children died in the school of Tubercular Meningitis. To my knowledge, only two died of that sickness. The girl that died in February, died of kidney trouble. Then, Mary Dixon, who died of Tubercular Meningitis at Norway House Hospital, was sick when the doctor was here in May. He ordered the child to be sent immediately. Regarding this girl, a year ago in May, we sent her to Norway House Hospital, as she had swollen T.B. glands on the neck. In the summer, the doctor advised me to discharge her and so I did. Last fall, he sent her back to school by the last plane, with those glands still running. If he had sent her straight home, as it was understood, maybe we would not have lost the little Martha Rivers who also died of T.Meningitis. This child was in bed in March when the doctor was here, and we kept her in bed nearly all the time until we removed her from the infirmary where Mary Dixon started to develop T.Meningitis.

In February, there was an epidemic on the Reserve, and of course nearly all the children had it too. Some remained very weak and ran a temperature for a long time. When the doctor came in March, he said that some of the children should be kept in bed for three, four and six months. I told him that I was not keeping a hospital or a sanatorium, and that I was going to send him to Norway House Hospital. He replied that he had no room for them. I suggested to send some of them to The Pas Hospital. As he did not want this to be done, we kept the children in bed until we thought they were well enough to be up. The epidemic on the Reserve lasted from February until April and there was no doctor and no nurse on the Reserve to look after these people; so the consequence was that the children of the school were sick twice. The nurse of the school had not enough time to look after the Indians of the Reserve.

In July, 1942, the Chief and the Indians sent a petition to the Department asking for a graduated mess on the Reserve, but the petition was not taken into consideration by the Department, and the result was that with this epidemic last winter, some weak children of the school were sick and developed T.B. in the school.

(1) To the Hospital!
In his report of July 1943, Doctor Corrigan asked that all children should be X-rayed. I wished this to be done a long time ago. It was impossible to have the God's Lake children sent to Norway House to be X-rayed before going back home; but these had been X-rayed before entering the school. Only a few of our own children of Cross Lake had been X-rayed before being accepted in the school, as it is not very handy to have them sent to Norway House just for that purpose; though I feel that the Department should have some arrangements made to this effect. But if this cannot be easily done, seems as if there is another way of finding out if a child has active T.B. or not.

I think that when the doctor fills the Physical Examination on the Application Form for admission, should at least take the ordinary means to examine the children. Since I am here, I have never seen him use a stethoscope to examine children's chest as he seems to have faith only in the X-Ray. I think that at least if this ordinary precaution was taken, it would help avoiding children to be accepted and who are already contaminated. Moreover, last summer, the doctor accepted some children whom he thought had T.B. but believed that the best place for them after all was in school. Why, now, does he seem to blame the school and says in the last paragraph of his report that we have practically 100% infection here? If he thinks there is so much infection, he must not blame me for over-crowding the school, which is false too.

The pupilage of the school authorized by the Department, was 100, and we never had that number yet. Dr. Corrigan, I believe, had in his mind that the dormitories were made to accommodate only 80, and this is why he still believes and insists that the pupilage should be reduced to 80. At present we have 95 beds in the dormitories and it is not true as he states in his report that the beds must touch side by side, head to foot. They were touching head to foot when he came in the dormitories, but this had been done to have a space of eight feet in the center. He never measured the dormitories to find out if there was a sufficient number of cubic feet for the number of children we had. I am sure that we have enough cubic feet and flooring to accommodate at least 96 children.

I told Dr. Corrigan that it was impossible to administrate this school with only 80 children, and that, so as not to have a deficit at the end of the year, we had to continue to operate with 100. He states that I said it took 100 children to continue to make money. We are not making money even with 100 children but he takes that number to make both ends meet. It is the same expense to run the school for 100 or for 80. So if the Department cuts the pupilage to eighty children, it means that we will be at least $3000 short every year. So our dormitories can easily accommodate 95 children. I hope the Department will not reduce the pupilage to 80, and by so doing, oblige us to suffer a deficit of $3000 yearly.

I am also anxious to have all the Cross Lake children X-rayed before they are admitted to the school and also will suggest that we have the clinic again soon and that all the Indians of this Reserve be examined by X-Ray too.

Regarding the Island Lake children, I am very willing not to accept any new ones in the school, but suggest that those that are already accepted should come back after summer holidays, provided that they do not have active T.B.

Dear Mr. Hozy, you may be assured, that my great and most sincere desire is to cooperate with the Department and that it has never been my intention to keep T.B. children in the school, being aware of it. In fact, I have discharged some whom I thought could be a danger of contamination to others.

Hoping that these well meant remarks may have enlightened you in some way concerning the present condition of our school, I feel confident that the Department will agree as to not reducing the pupilage as was suggested by Dr. Corrigan, as he will not be the one to carry all the worries of administrating the school, or to pay for the deficit at the end of the year.

I would be most grateful to you and would appreciate most highly, an answer from you before school re-opens.

With kind personal regards, I remain,

Very Sincerely Yours,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have your letter of September 21st, file 123-1-1, together with a copy of Father Trudeau's letter.

In the first place I would like to quote you the following:

Part III, Division 14, Section 189(a) and (b) of the Regulations under the Public Health Act of the Province of Manitoba:

(a) All rooms in dwellings or other buildings used for sleeping purposes shall contain not less than 400 cubic feet of air space for each adult and 200 cubic feet for each child under 12 years of age occupying the same and in addition provision shall be made for continuous air change or circulation. There shall also be provided in all rooms occupied for sleeping purposes a floor area of at least 40 sq. ft. per person.

(b) The medical officer of health shall require a floor area of not less than 40 sq. feet per person in any room occupied for sleeping purposes when in his opinion such is required to safeguard the health of the occupants of such premises.

From these figures it is easy to see that on the basis of floor space each dormitory should accommodate 37 or 38 children. However, I believe we are safe enough with 40 in each dormitory. When you work it out on the basis of cubic feet and take an average of 300 cubic feet, as the children range in age from 6 to 15 years, you will find that you have cubic feet enough for 56 children, due to the very high ceilings.
However, it would be a physical impossibility to put 56 children in these dormitories. However, the cubic feet should not be considered in this matter because I believe the Department itself has always insisted on 500 cubic feet per child. Therefore, I feel that we must stick very closely to the Health Act and insist on 40 sq. ft. to the individual. I explained this to Father Trudeau when he was at Norway House and it was probably unfortunate that I was not very good in mathematics that day. However, this is a fact I think he should not have taken advantage of. In dealing with Indian children who are so susceptible to tuberculosis I feel that we should take every precaution to guard them against this disease, and I believe that adequate accommodation is one of the easiest methods. Further than that, I believe that for the good of the Department and in order to protect ourselves, we should insist upon this regulation. I feel that another epidemic of tuberculosis occurs in the Cross Lake School with a similar number of deaths as there were this spring, it could well destroy the School and the confidence of the Indians in the Department. Please believe me when I say that there is no malicious intent on my part in any of this and that I have only the best interests of the School at heart.

During the last Treaty at Cross Lake many of the parents of the pupils of the Cross Lake School came to me and wanted to know why so many children had been sick, and why some had died in the School. I find it very difficult to protect ourselves in these cases.

Yours truly,

Cameron Corrigan, M.D.

Dear Dr. Moore:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 21st.

The policy of this department in respect to accommodations in dormitories is that we try to follow out the provisions of the Health Act which states in section six of division one, part five of the regulations as follows:

"The minimum floor area of any bedroom shall be sixty square feet and the minimum height of the ceiling, eight feet."

We believe that in institutions where there is a chance of communicable diseases amongst the inmates there should be a greater floor space area — at least seventy feet and in those parts of the institution at Portage la Prairie where we have reason to believe that there is communicable diseases, such as tuberculosis, we try to insist on at least seventy square feet. In many of our ordinary wards at Portage la Prairie at the present time, due to a shortage of staff, where we have had to close wards and place patients in other wards, there has been some irregularity in the standards but I should say that our area is not less than fifty square feet of floor space.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have your letter of April 3 with reference to George Paynter, serving a life sentence in connection with the burning of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School, Manitoba.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I have just received a letter from reverend Father Rivard in charge of the Roman Catholic mission at Norway House in which he informs me that there are about 200 Catholic Indians in his mission and that 45 children attend the combination Day and Residential School operated in connection with the mission. Fourteen of these are boarders, and the balance are day pupils. I understand that since the school was established, biscuits have been supplied for the noonday meal of the children, but no sugar or tea was ever received. No allowance either is given for fuel. It would be very much appreciated if help could be given along these lines.

So far, only 25 aviator uniforms were given to the school; there were no overcoats or army clothing; if any of the above are available, it would be much appreciated if you could send another consignment to Norway House. This military clothing is very useful to the school to train the older girls in cutting and sewing, and supplies the poorer Indians with needed apparel.

Through their missionary, reverend Father Rivard, the Indians have asked for two barges which they could use very profitably for the transportation of cordwood, hay, lumber and horses. These Indians live on a strip of land fifteen miles long, and their only method of transportation is the lake and the river. Part of the Indians are on one side of the lake, and the others live along both banks of the river. They, therefore, have to use both the lake and the river for the transportation of all the goods which they buy and the cordwood and lumber which they sell. The building of these
two barges should not be costly as the Indians have a sawmill or at least one which could be used for this purpose. Father Rivard is informed that help of this nature was granted to the Indians of Cross Lake. This is a matter which deserves consideration, for anything that can help the Indians to earn their own living should not be lightly refused when a request for it is made.

Would it be possible for you to look in the case of the D'Arcis children whose mother is an unmarried Treaty woman. I understand that there is no one at the present time looking after the welfare of these children. They certainly can be considered as orphans and waifs. If a favorable decision could be arrived at in the immediate future, these children could be accepted in the Norway House School for the September quarter.

Several of the Norway House Indians have gardens in which they raise most of the ordinary vegetables, and their potato crop is generally very good. Their only place for storing the above is the mission root-house. Whilst the missionary is willing to help, the space available is small, and only a few of the Indians can be accommodated. The construction of a large cooperative root-house is something which should be studied and if found feasible be placed on the agenda as a post-war expenditure. Nothing will help more that the cultivation of gardens to make our Indians self-supporting, and anything that will develop such a spirit should be fully encouraged.

Hoping that you will be able to give favorable consideration to the above matters, I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

I wish to submit the following report on the schools of the Norway House Agency, inspected in June, 1945.

Cross Lake R.C. Indian Boarding School

There are 95 pupils enrolled and all but the Cross Lake pupils had left before my arrival.

This was my first visit to the new school and I was greatly impressed with the very excellent building.

The dormitories were spotless, well aired and very bright. The beds were quite close together but with all the windows I am sure the children have plenty of fresh air. The bedding was clean and there was abundance.

The classrooms were very bright and the walls nicely decorated. The desks, although in use for some years, were almost without a scratch. I am certain from the books seen that the Sisters do very excellent work in the classroom.

I examined the work done in the sewing-room and must admit that the girls do splendid sewing. They make dresses, knit all kinds of garments and do very excellent patch work and darning.

The kitchen and dining rooms were in excellent order and the girls receive a good training in cooking and baking. The children seen were in good health and I am sure are well cared for and well fed.

This school is situated in an isolated area and the Rev. Father is greatly concerned and rightly so about his one engine and generator. If the engine should fail at any time the school would be without light or water - in fact, it could not continue to operate. I think a second unit should be installed. There is plenty of room, consequently no additional expenses will be required.

(over)
for building purposes. The total cost would be for the engine generator and wages for someone to see that it is properly installed. I think the Department should give this request serious consideration. If the school were close to a railroad I would not make the recommendation; but a bad break in equipment at this isolated point would be serious and perhaps repairs could not be secured for weeks. There are often weeks when communication to the outside is impossible and this is especially bad at freeze-up and again in the spring during break-up.

The hot water tank which hangs by the furnace also must be renewed. I understand Mr. Lazenby has the particulars and is submitting the necessary requisition. This should be ordered and sent forward at once.

The school has a large garden; which this year was planted late and of course was not up when I was there. The Rev. Father keeps some very fine Holstein cows, a flock of hens and some pigs. The school is under excellent management and the children appeared very happy. The operating of such an excellent school in this remote area is a great credit to the Church and Government. The Rev. Father Trudeau is interested in his work and is assisted by an excellent staff of Sisters.

Dear Sir:

Two days ago I received your letter of May the 10th dealing with the complaint of Bello Ross that in the Cross Lake Boarding School: "...they make the children learn to pray and make them learn the Cree, to write".

First of all I do not see anything wrong in teaching the children how to pray as a good education has to be based on religious convictions. The Manitoba School Programme which we follow here allows us half an hour a day for teaching of Religion and we do not take more time every day for the teaching of catechism. I must say that we teach them their prayers in Cree which is their own language so they won't be at a loss to pray with their parents when they go back home. Jack MILLER, 8 yrs., & Absalom COOK, 11 yrs., (Juveniles) Cross Lake, I.R., Manitoba.
Attempted Arson, Sec. 512 C.C. Contrary to Sec. 3(1) Juv. Act.

Act, the writer has to report that on the morning of the 26-9-49, Father TRUHAN, Principal of St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at Cross Lake, Manitoba reported that the optionally noted juveniles had intended to set a fire to the school in question in the early hours of the morning of the same date.

2. TRUHAN stated that Sister St. Marcel had reported same to him and that further information would be received from her as she had already questioned all the boys and had obtained most of the necessary information.

3. Sister St. Marcel was contacted and the following information received. She stated that she was awakened by a commotion in the boys dormitory about 2:30 a.m. of the same morning. She quickly dressed and entered the room in question, noticing, as she entered that all, except 6 boys, were out of their beds, some were getting dressed, some were already dressed and waiting. She went into the centre of the room and asked the boys what was going on. None of the boys answered, then she told them to get dressed and get back into bed. The boys looked frightened she stated but did as they were told. She was still at loss to know why all the commotion until she asked one of the smaller boys what had happened. The small boy said that Henry Rivers BLACKSMITH and James HOKAY had woke them up and told them to get up, get dressed and get ready to run away if they did not want to get burned. The smaller boys were under the impression that there was already a fire and quoted they were frightened even after the Sister told them there was no fire. The boys went back to bed and Sister St. Marcel stayed up the remaining part of the night to prevent a recurrence of the previous disturbance.

4. The writer requested to see the optionally noted boys and they were called from their class room by Sister Superior. The boys were questioned and each boy told what he knew only blaming it onto the other. They were then brought together and then they admitted that they, jointly, had planned to start a fire at the time concerned, 2:30 a.m. of the 25-9-49, and then run away before anyone found out about the fire. They admitted that, had the Sister not entered the room when she did, they would have gone down into the furnace room and started the fire as there was a lot of wood piled there along with a lot of paper and scrap wood.

P.T.C.
They also stated that they did not want to see any of the boys burned so they woke them up and warned them about a fire. On questioning the other boys from the dormitory, they all stated that it was Blacksmith and McKay who told them to get ready and run away. Thus the two boys also admitted too.

It should be stated here that in the evening of the 26-9-49 at approximately 6:30 p.m., Sister St. Alfred came to the writer with Blacksmith, stating that she had caught him going into the dormitory with his cap in his pocket, something that was very unusual and unreasonable. As Blacksmith was the big instigator in several attempted runaways amongst the boys and also the leader on the occasion the boys did run away from school, she thought another attempt was to be made. The writer questioned the boy about the cap but the boy stated that he had forgotten to leave it in the cloak room downstairs. It was learned later that both the above mentioned boys had their caps in their pockets, only that McKay had passed unnoticed at the time.

The writer patrolled from Cross Lake, Manitoba to Norway House, Manitoba on the 26-9-49, and reported the contents of above report to the Constable in charge of Norway House Detachment who then suggested the following Radio-phonogram be sent to Father Thibault, Principal of the Residential School at Cross Lake, Manitoba.

Advertising to the above, the writer has to report that on the 26-9-49, Father TRUDEAU, Principal of the St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at Cross Lake, Manitoba reported that the captionally noted boys had started a fire in a woodpile behind the school, presumably with the intention that the fire should set fire to and destroy the school.

He stated that at approximately 5:30 p.m. of the 25-9-49 one of the farm hands came into the school dining room to report that there was a fire in the woodpile behind the school. Father TRUDEAU and Brother Mabard ran into the engine room and pulled out the fire hoses and immediately forced water into the section of woodpile that was burning. The fire was extinguished with little effort as the wood being very wet, did not get a head start. About one quarter of a cord of wood is all that was damaged.

TRUDEAU stated that the boys were questioned and the captionally noted boys along with another boy, Joseph ROSS, aged 12 years, also from the school, admitted their knowledge of the fire and admitted to having been the instigators.

The three boys were questioned and all seemed to give the same story regarding the fire. The boys stated that COOK suggested to ROSS they start a fire under the woodpile. ROSS was to light the fire and COOK said he would stand by and watch for any intruders. ROSS told COOK to give the match to MILLER. COOK and ROSS told MILLER to start the fire and they would watch for anyone coming along and warn MILLER if someone did come. MILLER readily took the match from COOK and started a fire with some kindling and pushed the fire well under the woodpile to make sure that the wood would get a good start. COOK and ROSS were standing close by watching MILLER. When the fire started they ran into the school as the bell had rang, which was the dinner bell and meant that the boys were to be already lined up.

On further questioning it was learned that the boys had in mind the fact that if the woodpile got burning hard enough, it would start the school burning too. This was due to the fact that there had been a lot of unrest amongst the boys in the school. Boys kept running away quite regularly and no amount of talking to by parents, the Principal or the writer would have any effect whatsoever. They would promise at each time they were returned to the school never to run away again but within a week there was sure to be another attempt or two made. P.T.O.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Right Reverend Sir,

In further reference to Your Lordship's communication of February 1st, last, with which was enclosed a sketch plan for the proposed new Roman Catholic Boarding School at Norway House I beg to say that our architect has completed a sketch which I am sending to you, under separate cover, by registered mail.

Dear Sir,

I am returning to you the sketch plan for the Norway House School.

I am glad you have prepared it in order to have this school graded in the class A, because it was my intention to have it under that qualification.

I have marked down with pen few changes that I suggest to you. First it is about infirmaries. According your plan the both infirmaries for boys and girls have the same entry although separate door. Such disposition will necessitate a perpetual gardian when boys and girls will be in the same time in infirmaries, as they can meet easily at the entry. In the way I suggest they will be more isolated, specially if you agree with the particular designs in the passage. The door of that partition could be locked and prevent any communication.

A private room for the Rev. Sister Superior is needed and I think you have forgotten about it. I design a part of the sisters dormitory but it does not suit very well on account of the door inside of sisters dormitory. It can do however if you cannot find a better way of doing.

Do you think it would not be better to have W.C. for each infirmary? Supposing a contagious case in the Insolated Infirmary the patients in the other infirmary would not be allowed to go W.C. in the same infirmary and consequently they will have no closet for their use. It is a remark. If you think it is sufficient as it is I do not object.

I also make suggestions for the use of the church basement. I

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Pedley,

In June, last, the Department called for tenders for the erection of a boarding school building and a hospital at Norway House and a boarding school building, on the same plan, at the Pas. These plans were prepared by Mr. Burritt, Architect of Ottawa, and the estimated cost of the school, if erected in the Province of Ontario where labour and materials would be readily accessible was $28,000.00 to $30,000.00. The Department received only one tender for the school at Norway House from the Jones Contracting Company for $52,451.00 and the hospital for $15,735.00. The estimated cost for the latter building was $6,360.00 in the east. No tender whatever was received for the building at the Pas.

In view of the fact that the tender received for the Norway House buildings was much above the estimated cost, even allowing for conditions as they exist at Norway House, the late Superintendent General thought it well to
submit these plans to an architect in Winnipeg with a view to having him make changes to reduce the cost. They were given to Mr. Herbert E. Mathews, Architect, Public Works, Winnipeg, Canada.

Last year also a per capita grant was promised the Roman Catholic church for a boarding school at Norway House and they were to erect their own buildings, which would come under Class "A" of the contract. They said they wished to use the plan of the Fort Frances Boarding School as a basis and the Department agreed to furnish them with plans and specifications. Mr. Chene prepared plans based on this with such changes as they asked for and these were sent out to them in sections as they were completed. The Department understood that this work would be done by them by day labour and the plans and specifications were not, therefore, so elaborate and detailed as they would have been had there been intention of calling for tenders. The Roman Catholics commenced their work there, but in the meantime they made representations to the late Superintendent General, when it was decided to provide the cost of erecting the building without the Chapel but including the basement of this building, and an amount of $32,000.00 was provided in the main estimates for 1913-1914. The plans and specifications prepared for
the Roman Catholic school building were also handed over to Mr. Mathews at the same time as the Methodist school plans, with a request, as he states in his letter of the 30th ultimo, that changes be made "with a view to reducing the cost of erection and bring them to conform to requirements which appear to be necessary in the cold North-west outlying district." In his letter of November 30th, above referred to, Mr. Mathews writes as follows:

"The plans of the Roman Catholic School that I was given, appeared to me to admit of some improvement in various particulars, while those of the other two buildings seem to have been worked up on lines which could produce satisfactory, economical construction, and, assuming that the lay out and equipment is approved by the officials directly interested in these buildings, I consider that a reduction in cost may best be arrived at by a reduction in size and equipment of each building, or by a careful adjustment in the specified materials."

You will thus see that the plan of the Norway House building appears to be satisfactory and that a reduction in size and equipment or an adjustment of the specified materials is the only way in which any reduction in cost can be arrived at.

It would not appear practicable to reduce the size of the building, but any reduction that might be made in
the cost of equipment or specified materials which would not detract from the value of the building might be allowed and I would suggest that Mr. Mathews be informed accordingly.

The changes in the plan for the Roman Catholic Boarding School are apparently unimportant and Mr. Mathews might be asked to complete these plans and prepare the necessary specifications.

When the plans for the Roman Catholic school were prepared provision was made for a large chapel, which was to serve the purpose, not only of the school but of the reserve. The Department, as before stated, will not be responsible for the superstructure of the chapel, the cost of which the church will bear. The Department will, however, have to erect the basement, as there is provision therein for the heating apparatus and other accommodation necessary to the school proper. Mr. Mathews has given an approximate estimate of the total cost and the proportion that the Church and Government should bear, Department $46,000, Church $3,500.

As it will take sometime to complete these plans and specifications and as it would be well to have tenders called for so that work could be undertaken early during the coming summer an early decision should be arrived at.

Dear Sir,

As previously arranged we are sending to your Department today by Dominion Express, original tracings, comprising five sheets of drawings and one complete original copy of specifications, comprising 57 pages, prepared for a Roman Catholic Boarding School proposed for erection at Norway House, Manitoba. A location of the buildings is omitted from the drawings and specifications at your request.

We have endeavored to make the plans and specifications complete for a practicable building proposition. Our information is that the building sites are (quite properly) to be high and dry and on that account we have not provided for waterproofing the foundations nor for weeping drains. The concrete walls and floors provided for the building ought to keep water out under ordinary conditions and we feel justified in taking it that extraordinary conditions will be avoided when building sites are selected. You will understand that the taking care of rain water and sewage without a proper system of sewers may prove an expensive proposition and may not be handled in a general way with satisfaction.

In preparing my estimate sent to you on December 26th 1912 placing the cost of the Roman Catholic Boarding School for Norway house at Forty-six thousand dollars, we did not figure on the installation of an acetylene gas lighting system or a water works system because we were then of the opinion that these items which we had noted to be utilities at the Fort Alexander School, were there provided by the Church Authorities.

We have kept a copy of blue prints and several copies of specifications of work sent out today. We presume that your Department will look over our work and make the copies required for the purposes of receiving tenders and for forwarding to the several locations for exhibit to prospective bidders. We trust that you will find our work to be right, and awaiting further instructions, I remain,

Yours truly,

In looking over our prints from original tracings sent to you yesterday for Roman Catholic Indian Boarding School, we have discovered several omissions and inconsistencies which we would request you to correct on the tracings before putting out any prints.

Second, in the matter of ventilation, we have provided for ducts on plans and in specifications but are short in markings for registers on plans. Memorandum,

Schools Branch.

Will you please let me have at once an estimate of the difference of the cost between the construction of the Roman Catholic School building at Norway House and at Cross Lake.

D. S. G. I. A.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6260, file 577-5, part 1)
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

Regarding your inquiry as to the difference in cost between the construction of a school building at Norway House and Cross Lake I beg to say that it is a very difficult matter to give even approximately an estimate, as the transportation rates are so high and uncertain. The material has to be taken down in York boats, or, if by small steamer, frequent portages have to be made.

From the best information I have been able to obtain from the records of the Department it would appear that it would cost from 15 to 20 per cent more to build a boarding school at Cross Lake than at Norway House. The lowest tender for the Methodist School at Norway House, including the hospital, was $76,578.00. Deducting about $20,000.00 for the hospital would leave $57,000.00 for the school building. This would bring the cost of a school building at Cross Lake up to about $70,000.00. We would hardly be able to use the same plan.
plan for Cross Lake as for Norway House, as it is next to impossible to get much of the material called for by the specifications for the Norway House School into Cross Lake.

A much less expensive building would suit all the purposes of Cross Lake and it would not be necessary to make provision for so many pupils. When Father Magman brought up the question of establishing a school at Norway House in 1908 he asked for a building with accommodation for 30 pupils and if they had one with accommodation for 50 this would be about all the pupils they could recruit. It would be next to useless to call for tenders for a building at Cross Lake, as the Church would be the only people who could build there.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Chene,

It is desired that you should as soon as possible modify the plans and specifications of the school building at Cross Lake, Manitoba, so as to reduce the cost materially, having regard to a reasonably substantial building.

D. S. G. I. A.
Ottawa July 25, 1913

Memorandum.

Mr. Pasley,

The accompanying plans could be adopted for a school building at Cross Lake, Manitoba, providing that certain changes be made in the specifications regarding the nature of materials and the plans modified as both appear to be too elaborate and extensive for the locality.

The approximate cost of any of these two buildings without any modification at Norway House would be $48,000.00.

No definite information could be obtained as to the increase of cost for the erection of these buildings at Cross Lake, but, according to the distance and notes on maps, an increase of 25 p.c. can be considered as a minimum making a total of $60,000.00.

A reduction of about $6,000.00 could be made by reducing the plans and changing the specifications.
